content:
Posted: January 5
 Overview  Spacebase DF-9 is a survival game in the wide-reaching void of, you guessed it, space. Your mission is work with a trio of astronauts and build the most sophisticated, comprehensive and long-lasting space station anyone has ever seen. That sounds amazing on paper, and being developed from the veterans over at Double Fine Productions, you’d almost be assured a great game. However, the product falls short and development has long since died for this title, leaving an ugly mess in its wake. In space, nobody can hear you complain.The game opens up with an interesting concept at first – a map laid out with all the locations in the galaxy, letting you pick where you want to start and factoring in variables like meteor showers, derelict ships, traffic for earning more crew members [good and bad] and resources. Once your base is selected, you’re launched into space with three crew members, a space pod for power and oddly, no spaceship; the game starts you out in the dead of space with limited oxygen, limited supplies and a very short time span before your whole crew perishes from asphyxiation. From a logical standpoint, the start of the game makes absolutely no sense and it only gets worse from there.You must quickly build a functioning center with enough life support for your crew. You’ll gather material from nearby asteroids that oddly resemble play-doh, which you will ingeniously craft into oxygen recyclers and stations for power with nothing but a blowtorch and your wits. As the base grows, you’re able to expand, making different rooms that can be retrofitted into housing, laboratories, pubs, infirmaries and more. I like the aspect of building a base to my own liking, but Double Fine really chokes the life out of personalizing it as you see fit: limited items to use, each room can only use furniture from one list of items [I.E. only residential furniture in a residence] which forces you to build a lot of unnecessary rooms for no reason at all. However, my biggest complaint is being in space and not being able to build along the Z axis; you can only build outward, not vertically, which seems like a huge oversight since you’re not hindered by the laws of gravity.As you continue playing, you’ll encounter hazards that you must overcome, such as illness, resource management [marginally], machine repairs, raiders [space pirates] and meteor showers. Most obstacles aren’t all that exciting: meteor showers are not impressive and barely noticeable if the game didn’t tell you it was happening, space pirates have terrible AI capabilities and can easily be killed with a few well-placed defense turrets and most ailments can be cured by simply sending them to the doctor, curing them nearly instantly. Oddly, some of the ailments have auto-cures, such as when I was afflicted with “Space Blindness”, which I was promptly told there was already a cure so I didn’t have to do anything.The real gem to this travesty is the writing, or the lack of a proper writer. Here’s an example of the type of “communications” you’ll received while in space:


My first hail and it was some 13 year old frog who spends to much time on Tumblr. God this game needs a writer. STAT! 
A Screenshot of Spacebase DF-9
By: ErickaUnlimited




I felt secondhand embarrassment just reading it. The writing is dreadful, out of place and just downright terrible. Couple that with other gems like my dead astronaut having a “kinda happy” job satisfaction while simultaneously being dead, but the real winner is that her location is “space”:


Job Satisfaction: "Kinda Happy" - A real optimist considering she's, well, you know, dead. 
A Screenshot of Spacebase DF-9
By: ErickaUnlimited




Yes, everything in this game has "space" attached to it. Your location, beds are called "space beds" and even rugs are called "space rugs" because your typical Ikea rug is not suitable for the vacuum of space apparently.I could go on and on with all the issues with this game, but in the end it has been abandoned completely by Double Fine and is left at the hands of 3rd party modders if they feel like investing their time in such a project. Much like my crew member Nashira Corrino, this game is dead, asphyxiated by its own mediocrity.  Pros   There are none. Cons    The entire game is a con. There are too many to list. The game has been abandoned. Stay away.Overall, Spacebase DF-9 is an absolute mess with broken AI, poor graphics, terrible UI and even worse sound effects. There is literally no reason for you to play this unless you’re punishing yourself and even less reason to buy it unless you’re sending it to someone in hopes of terminating a friendship.

Early Access Review
								Plenty of people have already said this, but more voices never hurt: do not buy this game. It has been pushed from an ALPHA build to 1.0 in ONE UPDATE because the developers ran out of money. The game is mediocre at best - I managed to get almost thirty hours of fun out of it, but I really love this genre. It feels like a hamburger without cheese. You can enjoy it, but the entire time you feel like something essential is missing. Paying 25 dollars for a less than half-finished management game that still suffers from issues it had in the first build ever released (people forgetting to get out of their spacesuit in an airlock and suffocating, panicking when there's low oxygen and running until they choke instead of building more oxygen generators, trying to stomp out fires when there are extinguishers nearby) is a joke. Spend your money on the unfortunately-named RimWorld instead.

Early Access Review
								It's probably best to avoid this. The game was apparently reliant on early access funding and didn't sell enough copies to continue development past an extremely barebones set of features. Not sure why Double Fine decided on an extremely risky business model.It's worth noting that I haven't been able to play for more than about an hour without some kind of show-stopping bug as of the patch before they call the game complete. The AI is dreadful and has a habit of doing the worst thing possible, like suffocating when there's a working airlock and oxygen generators. It's not very likely that all of the issues will be tidied up in the month or so they had left on development.It's a genuinely great idea and with another year or so of dev time I could really see it shaping up to be worth the money. For now it's not worth the money, and likely won't be once it leaves early access.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2016
												Dissapointing....  Back when the game was in early development I fell victim to its "appeal".  I saw a game with potential and I was all and all hopeful.  In those ealier days the game was riddled with bugs and glitches, and when I found out they were dropping the game and rushing development, I was hopeful they would eliminate those bugs and glitches in the game.  So as a review of the official release of version 1.06 here is the breakdown.  I'll have a simple review and more in depth... or in this game... anger driven review...----- Simple ----The game is crap... It had so much potential but since it got the axe and a speedy release... it has so many issues.  I honestly tried to play the game again... but yet I wasn't able to play longer than 10 minues.  I would not recommend this game to anybody unless it's less than a dollar or given to you free.  It's buggy... rough to control, and just honestly crap.----- Angered Version -----Graphics:As this is not a "Highly graphical" game I wouls say they are acceptable.  The sprites perform actions that is befiting, and nothing to standoutish.  However in aspect of gameplay the "isometric" angle makes the game difficult to know exactly what is going on.  In the typical fashion the walls disappear in a way to allow you to see in the rooms, however being able to roatate the camera would be nice.Gameplay:This is where the game loses me.  Although the controls aren't "hard" they are difficult in there own way.  I've played many builder games, and most games play similarily with minor adjustments to the controls.  In more recent terms since the era of shooter games almost every game depends upon the W-A-S-D model.  This game doesn't stray too far fram that idea and it feels comfortable... at least until you start building.  At that point the game takes a turn for the worst.  Edge scrolling doesn't feel like it's in existence, so your dependant upon the WASD model, but once you open the construction menu, foul language fills the mouth as when you click with your mouse to select the item and press "D" to move your contruction item changes.  As soon as that construction menu comes up the game shifts from a comfortable WASD model to a point and click model.  This wouldn't be a problem if they didn't establish you could use the WASD in the first place....   So that is annoying.  Then it gets worse.  As you play you decide to speed up the game, and most games using some button near the WASD (tab, 123, something) changes the game speed, but in comes the mouse model, and you have to click the speed options.  Now I wouldn't have an issue with this, if it wasn't for the fact that when any ship arrived or any notification appears the game switches back to speed 1.... and DOES NOT RETURN.....I find it quite annoying because I'll be in the middle of waiting for my characters to build a room... then all the sudden a message... then the question, "Why are my guys moving so slow"... then oh gotta click that speed... then the game goes NOPE... and another message.  It just continually pesteres you until you get so angry that you give up.AI:I don't normally judge AI as it's always an issue with all games.  It is always about finding that right balance between what the computer needs to process and what the character prioritizes.... unfortunately it appears that this game said, "F*$k it... have the guys do whatever."  And like loyal programs they do whatever.  You have absolutely no control over the individual character, so when your trying to finish that bed... your have to wait until the game decides... "know what I think I should build that bed."  But at that point your characters are now falling over because they are so tired... that they have no energy... then get depressed and not want to work... so now that bed will never get done.... it annoying the bleeping crap out of me as I was just trying to enjoy the game.Glitches and Bugs:Yes I'm bringing it up... as a "fully" released game you would expect most of the bugs and glitches to be taken care of... in fact thats what most of the follow up forums established... but know what.... turns out that your characters get stuck (dumb AI) and because you can't do that they sufficate.... yeah... so just started finished the basic build... airlock... air... and such... but oh no... two of my guys just sat there... doing... NOTHING... could it be AI? probably... but to me that's a bug.   But it's not the worst oh no... in my honest to goodness no opinion try I got "invaded" another ship attached itself to me, and I was assulted.  After killing the AI I noticed, Hey there is a gun outside...  Then I slowly watched one of my security guards go out to take care of it.... two shots later dead.... ok..... so what does the AI do?  "Well he's dead... probably should take care of that... but naa...."  Guess where my miners had to go to get resources?  Right in the line of fire.... so there goes two of my miners...  Well maybe I can control a security... oh wait can't control the guys so whoops... maybe set a security point for them.... nope... dead... dead and dead.....  I'm happy they incorperated the guns for defences... but when a gun is established as enemy and even if you took over everything it appears that that guns still acts hostile....  My frustrations knows no bounds.Overall the game is fine.... just fine.... not great... not good... just fine.... if you want something new to distract you for 10 minutes... here is the perfect game for you... but don't buy unless it's on uber sale.... and by uber sale like... I dunno $0.99 per copy... or heck maybe if the company pays you to play... becuase honestly this game isn't worth anything more.

 This game is a scam. Do not touch this game. It has been rushed to "completion" after the developer failed to deliver promised monthly updates and supposedly ran out of cash. They returned their original investor's cash mind you, but they banked on using gamer's (Early Access) cash to subsidize the development, greatly overestimating the monthly sales for an unfinished piece of garbage. Maybe if they had kept up with updates it would have sold better, that seems to have been key in most other successful Early Access titles.The greatness of the game's concept (found at http://web.archive.org/web/20131018054131/http://spacebasedf9.com/devplans) pales in comparison to the terrible nature in which this games development and budgeting was handled. Avoid at  all  costs, developers should receive no incentive to pull these types of moves on fans and consumers.This game is unfinished, awful, and I'm ashamed to have supported it in any way. The pride with which they present this abysmal product that cashed in on their own fan equity completely turns my stomach. "We’ve learned a lot and are proud of what we managed to accomplish, and it’s all thanks to your support." Double Fine, I think a lot of your fans can also say they learned something during this escapade and I doubt you'll like what effect that's going to have on future support for any titles bearing your now tainted brand.TL;DR / What should I play instead? - Don't buy this unless coerced through physical violence. Instead, try Prison Architect or actually try out  Dwarf Fortress. [www.bay12games.com]

content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
												This is a post-release review.  Previously I had recommended it while it was in early Alpha.  In early Alpha, I did recommend it because it showed great promise and looked like it was going to be improved greatly as development continued.  As it was Double Fine - I had high hopes.  Admittedly, I probably shouldn't have gotten my hopes up for any game that is early access.  I highly encourage you to buyer beware for any early access games you may wish to fund in the future.A note on the current status of Spacebase DF-9: It is considered, by the developers, to be complete enough for a full release.  Currently they're bug squashing and finishing some other small details on their development list.  That's it.  They're done after that.  There will be no future development done to this game for the foreseeable future, according to the developers.  They may not get back to it for at least 2 years, at minimum.  Buyer beware.On to the review:I have only played it for about 2 hours since it's official release.  While it still retains the charm and brutal difficulty as most games of this genre (ala Dwarf Fortress), there hasn't been that much added since the last builds of the early access Alpha.  The graphics are passable, the sounds are passable, the text and artwork definitely has the Double Fine touch that many love and enjoy.  The actual game play and game design is a hollow shell, crying for more.  Should you survive for at least an hour to hour and a half, you will have built everything that is needed.  The rest of the game is simply adding more space for more crew members, taking care of their needs, fighting off the occasional raider/parasite, researching the lack-luster tech tree, and preparing for the “end game” fight with the raider mega-fleet (which also completes the game; I believe).  I'm unsure if the raider mega-fleet actually ends the game or just scores you as I simply got too bored waiting for the mega-fleet to show up.  I built everything I wanted, I raided derelicts for tasty materials, and I threw the troublemakers in my station in a brig or two.  Not to mention dealt with some of my own bugs that are still hanging around since the Alpha builds.Amongst some of the issues with the game: No varied save slots for more than one base at a time, vague tutorial, unrealized or fully implemented concepts, inability to clean up blood stains (at least no way I have found out), questionable fairness (random spikes in difficulty or events that have no lead up; bad things just happen and they're absolutely devastating), and AI having no way to prioritize important tasks (so they just stand around building the room while they suffocate instead of building the single oxygen recycler they need to survive).Elaborating on the unrealized/fully implemented concepts: There are a great deal of the beginnings of production chains, rooms, etc. - But they're just lacking.  All those things you would normally build in other games to fully flesh-out a production chain just aren't there.  You just build a room and get the end product immediately.  For example, instead of building a whole bunch of different machines and making an actual factory that takes raw ore, crushes it, purifies it, refines it, and then makes it into usable construction components – You just get a single shot “matter” resource that you use for everything.  The developers didn't want the game to be too bogged down in these systems, but you never need more than one type of room with their setup.  There's not enough décor for the rest of your base, so you're just stuck with single blocked out rooms at a minimum size to hold just what you want and that's it.  It just leads to boring designs and an uninteresting base to look at.  It's visually boring.If you're dying for another Dwarf Fortress game, set in space – I highly recommend checking out Rimworld or even looking into Gnomoria for your Dwarf Fortress needs.  Let this derelict game drift away.

number of helpful: 24 of 27 people (89%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
												Could have been a great game, but was abandoned by the developers. This is not hyperbole or butthurt exaggeration, the developers saw their sales for the game slow down and just threw their hands up, declaring the game completed. Do not buy it. This is one of the games that caused me to abandon purchasing any more Early Access games on Steam (thank you Doublefine -- I hope you're satisfied with the reputation you're purchasing for yourselves. The free "I'm sorry" shovelware game you gave us early access supporters sucks too, by the way). Do not buy this game.Awesome graphics and sound are ruined by the crippled AI -- your citizens will literally charge past a fire extinguisher hanging on a wall to stomp on a huge room-sized fire to promptly catch on fire and burn to death. Technicians will do pushups in front of a failing oxygen scrubber, then their air will run out and they'll panic and die. Everyone on your station is mind numbingly stupid, but there's no way to directly control them -- you'll just watch them helplessly as their lack of regard for their own safety causes them to die in a variety of ridiculously preventable ways. At first it's funny, for a short time. Then it's annoying. Then it's frustrating. Then it becomes infuriating.Do not buy this game. I'm somewhat convinced that it is not actually a game, but an elaborate psychological experiment to determine frustration thresholds. Do not buy it.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												I'm going to focus on the AI aspect here. In the beginning, there was Early Access. In its Alpha build, DF9 AI was rudamentary. It made bad, often comically bad decisions, and it was like watching a child grow and interact with a world we knew it would adapt to. Like parents, we told our friends the marginally interesting tales of how the children stopped to chit-chat about Moonbeef and whatever while oxygen recyclers caught fire and firefights happened around them. And it was funny because we assumed that it would improve with time, development, and attention.Then DF noticed. They thought this is where the charm of the game came from, and they pulled the plug. Our AI children stopped growing, and were now going to stay stupid. "You enjoyed the stupid AI", they say, "and now that's where we decided to leave it." We enjoyed the AI because it was temporary and had some amusing quirks in its broken state. Being forced to deal with the game in the shape that it's in is not fun. Building a base for inhabitants who don't know how to live in it is not a sim, it's an exercise in futility.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								You too Double Fine? An Early Access game falls short again but this time it is a pretty well known developer that decides to under deliver.  DF stated that it simply wasn't making enough money to warrant continued development and from a gamer's perspective, there's not much of a game to warrant purchasing, especially at the $25 price range. What we have here is a stalemate in which both parties lose. Gamer's lose money and the developer loses face.As it stands, Spacebase DF-9 does let you create a base and manage some resources, it does have some random events to throw at a player so that the game isn't completely boring however, there are no end game type things to work towards, no objectives to ultimately strive towards.  In five hours, a player can pretty much run into everything the game offers and after that, the game will just keep repeating itself.The lack of gameplay issue is compounded by the fact that the beta phase of game testing is being skipped over entirely.  DF is going to tack on a tutorial, wrap up some issues and then release the code in hopes that modders will run with their..un-game and make it better.What was supposed to be a game that was to be in continuous development over the next five years with gameplay tweaks and additions is now kicked out the door in its current shape. I guess in space, no one can hear you break promises.

												*I recommend this game only if it goes on sale or gets a serious update*As of right now I've put about 30+ hours into the game. (Offline play, that's why the hours don't match up.)I purchased this game very early on at a reduced price around $10 or so and at that time it seemed tottally worth it. What was promised seemed awesome and backed by a developer I actually liked how could it go wrong? Well it sorta did and didn't. The game had serious bugs like:Being wiped out within 1-10 minutes by a parasiteBeing wiped out within 1-10 minutes by raidersSave files being deletedGame crashingOverall difficultyPoor performanceNo direction/Story/LoreNo basic tutorial (now in game)Promised missing core featuresNo really settingsWhile I won't get into specifics a simple google search can easily confirm every one of these points. While some of the perforamce issues have been fixed, gameplay "bugs" still remain. It is incredibly frustrating to spend hours building a large base when within seconds, Because of derpy AI or crazy strong raiders/parasites/space debri, everything you built is gone with no real feeling of acomplishment and a feeling of being cheated by the game. Right now $20 is a crazy high price to sell this game at, especially when starting a new game could last a handfull of minutes to several hours after being cheated and killed. I really hope this game gets some serious gameplay options and core function updates soon. When the game changes significantly I'll update this review to hopefully something more positive.But seriously Double Fine? $20?!

number of helpful: 17 of 17 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												Full Review:Big discussions arose about the Early Access programm and kickstarted games. Leaving that aside I wanna focus purely on the game, that I got bundled in a Humble Bundle when it was still Alpha and played several times until its current version.The premise and style of the game seemed enticing to me: Build and manage a space station with room for crew and their needs. I like space and sci-fi settings, plus the whole base-management had a Theme Hospital-like feel to it, which was also a great and creative game.So I started out in space and began building. The game doesn’t offer a campaign, you basically free-build and manage your base from scratch. After a few basic rooms for living quarters, refining asteroids and oxygen supply your base begins to take shape. An intercom window pops up: other space drifters saw my station and want to join my effort. Randomized events like this keep things interesting and challenging. Not all encounters are friendly and you need to be ready for intruders - or pay the costs.The building and managing is fun and keeps me entertained: There are some fun ideas in Spacebase DF-9 that I really like. Your base-dwellers for example post about their wants and needs in their social media “Spaceface”, where you can read how they feel and if they are happy with their occupation. The rooms and objects have good ideas that tie into each other: Plants can not only produce food but also oxygen. The food you produce can be brought into the pub for cooking. When fire breaks out you can not only use fire extinguishers but you can also cut off the oxygen supply to a room - though this usually takes longer and damages your equipment.All these ideas and concept sound fun - on paper. In the game however they can get buggy and very frustrating. The power management for example can get very messy as the only data I have is a bunch of colorful lines across your base. I don’t see how much reach a generator has and how much power is being drawn. New derelicts appear out of nowhere that are so close to my base that my building plans are screwed. And several times my crewmembers kill themselves by simply staying in space until their oxygen runs out or not fleeing a empty vessel that runs out of oxygen. This is very frustrating and something that doesn’t feel like its the players fault. The build-queue is also not very clear as my crew builds rooms but just doesn’t make time to build the door that would connect them - ordering them useless.All in all Spacebase DF-9 is a game that had great promise but will never live up to it because bugs ruin the experience. I tried, I spent the time to build a big base and train my crew to fight back an alien invasion - but when the same men later just suffocate by standing in an room without oxygen, I just feel like its not my fault, its the games. And I don’t want to play it any more.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												I quite loved the potential for this game, but in practise it is horribly disapponting!My first playthrough went fine, pretty basic management fare but then a raider showed up and I discovered that the 'security' crew assignments I'd made meant people couldn't last two seconds against the lone raider..Alright then, it was the first go and in tutorial so I can accept an hours play lost and decided to start a new game.First realisation, there was no "this will erase your data" or "do you want to save" warning. Surprising and not great, but as said, I hadn't planned to anyway so I went ahead with a new real start.My hopes for the game returned, I enjoyed starting anew and building up the base and this time I had a plan for raiders!My plan... reassign every crewmen to security and overwhelm in numbers! XDNot great I know.. but it worked, though highly tiresome to have to remember and reassign everyone back to their old jobs as you can't assign saved positions to default back to.Then of course, things went bad again...I find a derelict ship, so badly laid out it could've been a rushed post-battle vessel from Galaxy Truckers.So of course, I decide to tear everything out as salvage materials.Unknown to me, one crew decided to remove the ships oxegen generator and then the door of another room from the inside.. leaving him stuck and likely gormless, as there was no notification of him being stuck.I'll admit a possibly mistake on my part: Not painstakingly watching and assigning each item removed one at a time, but when I tried that previously the crew had a habit of just heading off to bed or returning to my base for a minute to build some shelves I'd requested another builder to build, before coming back.. which is why this time I just left them to it.Anyway, I found Mr.Gormless and got him to let himself out of the room but before he got any further the oxegen in the ship got too low and it turns out people panic when they realise the oxegen is low (fair enough I'm sure).Unfortunately, this panic was apparently too much to allow the builder to obey my orders to rebuild an oxegen generator.Close to frustration I see my second builder heading over in a space suit to save the day..Unfortunately, Gormlessness is clearly contagious as our superhero stepped out of the airlock, went into a panic himself, rushed back into the airlock and flushed himself into space...So yea, there you have it. My adventures in Spacebase DF-9. I advise you against having any of your own.

I personally feel like the latest updates have ripped idea's directly from Rimworld as well. Nevertheless, it may be one to watch, as there are plenty of interesting ways the game could go. As it stands, it's not worth buying right now, you will get perhaps 1-2 hours of content, and even that is very basic.

												This game had huge potential until Double Fine cut it loose and ran off with the money from the early access. It was a decent start to what could've been a great game, but the devs decided to run off with the money and leave us with a half finished pile of garbage. They keep releasing "patches" that barely fix any of the problems, lied about all of the insanely cool sounding features that were supposed to be added, and then have the gall to charge $20 for a game that's got about $5 worth of content in it.This game could've been another colossal hit for DF, but instead it turned into a colossal mess. Don't buy it. Pirate a copy if you have to play it, but don't bother buying it. DF doesn't deserve another cent for this train wreck.

number of helpful: 15 of 15 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												For shame, Double Fine. After Psychonauts I was thrilled to see this release. But after your decision to take your money and tell us all 'Oh-well, so sad'... That was some truly cutthroat business. Sadly, your managers will probably go on to make similar decisions, but it's your name they dragged through the mud, and I will never purchase another Double Fine title.The game had promise, but the bugs make it practically unplayable. There's no real way to stop rampaging citizens, as the jail system doesnt seem to do anything about their attitudes. Wounded people will lie around on the ground because the Medics cant be directed to go to them and will instead carry on about their daily lives, meanwhile everyone takes a morale hit. Would have been fun, but as you can see from the nosedive in reputation the game has taken, "would have been" doesnt sell games.

number of helpful: 15 of 15 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												This game is fun, I really enjoy it. This game also has a large amount of game-breaking bugs, which are not fun and will kill everyone in your base. Sadly now that it is officially released these will probably not be fixed.Things to enjoy: SPAAAAAAAACE. Also base building, planning, and generally keeping everybody happy, fed, and safe.Things to hate: Terrible AI. This includes having all your technicians/Miners/Scientists/etc go to a raider ship to pick up an item they want... and then being killed by raiders. It's like watching lemmings. Speaking of raiders, they have a tendency to outmatch even the toughest of 5v1 battles with your security forces. Other things to look out for are Builders bothering to install some more flooring, taking a break, and then suffocating to death because they forgot to build some air recyclers before taking said break.What this game needs: Able to queue up actions, or prioritize building. Being able to tell your citizens to STAY AWAY from scary people in scary spaceships. Or fires. Or vacuums. Theres a lot of room for both necessary, and quality of life AI improvements. Theres a lot of work put into this game, and I happen to think it's fun, but it is clearly not finished yet.

Early Access Review
								Perhaps, half a prototype.I'm not upset that I spent the money on this, and I feel I payed for an adequate amount for playing what content there was to play--but I wouldn't recommend the game with the content that is going to be called a 1.0 release. Putting aside what was promised that didn't make it into the game, what's currently there will only get you a few hours in, before you're wondering what there is left to do.It has a few clever ideas in there, and there is a very lovely amount of polish to the product--which is why it seems like such a waste.I wish DoubleFine the best of luck for their other projects.

number of helpful: 14 of 14 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												This game had a lot of promise and I bought this game elsewhere cheaper with the thought and impression that as a early-access game that this game would become finished at a later date. Despite its enjoyment and yes it does have a few hours worth of game play but after 10 hours you will have played through everything and have done everything possible within this game. I will still from time to time come onto this game to pass the time and play on it for a few hours but despite having it as an early access game they decided that they would cease production of the game and keep it out on Steam and ask for a high price despite it hardly being finished. To make it look more appealing they dropped the game by a few bucks but in all honesty this game is worth about £4.00/$6.00 max if that!. This review is aimed at informing you all that this game is no where near finished, has many bugs to it and won't get finished as the developers ceased production and said "we will leave it to the modding community". Was a huge disappointment for me as this had so much potential and after the first two weeks that i got this game and played it a lot they announce on Steam that they are ceasing production of this game. 4/10. Unfinished, infested with bugs and not worth its current price by far. Either lower it significantly or remove it from the Steam store. I would like compensation for the disappointment that this game has caused, especially when it could have been an amazing game!.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												Unfinished, abandoned game. Devs did a quick cash grab by putting the game on sale a week before announcing they would stop production and release the game as was. Which was an alpha 6 stage. They went from alpha to release and never even patched it again. They actually expected the game to be fully funded on Early Access alone and tried to treat it like a normal release. Meaning they had an overhead of thousands of dollars. A completely unrealistic way of making and funding a game, by a developer that really does not care about their customers.I will NEVER buy Double Fine games again. They are the lowest of the low when it comes to money hungry developers.Update: Turns out I eventually did buy another DF game: Massive Chalice. DF seems to have learned from their past indiscretions and I am not someone to pass up a good game just because reasons. They also patched Iron Brigade as soon as they regained control from Microsoft who was apparently hogging the game. DF is making some steps that are actually restoring my faith in the company, a bit. It's something.This is not to say you should ever buy Spacebace|DF9 because this one is beyond repair. ;)

number of helpful: 14 of 14 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												To me, somewhat enjoyable I play it from time to time when I am extremely bored. However there are lots of fustrating issues with it. Prioritization of work is non-existant (ex. running out of air, so I put plans on building more air recyclers, but builders instead were chatting, eating, and sleeping and did not get to it for a LONG time). Combat/action pretty boring and worthless, takes security like 10 shots (mostly missing) to kill a raider. Bugs everywhere. Base location unbalanced (basically, some locations have lots of matter to harvest, or barely anything. Nonstop citizen ships/raiders practically everywhere. Just a few examples). AI pretty pathetic. Basically, a lot more Cons than Pros. I wish that the devs would improve on these issues to make a more enjoyable and exciting game, but it seems that they washed their hands on this product. This could be an amazing game if they get updating and fixing it.

number of helpful: 19 of 23 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												This game has cute points, but overall it is too shallow to be worth the price. Some examples: You mine "Matter" which you use to build stuff. There are no different types or ores, or complex manufacturing steps. You have two basic paths to feed your colonists: Matter replicators to start with, or a mini-production chain with botanists growing plants which are served by bartenders. A simplistic research chain. There are several types of rooms, but each has just a few types of furnishings. The whole thing is just --- I guess superficial is the word I am looking for.I started playing during Alpha-3, and through it had a promising beginning. Unfortunately, what I thought was a concept outline which would have a lot more stuff added to it turned out to be it. Space-sim lite. Not an awful game, but no where near worth the asking price.

number of helpful: 15 of 16 people (94%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								Here's a game that had great potential. Then, after alpha 6, the developers suddenly decided to skip beta, fix the remaining bugs and call it 1.0 and let imaginary coders from the community finish the game by releasing the source code. They'll still take your money, though, thankyouverymuch.In its current state, the game is bug-ridden, which is understandable since it is (was) still in development, and you'll be lucky if you can play for more than a couple of hours before you encounter a game-breaking bug.When/if said bugs get fixed in "1.0", you'll get a bug free empty shell of what could have been a great simulation game. It'll be fun for a while and then you'll realize most of the advertised content and features have never been implemented.There are probably some valid reasons why Double Fine chose to abandon this game, but in the end, it also means that they chose to let down everyone who chipped in to help funding its development. Not a very nice thing to do.TLDR: Don't waste your money, there are many good simulation games out there that have actually been finished.

number of helpful: 18 of 22 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
Almost like it was designed to be pay to play... but they forgot to add anything to pay for to make it fun.Although this has promise and I got it free I would not recommend it at all.It's as though nobody on the dev team st Double Fine actually played this game for more than 30mins. After the first few minutes it just becomes frustrating and annoying. Examples: - 7 botanists, all in one small Garden zone totally ignoring two other large zones. Game tells me I need more botanists. - 15 technicians (meant to repair stuff), EVERYTHING is sparking blowing up and not getting fully repaired. The only way to fix this is the reclaim the damaged equipment and build it again. This is totally STUPID. Game tells me I need more Technicians. - Sometimes people flip out which is fine, but assigning security to them, trying to cuff them, nothing works. They will destroy half your base, kill as many crew as they can and then eventually hopefully be subdued but some passing person as your whole security team run around them doing nothing. - Invincible aliens that wipe out your crew, eventually your security team turn up one by one and get killed off. Restart game. - Space debris damages a reactor and take out the power, nobody repairs it, builders take ages to get to it to reclaim it, will not build a new one as they are freaking out about oxygen. Restart game. - 7 member security team wiped out down to the last man by raiders. All 5 stars. - More raiders straight away. Restart game. - Give the hell up and go back to a decent game.Play this if you want a lesson in total frustration and how to never "finish" a game.

content:

												I purchased during the very early days after it was released on Steam and I did truly enjoy the game back then even with its terrible game breaking bugs. Every update added new features that made it both easier to play and easier to get everyone on your entire base dead within minutes.  I still see a single raider take out 5 of my level 3+ security staff and also win several matches of fisticuffs with civvies... what the F..? Also, the AI is strange... SO stange! And possibly sociopathic... with not so subtle rage issues... and a long line of family mental health problems... Someone will freak over something, probably quickly, and go around smashing half of the base until someone else smashes them in the face enough times that they pass out.  If your unlucky, which you usually are, they will have trashed your oxygen recyclers and no one will repair them before the levels get low enough that everyone runs around like chickens with their heads cut off until they asphyxiate instead of solving the issue like a boss.  Sorry, that got dark.Unfortunately in its broken, unfinished, never to be finished state I cannot recommend this game.  If it goes on sale for $1 or something similar depending on your region it may be nice to pick up to see how good the game could have been eventually, when it was properly finished, but that is just about it.

number of helpful: 14 of 16 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2015
												Game is incomplete and devs ditched it. They wanted to do the Minecraft-style development where they keep improving the game and people keep buying it as they add more and more, but they had a barely-functioning skeleton of the game, not enough people bought it to justify them continuing, so they shut it down. That's just pathetic behaviour. Small indie studios get crucified for that kind of thing, let alone a bigger established studio like DoubleFine. As a bonus they put it on a big steam sale a week before announcing the end of development, just so new buyers felt extra shafted. They tried to buy some goodwill back by giving purchasers a free copy of Hack n Slash, as well as by putting out tools for modders and asking the community to finish the game for them(!), but buyer beware. This game was halted a brief way into development and never even remotely came close to being a releasable product. If Broken Age's double-kickstarter shenanigans weren't enough, this is proof that DF cannot be trusted with early access. Just stay well away.

number of helpful: 14 of 16 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												Before I start. Isn't it a bit disgusting that Double Fine is the curator for their own project? Anyway it's a bare bones Space Building game in the vane of Dungeon Keeper, Theme Hospital and Startopia. You build stuff and people rather stupidly suffocate in Space because you can't give people a slight nudge in the right direction to avoid their terrible deaths. The AI is very stupid, and the Building is a very bare. Worse yet is how much DF are asking for, while it's not quite the price of a AAA title, it's by no means cheap either which is yet again is another reason to be critical because what you're buying doesn't add up to £20/$30 worth of content. And to add salt to a fatal wound? DF have decided to just straight up ignore Beta stage and release the game into 1.0, that's right a full version from Alpha where there's been a startling lack of updates throughout it's year of development. Poor show.After the jump into V1.0, my impressions are still disappointing. The game is not fun to play, the citizens now know how to not suffocate stupidly but their prioties are extremely messed up. The UI is counter intuitive and really clumsy and hideous as a result, the game is unimpressive visually and you'll find that the game doesn't do enough to hold your attention. This is further signs that money should not be given to DoubleFine, a company who do not deliver on their promises.

number of helpful: 13 of 15 people (87%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is kind of like Dwarf Fortress in space, a little simulator where you design rooms and manage the roster for your space station.  You don't control the citizens directly, but instead you put down work orders, and the citizens will handle it on their own.  You sketch out rooms and order furniture and so on and your citizens place it.The first few mintues of the game were a lot of fun for me.  You're kicked out of your life support pod drifting in deep space and have to build a little self sustaining environment with an airlock and some life support systems before your citizens run out of air (about 5 mins).  This was an encouraging first glance for me, because it's pretty hard and will probably require a few resets if you don't know what you're doing, and the systems seemed interesting and complex.  Eventually, though, I figured it out and started branching out, putting up a refinery to allow my miners to mine nearby asteroids, using the materials to build a residence and a bar and a garden and a lab and stock it with furniture.And then the game ended.I don't mean it dumped me to a "game over" screen or anything, there just wasn't anything left to do.  Once you've got a half dozen rooms down and functioning, which takes maybe an hour, there's nothing else you can do except wait for your science team to sloooooowly research some unnesescary upgrades, or maybe have your security team scrap with some raiders (note that this isn't an RTS, combat in this game is just a matter of setting a point for your security team to defend and maybe they will if they're not on break or hungry or tired or sad).  Sometimes a derelict will show up and you can... well, tear it down, nothing else to do with them really.If you've ever played Dwarf Fortress, basically imagine that game but with no workshops.  You can make rooms and designate areas and place furniture, but there's no crafting system, no economy, no trade, resources are all boiled down to a single currency which is used to buy everything from walls to furniture.  The game just has no depth at all, and it's competing with some of the most complex and deepest simulations on the market right now.The devs seem to have responded to this by ramping up the challenge, which makes things a bit frustrating.  Colonies can die from parasites before you get a doctor, waves of raiders can annihilate an underequipped security force, and once things start to fail, it's pretty much a chain reaction to an abandoned base.  Colonists freak out and refuse to do their jobs so vital equipment isn't maintained or repaired so colonists freak out even harder and things just spiral downward.  For example, if the air supply gets low, colonists will freak out rather than do their jobs, so if the area with the life support systems has air problems, you can't ever fix it because whoever goes in there is going to panic instead of fixing the air generator, and the problems get worse.  And this doesn't really do much to fix the problem with the game being short, because once you've got whatever it is you need to counter them, then they're not that big a deal.  The 1.0 update added a lot of nice features, but the game still has serious issues with longevity.  There are still occasional glitches with draw order and some AI issues, but the game works pretty well mostly.  I've only played a bit, but pathing does seem improved and the interface does make things clearer now.I don't want to sound excessively negative, this isn't the worst game ever.  I had a lot of fun with it.  It's just really short, and the asking price is kind of high.  On sale, for $5, I'd say this is a good deal.  At full price, I don't think it's worth it.  I'd recommend looking at something like Startopia or Space Colony or grabbing something like Gnomoria or Dwarf Fortress if you're not in love with the sci-fi aesthetic.  All of these games are cheaper, deeper, and more fun in the long term than DF-9.

number of helpful: 13 of 15 people (87%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
												Here, I made an analogy of this whole situation for you:What they've basically done is told people about a wonderful mansion they were planning on building for everybody; it would have a waterfall, and monkey butlers, and regular butlers too. If you want to get in on this; drop us some money! You can watch the work come along!Except, it turns out, they basically have about two walls, and maybe a bit of tarp stretched over a corner or something. Not exactly inspiring stuff; so uh, they're having trouble getting any more people interested in it. Time to cut it there, they figured, we've made some money on this; let's wrap this up before we invest any more money into it. It turns out they were only planning on building a mansion. Planning! Obviously what we meant by that and what you thought were different things. Our apologies.But no worries! You have full use of the two walls and tarp. We never got around to adding plumbing, though, or electricity. Also, there's this hobo who keeps trying to shiv people. Finally, uh, the site is contaminated by deadly radon gas, (interesting, because there isn't even a basement) and some of you may have progressive pulmonary fibrosis.We'll leave a few nails and boards around, if someone wants to improve on things, though. Also, the president of the company is just as bummed about this as you guys are, except not really, because he's got a bit more money out of this deal!Bottom line: This company has made some good games in the past, but not recently. Early access might work with small studios, but when you've got 60 plus people to support, it doesn't seem as financially viable... Especially when you repay the investors with the early access sales, before the game's even released!I accept this risk for early access games, but this is the first time I came across a situation quite like this one. I was treating DF by the reputation they had built long ago, not by what they are now. Double Fine? More like Doesn't Finish! or, uh, Don't Fund, or whatever. Boo this company! Boooo!

content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												This game is probably the most notorious vaporware game in Steam history. The developers at Doublefine were on a roll with a great game, and out of nowhere cancelled the project without finishing the game due to funding issues. Not to mention they didn't even open up Steam workshop support so Steam users could finish it for them. The worst part is that it was a fun game a couple versions before Doublefine abandoned the project. However, when they abandoned the project they released a final patch that sends swarms of raiders to attack your base so frequently you can't build, and your citizens are constantly sad or angry. It's unplayable now because you can't send your citizens outside your base to build,mine,explore,etc without them being killed. And I'll point out that this is in the Extremely Low threat areas of the galaxy map. To me this seems like a final insult to all of the people who paid good money for what was a good game. I for one will never purchase anything from Doublefine again, and I can't see how this could fix their "funding" issues because the PR nightmare of this game has killed their reputation. My recommendation to Doublefine is to reopen this project and satisfy their customers, as it's the only way they will save their company. My recommendation to anyone thinking of purchasing this game in it's current state, is don't!

number of helpful: 12 of 14 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
Spacebase DF-9 is a casual building sim-tycoon game. You are put in charge of a few colonists to build, maintain and protect your own space station.Pros: The game is easy to pick up on: you start with a power source, minerals and a handful of colonists whose first priority is to build a modest space station with oxygen supplies, and expand to a small variety of room types while mining and refining minerals. As your crew grows and time passes, additional needs will surface, needs that you must address or risk your crew to lose its temper. Derelict ships and additional travelers will want to join, some whether you like it or not, and you must deal with meteor showers, raiders and other threats, all the while researching better equipment.Cons: There is a severe lack of variety in every way: Only a couple of room types with very little content or options, while general furniture offers a scarce selection. Travelers will often discard your rejection, and you quickly become over-populated. You barely have any control over crew morale. The game become repetitive as you are constantly facing the same issues: need more resource or oxygen/power, raiders come over to kill some of your crew, crew member goes berserk, rinse & repeat. Even tech research is rather limited.Verdict: ★★☆☆☆ - Forget itSpacebase DF-9 drops the ball. While not a bad game, it had the potential of being the next Space Colony, but doesn't come even close. Games of this genre require variety to make it interesting to build and grow, and this game doesn't have what it takes to give it the replay value it would need.P.S.: I do not recommend this game as it is offered on Steam. There is, however, a dedicated team of developers at http://spacebasehub.net who have taken it upon themselves to enhance the game and its content. There is still a long way to go, but should the game's potential actually come to fruition, my opinion of the game could change.—————————————————————————This was just my opinion.If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated) reviews.

Posted: August 4, 2016
												Ignore the part of this game being unfinished and abandoned, despite that it was fun.Now, there is a game breaking bug, where airlocks are awful. Sometimes, when a person steps near an airlock then can break it essentially and whoever was trying to get in will slowly die to asphyxiation, THEN you have lazy builders not finishing the airlock so you'll die before you even got started. I restarted five times, and nothing, nothing works.I don't know what they did, but after the last 'major' update they broke the game, when I tried using my old base, everything was broken, my reactors, my production, everything.This was my first base builder game and I loved it, then, double fine did something wrong and broke it, I don't know what they did, but they broke it.This game needs a way to revert back to an older version so I can play this again, the only thing you got out of this game if you got it early on was a free crappy game to go with your payed game that was broken.Don't let this discourage you from buying other doublefine games. This one in particular however, was something good, before they broke it.

number of helpful: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12
												Okay, I got this in a Humble Bundle or bundled Steam sale or something. Gave it a try last night.It's not that it's a bad game. It's that it's... disappointing. There are clever mechanics and clever concepts going on, art I found charming, but it's clear that it's just unfinished. I don't know the whole history with this game. I see other reviews talking about a Kickstarter and broken promises from Double Fine. I don't know about all that. What I can tell you is that this game has SO MUCH potential but never lives up to it. So many little things about this game hint at a larger story, at a more in-depth gameplay, at a game that could be but isn't. If someone could take the concepts of this game, with a living crew to manage and a procedural storytelling system and an expansive sandboxy space construction system, and actually FINISH it, it could easily be one of my favorite games.I want to like this game. I really do. But it's just not finished, and from what I'm reading in other reviews, never will be.Sad I will never get the Star Trek Deep Space Nine simulator that I was hoping for.

number of helpful: 9 of 9 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game was billed as Dwarf Fortress in space. It might have been just that, had it not been developed by Double Fine.Unfortunately, Tim Schafer thinks that Early Access exists to test the waters rather than to operate as a platform for developers without solid capital. They honestly wanted to develop this game for 5 years. 5 years. And Tim says since the game isn't bringing in enough money on early access that they're going to have to push it out as 1.0 with most of the features on the devplan unfinished.So Tim honestly thought that they were going to make profit on an unfinished game for five years. That, ladies and gentlemen, is the CEO of Double Fine. That's the man that couldn't finish a point and click adventure for 3.3 million.I've got some advice for you, Tim. And it comes from Gabe Newell."Do not focus on anyone but your customers. Your reputation will follow you forever so always be fair to your customers, and certainly one thing you need to always remember is that your customers are not going to be fooled. Some people think they can get away with something and just hope people won't see through the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. The internet is way smarter than any of us."You've been exchanging your reputation as a game developer in for cash, and given your recent default on Spacebase DF-9 it is with regret that I must inform you that we, the gaming community and responsible consumers, can no longer extend your line of credit.The next time you want to build a game, like oh, say, Dear Leader, don't come to the community with your hand stuck out and nothing for collateral but promises.I feel bad for the people who worked on this game. Who wanted it to be something more only to have its legs cut out from under it because it wasn't a profitable Early Access game. To be honest, the updates were too far apart. Of course no one was buying it. It took too long to see progress, and your behavior and glibness on Twitter and other formats has been intolerable.Sorry, Tim. You can't ride the success of Psychonauts, Day of the Tentacle, and Full Throttle forever. You could have been one of the greats, but instead you're going to end up like John Romero. Only John only screwed his fanbase over once, while you seem determined to make it the remainder of your career.Do not purchase this game. Do not purchase Dear Leader, an Amnesia Fortnight winner like Spacebase DF-9. Do not buy Costume Quest 2. If Tim Schafer comes onto Kickstarter and is like, "Hey, Psychonauts 2 - I need cash." Do not give him money. Double Fine cannot manage its finances, and has abused a system that was put here to help unestablished developers as a way to decide whether they should bother to finish a game based upon its profitability before launch.

content:

Early Access Review
								When I bought the game I figured I'd love the vast base-building. I'd hoped it would resemble something like Prison Architect, and to an extent; Banished. But it seems more appropriate to say it's like Age Of Empires, as, with limited build time, I'm forced to hapazardly prepare for an attack from raiders, parasites, or one of my own crew. Taking into account this was in the easiest area of the game I could find.After multiple restarts (I've barely played a single playthrough for more than 30 minutes), I gave up. This kind of game could steal hundreds of hours from me, but with the trouble I'm having constructing a fuctioning populace, and a decent-looking spacebase, that's not going to happen.

number of helpful: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11
												I bought this game a few years ago for $30 when it was still in early access. Thirty dollars might as well have been burned. Don't get me wrong, I like this game, and I think it could have been so much more than what it is. In terms of gameplay, it's decent. There's lots of options for zoning, wacky randomly generated names, and a unique art style. But it's obvious that the game's been abandoned by double fine. There hasn't been a major update (or even an update at all, correct me if I'm wrong) in who knows how long. Then there's balance. When I first played this, I was extremely frustrated with the raiding and pirating system. There was really no correlation between base level and defense systems and the difficulty of any enemies. Seriously, you know no effort has been put into balance when you have 2 entirely unrelated raider boarding parties entering your base when you're barely 10 minutes into the game.In terms of replay value, I struggle to find any.In conclusion, I think this game is a bit of a lost cause. It had potential, but it was thwarted by bugs, balance, and lazy devs. It's a shame, really. I recommend taking a look at Prison Architect if you still want a game similar to this, but far more in depth and absolutely worth the price.

number of helpful: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2016
												Lets see, the first time i loaded up the game i decided to run the tutorial. I was greated by roughly 100 frames of intro (please keep in mind these 100 frames were spread over 20 seconds or so). So i turn my graphics setting all the way down, ditch the second monitor and lower my screen resolution as low and the game allows. Well I can now move fairly unhindered. Go through the tutorial up until I have to fight 10 ish enemies. imediately my frames drop to 10 or so. I have a mid range PC that runs pretty much every game i have in at least a playable fashion (IE ARK and Squad), however this unoptomized POS can barely pull 10 frames?F**K it, me and some friends already have bought and installed the POS so lets try it out. After about 15 minutes of loading screens were finally into the game, well 3 out of the 4 of us. So another 10 minutes go by while they restart and load into our game. Alright lets rock n roll! To be fair the gameplay is pretty decent and it definitely is what i was expecting. That being said there's a solid chance your gonna get dropped from the game mid session, or want to play with some weapons that were in the beta but removed from the actual release for umm idk a reason i guess. The game has so many glitches i can't even recall them all. Our favorite of which is when you interface with a door and afterwards cant use any of your buttons besides movement. This can be solved by running(you know without actually running cause the sprint button doesn't work) over to a door and interacting with it again. Some times it seemed to just happen randomly. Once we were running two auto Cannons and both just happen to get glitched for no apparent reason what so ever. Pretty legit.All in all not that bad if you enjoy 5 frames, of unoptomized graphics from the 90's, a second while not being able to use your weapons after spending 15-20 minutes of time in loadings screens. But hey its a 40k game!The emporer protect anyone who buys this.

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												Nice try ... but not finished.Playing sims/strategy/rpg genre quite often my expectations of this game have been too high.It has a nice setup how you interact with your crew, fulfill their demands, but dies under too many random factors. For example, the perfect bartender has as psych attribute "quiet" and "shy". It is not funny and will lead unexperienced player straight to a loss.The "morale" system is very raw. People will get happy when you built many small rooms filled with monitor/plants. That means long hallways and big rooms are game breaking. You will lose every time cause of low morale. A drawback of many small rooms is the micromanagement in case of emergencies. I do love their humor ... A chicken alien beat up a human who was eating because he thought the chicken legs have been from his race/planet.Conclusio ... Play Dwarf Fortress ....  It free but not that fancy and includes all the things Double Fine wanted to realize but didn't finish.

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
This is not Early Access any more, it's more like Early Abandonment.At the Time of WritingGame: Spacebase DF-9Price: $21.99*Genre: building/simulationTime Played: 25 hoursPersonal Enjoyment Rating: ☺☻☻☻☻Links I Found Helpful**A YouTube gameplay look by Whole Brain Gaming. This video gives you a good idea of what the game is actually like to play as the narrator explores it. 


YouTube™ Video: Spacebase DF-9 Playthrough & Thoughts 

			Views: 1,418		

			Nathan takes a look at the final release of Spacebase DF-9. A very controversial title that had been announced an official release. Jumping from Alpha 6 to 1.0 due to funding issues in Double Fine.		

A YouTube discussion by Total Biscuit. His discussion will not only tell you a bit about all the drama surrounding this game, but you’ll also see some of the gameplay. 


YouTube™ Video: Double Fine & Spacebase DF-9 under fire - Sep. 21st, 2014 

			Views: 203,683		

			Bobby Kotick slags off Tim Schafer: http://bit.ly/XTB1kW 1.0 release announcement: http://bit.ly/1rcwvbn Steam announcement: http://bit.ly/1v5X2bk Tim Schafer needs more money for Broken Age:...		

 GeneralFor what little it is now worth, I did enjoy playing the game and exploring the changes in each new Alpha update. This game had a lot of potential and was very exciting. With gorgeous artwork, a decent attempt at UI design, atmospheric music, and an absolutely delightful sense of humour, all of which contributed to an interesting universe of different species and way of life. But the fact remains that this game was abandoned, never finished properly, and at the time of writing can not be considered a complete game.They did go in and include a tutorial for the game, and I was very impressed with the tutorial until it suddenly ended. Although it felt like it ended abruptly and too soon, I can see why they did limit the information provided. If they don’t leave you to figure out the other rooms and the way the spacebase generally functions then you would have played all there is to play of this game in the tutorial. Ultimately the tutorial just seems to highlight the lack of depth to the game.Spacebase has a rocky history so far, and I feel I really must include a discussion of this so that you can make an informed decision. However, as you will see with the format of my reviews, there are plenty of sections which allow me to consider the game for itself regardless of the surrounding drama.In the interests of full disclosure: I was an early access purchaser, and yeah, I did get burned with this game. My experience with Spacebase truly set my mind to never buy an early access game ever again, no matter how wonderful it looks and tempting it seems. Nothing is a sure bet, and I will only be spending my money on finished products from now on. I can accept that I took a risk by purchasing an EA game and that it did not pan out in this case, but the end result is still a bad experience with Spacebase and Double Fine by extension. Things did get very dramatic, but I don’t think the company did a very good job of handling things. I’m not going to go on about it, so suffice it to say that I’m not an admirer of Double Fine any more. If you want more information regarding the drama I refer to, please check out TotalBiscuit’s discussion on the subject.GameplayThis is a base building game. You build a space station from basic building blocks (floors and walls) and zone different rooms. You fill those rooms with things like oxygen tanks, plants, beds, exercise equipment, tables, food, defence turrets, fire extinguishers, science labs, and matter converters. Mine asteroids to refine into matter, the basic building block/currency of the game in order to build everything else.There isn’t exactly a tech tree to this game, and there aren’t any crafting recipes (although there is scientific research). It seems to be more about the simulation of how people interact with one another, but there are so many characters that join your base that it’s impossible to really follow many interactions in a very meaningful way. So I end up concentrating on building the base and trying to see just how big I can make it. Once you get a vast crew though, things start lagging up and the bugs start to get obvious. Ultimately you will find that there is an imposed limit on how big a base you can create and keep running not by design, but because (I'm afraid I must repeat) this game wasn't really completed.I really desperately wish that there was a blueprint function (like in prison architect) so that one could plan their base out before starting construction.ControlsAlthough you can use the mouse to do everything, there are thankfully plenty of hotkeys. Some of them aren’t as intuitive as I might like, but I got used to them over the course of many hours of play. I found the camera controls to be fairly good, with my most appreciated camera functionality being the ability to pan around. It’s also always a plus to have a simple pause/start button to hit, which is good old spacebar.StorylineI can’t say there is much of a storyline. I think the original intention for the game was to immerse yourself in the lives of the different people on the base and sort of imagine your own story. However, there isn’t sufficient depth and breadth to the rest of the game to allow you to direct any sort of imaginary storyline. It was an interesting concept which didn’t really get developed or thought through well enough.SoundI really like the sound in this game. The music is quite atmospheric (appropriate to the universe they created) and interesting to listen to. It may get repetitive after a while, but it is more like it fades into the background of your awareness rather than becoming irritating. Meanwhile, the sound effects are pretty much functional, nothing much to warrant remark.GraphicsThe artwork in this game is really very good. It’s certainly got a specific style to it, however that style is stuck to throughout and that consistency helps to establish a weird and wonderful universe. I really only have good things to say about the graphics, it’s a shame that all this creative work is now trapped in the wrapper of the rest of the game. Alas.Pros+ huge potential, great concept+ easy to read and navigate the UI+ gorgeous artwork+ interesting universeCons- EA = Early Abandonment- an unfinished game- no real end goal- not enough depth to make it a decent sandbox- still rather buggyHelp Me Help YouIf you did not find this review helpful, I would really appreciate your constructive criticism - tell me why it wasn’t helpful for you. It’s my hope to make the reviews that I do take the time to write up, as helpful as they possibly can be.Rothana's Steam Review ArchiveFor those that are interested in seeing more of my reviews, I have set up an archive of them at an external website. I don't earn anything off of this at all, it's just a little side project that I add to when I can. Steam won't let me create a direct link though, so you'll need to make your own way to the URL I describe now: rothana dot weebly dot comFootnotes*Any prices that I mention are in CDN because that is what I see.**I will not be keeping an eye on whether the links are up to date, so if they are broken I apologise. Remember that these are external websites and I'm just trying to be helpful - I'm not responsible for the content on the other end.Edit Log1/03/2015 formatting and additional writing

content:
Posted: April 13, 2016
												Started playing this game, having startopia and other similar games in mind… it could have been a great game but it somehow misses the motivational part. If you enjoy building something next to an angry toddler who destroys all your work randomly… then this mightbe a game for you. I've played it some hours now and found it quite frustrating. Even in the supposedly easier parts of the galaxy you can barely construct a base, at one point the game starts to throws masive waves of raiders - way more than the population of your base - against you. Just after you barely survived a couple of killerbots arrive. This might be something to handle and to enjoy if the games worked as intended. But you only have one "security" beacon (but probably about 6 differend intrusin locations) and if you are lucky the citizens respect the emergency alarms and the security comes to the beacon. one by one. to get slaughtered. But about half of the time they don't do anything when they arrive at the beacon. There are construction bugs and fire extinguishing things as well.After all, it is hard to actually have fun playing this game.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2016
 I want to rate this game well I really do but I simply can't at the moment  I have had it before where I have made a great base and all has ended well and that feels great but its getting to that point that makes me want to scream in frustration. The AI in this game to put it simply is suicidal. In my latest playthrough a raider has calmly floated outside my base and shot my miners. I think wait I put a beacon on him why did my security force do nothing? They got stuck in the airlock. They were in there so long I had to build a second airlock in order to save a small building team I had working outside. On numerous occasions I have had builders who were working on unfinished rooms in space simply take off their space suit and die from a lack of oxygen. Normally in a game like this I think well its an early access game give it the benefit of the doubt it will be fixed it may even turn out to be as good a prison architect  'Double Fine Productions is releasing a final version of Spacebase DF-9 next month, the studio announced last week. The decision brings an end to the studio's plan to continuously expand the game over a few years' Yep the devs at Double Fine abandoned it. The concept seems really cool to me its just so frustrating I can't recommend it

content:
Posted: September 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								Spacebase DF-9 is a fun little rogue-like Dwarf-Fortress-ish game where you build and control a base in space, while fighting off potential invaders. It is a good-looking game filled with potential that is never quite realized and, in the end, it eventually feels very shallow.It's easy to recommend Spacebase as an amusing little distraction, but not as an in-depth game of strategy or exploration. Unfortunately, it is in a price-range that demands far more of it. I can not recommend this game at or anywhere near its full price of $25 USD. There are numerous similar titles out there that are only a few bucks or even completely free that accomplish far more.Pretty, but empty.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								Since the original Early Access, barely any features have been added, and updates were months apart. The game is far from complete (and even further from what was promised), even though DoubleFine seems to think it will be from just adding a tutorial, wrap up the major bugs, and calling it "1.0".DF continues to look highly mismanaged, especially financially. E.g. Broken Age was supposed to work with $400k funding. They got six times that and still they "ran out of money" and had to release what they had as "Act 1" (i.e. "Incomplete game, part 1").This was the last time I trusted DF to make a good game with my money. The only time DF is getting any money from me is if they've actually released the game with all its features, and even then I'll think twice if there's nothing better I can do with my money. Like lighting it on fire. I get more enjoyment out of watching a brief flame than playing this husk of a dream of a game.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2016
Product received for free
												SDF9 is not very amazing at all. In the past I've held Double Fine in somewhat of a high regard, but this game just isn't very good at all, for a multitude of reasons.Namely, it is unfinished. It is abandonware. And yet DF have the gall to keep selling it. On top of this, there are people making mods in order to fix the game. This should not be necessary, and sends red flags from the get go.Playing some of the game you immediately see that it has a very unfinished feel:The controls are rather clunky, and there are quite a few problems with the graphics. I can't find out how to rotate the display, which means [as it's in an isometric view], lots of stuff are hidden and can't be easily accessed. Many of the elements end up 'overlaying' themselves on each other, evidence of problems in the graphics engine itself.The gameplay is rather boring, frankly, and the game lacks flow. You're just dropped in without any real explanation of what the point is. Every now an then a passer by might interact with you with some, well, 'odd' dialogue is probably the nicest way to put it.The sound design in this game is probably the best part, honestly. It has some nice background music.Just to TL;DR, Don't buy it, its a shambles.
