content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								Spacebase had the potential to be a cool game and I liked the concept. As of this writing (and I don't see myself opening it up again) I have 5.7 hours of gameplay over the course of development; that's about as much gameplay as you can squeeze out of it. Truth be told you can run through about all the game has to offer at this point in one two-hour sit down - and that's fine - but definitely not for $25.00. I think the price tag is what really bugs me and, personally, says a lot about the way the higher-ups at Double Fine truly feel about the whole situation. Yeah, the whole rush to 1.0 is a bit of a joke and there won't be much to the vanilla full game. But to have the audacity to charge $25.00 in Early Access! And given that the time between now and its 1.0 release is mainly for bug fixing means you're not getting any more bang for your buck in terms of gameplay (i'm not sure a tutorial counts).This game was gifted to me nearly a year ago and bought by the giver for about the price of a movie ticket. I got nearly 3 movies-worth out of it, so by that reckoning we're doing alright. That being said, I would be incredibly angry to have bought this for $25.00 only to find what the game holds (and more or less will hold at release). It all seems like "poor sportsmanship" on Double Fine's part. So your game lacks polish and contains less gameplay than some free Flash games; at least be honest about what it's worth. In any case, post-"release" sales performance will, over time, likely drive the price to where it should be...somewhere around $5.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game will never-ever be worth the full price now that DF have announced that they're abandoning development. It MIGHT be worth a quater of the price IF the community gets into modding it to fix serious issues and add much needed content.MIGHTIF---I guess i should update this review now that the game has been released and has been updated to 1.05.I still play this game, and at the time of the edit to this review, i've invested about 70 hours into countless new games. The updates have helped a whole lot, but the game still has some playability issues: Doctors will often ignore corpses, which leads to bad morale, which leads to violence which leads to drastic crew loss.Raider events are too randomised, and can often lead to base failure in the very early game, or general drastic crew loss.The added raider mega-fleet event is a good idea in principal, but is vastly over-powered.Construction crew often take huge detors to the next block to be built when in space, which can lead to a new base failing, or causing unrecoverable crew loss in the very early game.Even with my reasonable system spec and the relative simplicity of the game, it tends to lag-out far too much.Generally; Base failure seems to be down to chance rather than skill.There are positives, howeverThere are mods appearing now, which is great. The community is addressing balence issues and adding reaseatch and similar. Workshop support is still very much missing, sadly.Overall:Has the potential to be a reasonable casual game, but really isn't worth the full price at all. Perhaps at a quater the price, it woulnd't be so bad.

												This game is fun, and as a space-themed strategy game about building a base in the middle of nowhere.  That part is fine. Anyway, here are some pros and cons.Pros:+ The game is fun, if you are patient.+ The community for this game is releasing unofficial updates to the game.+ Can actually present an occasional challenge.Cons:-The devs abandoned this at the side of the road like an unwanted child.- Might be a bit TOO challenging at times- $9.99 is a bit steep of a tag for a game that was abandoned in alpha.Summary:  Buy this game if you like space strategy games, and dear god, please don't buy it at full price, wait for a sale.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												This game is fun for the 30 - 45 minutes you can play.  Bugs still exist.Great concept and gameplay.  The problem is, even when in an "extremely low-risk" portion of the galaxy, you are faced with raider after raider after raider.  With 12 citizens and FOUR of the being 4-star "security"... ONE raider wiped out all but two citizens. Ridiculous.15 minutes later I had built back up to 5 citizens.  Three raiders wipe EVERYONE out.No way to save a game and return to it as far as I can tell.  You may "quit and save" then return later to where you left off....  But once catastrophe happens, you can't back up and try again.Start over?  I've done that plenty.  Tired of it.  This game sux and is the biggest waste of money I've ever experienced on Steam.As I said, good premise, fun game.  But no saves and wave after wave of intruders in the "significantly low risk" portion of the galaxy.  Ridiculous.Continuous message that my base is out of power yet it is NOT.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 19, 2015
												This game is fun, and as a space-themed strategy game about building a base in the middle of nowhere.  That part is fine.  What is not fine however, is how the devs abandoned this game part way through development.  Good thing I bought this on a really great sale when it was around the first few versions.  I cannot recommend this game unfortunately, even though I do actually like the game itself.  Wait for a sale if you want to buy it.  Anyway, here are some pros and cons.Pros:+ The game is fun, if you are patient.+ The community for this game is releasing unofficial updates to the game.+ Can actually present an occasional challenge.Cons:-The devs abandoned this at the side of the road like an unwanted child.- Might be a bit TOO challenging at times- $9.99 is a bit steep of a tag for a game that was abandoned in alpha.Summary:  Buy this game if you like space strategy games, and dear god, please don't buy it at full price, wait for a sale.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												A real shame.This game had some real potential. I love playing it but without finishing the game properly you run into the same issue with every play.You build, you research, and you run out of things to do. By the time you have researched all functional upgrades your space base is sprawling and you spend your time reassigning all staff to security detail when the multiple raider attacks start happening and then reassigning them back to their positions after the attack.Eventually you cannot look in all places at all times and "questionable" things begin occurring when your not looking in an  aggravating attempt to "fake" difficulty ala' MarioKart.The game itself is really not much more completed than what I played when I first purchased the Early Access version.The AI is shoddy, the dialogue feels very much like placeholder dialogue, and there are items to construct that seem to have no real bearing on game play (can anybody tell me what exactly reactors do or why my turrets don't shoot raider ships out of the sky before they board?).Feels bad to give this game a negative review, but it's earned it.

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
												TL;DR Don't bother, it doesn't follow it's own rules.What a steaming load.  I bought this for 99 cents and I still fell ripped off. sure, it looks okay, sure, it has it's atmosphere but the game doesn't understand what a "low chance of being raided" means. I played one game for ~4 hours today and I was actually starting to have fun. theeeen raider after raider after raider, waves of the scrublords killed my workers, so I had to assign people who were not workers.. they were murdered, eventually my security was killed off and everything fell to pot. This isn't a strategy game, this is an exercise in futility and it desperately needs fixing. (but its not being  developed any more, ohnooes) And if you think I'm just being salty over this, I moused over the galaxy and found the most ideal spot I could. (which is near the galactic center) I was looking for the easiest of easy modes to get my feet  wet before I tried any of the other areas. And it was decently easy! uuuntil the game decided to start throwing raiders at me like they were party favors. seriously, I couldn't even keep up with  the info box because it was all "hey, raiders. look, raiders. oh hey, guess what? raiders!" Maybe there's some sort of infinite loop, maybe there's some sort of size threshold that this happens at but I never even got my population to 40. On top of all of this I was unable to do any research, medical or tech related. I couldn't assign anyone to do anything like that even though I had a huge research bay with 16 or so research tables and at the peak, 4 scientists.  And can we talk about unhappiness? nothing  I did seemed to help them, they'd just go off and sulk and get into fights n stuff. All in all,  not as bad as Kirk Cameron's Saving Xmas, nor is it anywhere as awful as Depression Quest, but it has some serious coding and feature-related issues that really need to be looked at (if not by DF, then by allowing 3rd party patches to fix it.)

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								Early access brings the unfortunate risk of being burned and this game is the first one to have burned me badly enough to write a negative review. First of all, this is practically a demo that absolutely does not capture what makes this genre "fun". Generally the interesting thing about base building games is not about how you can create a utopia where nothing goes wrong, but how your base will eventually come to its inevitable end. Spacebase DF-9 fails to spark any continued enjoyment because of how quickly one can create a stable base without having to worry about anything bad ever happening. One playthrough was all it took to figure out all the kinks for the next time, where it is entirely possible to reach a state where everything simply balances itself out. This can be attributed to the fact that the game has a very short list of features.The short list of rooms have an incredibly short list of items one can add to it, so constructing a base on the second playthrough provides almost the exact same experience. It is not surprising how shallow this game feels compared to other games from the genre, even before you are hit by the realization that the learning curve is really just a horizontal line.The random events and the citizens "dynamic" behavior do not add a lot of variety, which is something that also quickly realized as you build your base. Understanding the patterns of the short list of events the game throws at you does not take a lot of figuring out, which is not surprising given the fact that you can count these on one hand. To make things even worse, any negative event that can happen is easily preventable with the aforementioned short list of items at your disposal. The only challenging element this game presents, is the incredibly stupid AI that is set on destroying itself as early as building the very first airlock for the base. God help them if they are apart of your mining crew and there happens to be two airlocks to your base, because they are more likely to asphyxiate in space than they are picking which one is closer so they do not die.Again, all these negative aspects can be attributed due to the fact that this title is feature INCOMPLETE and will probably remain so, unless it builds a decent modding community (which is incredibly unlikely to happen given the current state). The keyword here is short, as in the feature list, the amount of time this game was given development time until its "full" release, and any enjoyment you can get out of it.I would be lying if I said I had never been so disappointed by a game before, but certainly not with a game that I was so excited to see completed. In the end I, and several other hopefuls lost out on $20-25 on a game that will never be finished. And while they did not lie to us about "silently pulling the plug", but they certainly lied about delivering us a "complete" game. With them violating my trust, I will never be purchasing another early access title or Double Fine game ever again.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
												Today I thought I would write a somewhat higher quality review for this game.Gameplay is utterly horrible. The interface is very clunky and you will be lucky if you actualy do get a base up to specs. To begin with the game is so full of game killing bugs that 9 out of 11 games I played were ended NOT because of a disaster, but because of  a major game killing bug.  I even had to restart the game 6 times in a row one time just because there was a bug that was killing it shortly after launching.. Moving on we now go to the general aspects of the game itself: Support 0/10This game was released in an unfinished state and is abandoned yet sold on here for $20 (at the time of posting) I can not give a game in this condition or state any kind of rating at all.  Moving on, the devs are not freindly at all and have banned people for expressing their opinions that the game was a piece of vaporware.  You can take a look at the discussion forums for yourself on this and get a good idea of just how much censorship that is going on and make up your own minds on this . Graphics 5/10I am really not impressed with the graphics.  They are not impressive at all and were somewhat below average. Sounds and Music 1/10This is an area that is bare bones.  Obvioiusly this area of the game also did not get fnished.  What little music and sounds that there are  annoying as it is repetitous. Gameplay 1/10I tried. No really I tried and I got 1 decent game out of 30+ hours which yielded  constant frustration from game killing bugs.  So I give gameplay a 1 because it was fun until the game was killed by a bug. Fun 2/10What time I did play that was not killed by a game killing bug was fun so I give it a 2 in this area. Price:  due to the bugs, unfinished state, and unfrinedly devs it is my opinion that this is one game that definitely NOT worth more than a few pennies. Bugs and Execution:  The interface sucks, the game is full of game crushing bugs. I hope this review has been helpful to anyone looking for a new game. Feel free to comment.Overall :  This game is not just an epic failure but truly IS  vaporware.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												Very promising idea, however, the game is unfinished. It has so many glitches, that it is bound to break after some time of gameplay.To be honest: I'm sick an tired of constantly being the alpha- or beta-tester!The game lacks the very basics. You can only save your game by quitting. If you accidentally click on "how to play" or "New Base" you lose everything regardless if you have saved previously or not. You are not even asked "are you sure?" or be warned the your current game will be lost.In terms of gameplay:It is quiet unbalanced. Constant attacks don't give you much time to breath if you have not found the right area in the galaxy for building your base.Sometimes ships dock at your station and there is nothing you can do about it. If these ships happen to have exterior turrets you might as well start from scratch. Because these turret will tear your crew apart and you won't have a chance to disable or even destroy them.Again. Haven't the developers even played the game? Other players keep having the same problem. There seems to be no answer accoring to the double fine board.You have to start over several times in the beginning until you have figured out what to do. There is a tutorial, but everything it does is presenting you a half finished base. There is nothing that explains the building items, what to take care of or the basics of managing the station.Sometimes some of your citizens just stop doing their duties and telling you they are bored. You send security to a place where pirates tried to break into your ship and they just keep patroling the base. On occation citizens refuse to enter a room and do maintainance... which results in suffocation of all citizens on your station.So, what do you do against those pirates raiding your base? You build some turrets of your own. Then one of your scientists goes mad, usually you would stop him and throw him into the brig until he stops acting up... but the turret has a better idea: it shoots him.Conclusion:Under no circumstance is this game in a "release"-state! Beta at most. I feel violated as an alpha-tester again by a company which obviously did not even bother to try and play their own f***ing game! It reminds me a lot of the initial problems of X-Rebirth. But this company does not even show effort in fixing these issues.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												I can't say anything that hasn't already been said. It's kind of obvious why I can't recommend this!* Updating my review as this game is out of Early Access now *In the good old days of games, companies would invest money into developing a game. Sometimes these investments wouldn't pay off and the game would be unceremoniously cancelled. Remember Snake Plissken's First Escape for the PS2? Me neither. How about the next MMO from Blizzard that was recently canned?With Spacebase, not only do you get the experience of a game cancelled in mid-development but you also get the luxury of paying for it.Without chasing the rabbit about the dubious nature of the way this game was funded, it's fair to say that I and everyone else who bought this in early access took a risk that didn't pay off. That doesn't mean I can't and shouldn't have expected better from an established development studio.

content:

Early Access Review
								There are dozens of posts explaining their blunder. Poor money choices, they desperately need an accountant. And if they have one, dude should be fired and his degree sent back to whatever cracker jack box he "earned" it from.... That, and this should be proof that more developers on a project DOES NOT mean more success.... just more failure. GG guys, GG. If a game has Double Fine on it, I'll be skipping it from now on. Your rep is not great or even good at all, the days of Monkey Island and Day of the Tentacle are long lost, and I'm saddened by this - Like you were paid to prove these sorts of games AREN'T successful, when I have seen a lot of success in them. FTL is amazing, just to name one. And it is recent. And indy built. DF isn't indy... They just aren't professional anymore. I'd scale them with the wierd uncle who claims he could do all this great stuff, but when he shows you, claims he isn't in his prime anymore when he falls on his face. Repeatedly. Because he doesn't get that then and now are two different times, and his pride won't let him stop. But people want to keep seeing him try in hopes that he can do what he used to do. And we spend hours over the dinner table listening to "back in the day, I used to..." But what now? He's old and worn, and can't get back to his proper feet anymore. And it saddens us, because he used to be the cool uncle, now he's just the weird one.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								just as they promised not to, this fly by night dev, has rather loudly pulled the plug on Spacebase. It has been disastrous to their reputationand it has killed the games fanbase emotionally.This game is Early Access AbandonWareIt is DEADIf I were in Double Fine position, id drop the price to $5 and see if that could help generate sales. BUTThis is why you shouldnt buy this game.NOW as for why you shouldnt even play it. Its undercooked and unfinished and will never be finished,the core gameplay that is here is lacking, and there are much bettermanagement sims available than this, go play SimCity instead, The worst thing is, whats here isnt bad, its a fun game ( not £18.99 fun however) and there clearly was a lot of promise here, but it lacks a cohesive and complete designa victim of the early access nature of the game, very basic systems were in place herewith no real central mechanics, while it is noticably graphically superior to the amnesia fortnight prototype, mechanically it is almost just as under developed andafter 18 months of development, a lot of promised features are completely missing.While I understand Double Fine has a passion and a penchant for making unique andinteresting games, they absolutely shouldnt not start making a game that they cannot gauruntee to finish. Spacebase DF-9 should have never been greenlit, I love the idea butthe project completely failed, and Double Fine didnt gamble their own money on this, or even their investors money on this, they gambled OUR money on Spacebase. The game made its initial investment back pretty quickly, but due to a high price and lack of featuresonly a small subset of dedicated fans jumped in. Early Access is supposed to be a tool for devs to make a little extra money before a game is finished. The game should be planned and financially secure for completion before coming to Early Access and in spite of it. It absolutely should NOT be the primary form of financial resource for a game, ESPECIALLY for a professional studio like Double Fine that is located in a city like San Francisco that has a high cost of living. This game shouldnt even existand poor management has cost me and many others about £19 and it has cost Double Finemy trust and future trade.Im Sorry JP LeBreton, I really wanted Spacebase DF-9 to succeed, but you gambledwith my trust and now Double Fine has lost it.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								Developer Double Fine has posted that the final release of the game will be version 1.0 and that no more versions will be released.  This comes at a time when the game is still in alpha and lacks considerable depth.  Be warned, if you are buying this game after 9/18/2014 you are potentially buying a dead game.  You can plow through what little content is there in an hour and from Double Fine's last post it seems unlikely much content will be added for the "final" 1.0.--Spacebase DF-9 is an interesting play on the Dwarf Fortress formula.  Instead of carving out a kingdom from rock you are inversely adding a "kingdom" to the vacuum of space.  Similar to Dwarf Fortress you are given little control over your citizens.  Instead you play the role of macromanager, assigning citizens to tasks and watching them go about their day.  Certain events will trigger at random times forcing you to deal with raiders, parasites, killbots, and meteorites.While all of this sounds fun in theory the problem is that Spacebase DF9 is competing with 10 years of Dwarf Fortress development.  As of Alpha version 6 there is still relatively little to do.  You can speed run through an hour of gameplay and basically see all that Double Fine has to offer, afterwards the game offers little reason to continue playing.  Unlike Dwarf Fortress, Spacebase misses the boat on simulated empire building.Don't let my number of in-game hours sway you, 40 of those hours are from idling the game while I did work.

Posted: September 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								A few months ago I likely would have recommended this game. While development was fairly slow, they were making progress and the game was getting better. I was hopeful for the future as the game had, in my opinion, a very solid foundation.With the news that this game is now only getting one more major patch; I can no longer in good faith recommend it to anybody. This game was initially touted as a 'Sci-Fi Dwarf Fortress," but make no mistake, it offers nowehere near the complexity or longevity, The feature list is incredibly underwhelming for a sim game of it's type, and you will very quickly lose interest in the little this game has to offer. After a few hours you will have experienced absolutely everything. They could have done so much more with the concept, (and planned to,) but nothing in this game will strike you as particularly unique or groundbreaking. The fact of the matter is this game seriously underdeliverd on the features that were going to distinguish it from other games in the genre. You can go back and look at the archived dev plans to get an idea.Of course, this was always the danger of early access. There's no guarantee that the game you fund will make it to it's fully realized state. If a game becomes unprofitable; they'll ship it in it's current state regardless of planned features. As far as I know, this is the highest profile early access game that has seriously underdelivered. Let it serve you as a warning when buying other early access titles. After this I don't think I'll be putting money behind any more games that have a chance to be released so woefully unfinished.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								Developer Double Fine has posted that the final release of the game will be version 1.0 and that no more versions will be released.  This comes at a time when the game is still in alpha and lacks considerable depth.  Be warned, if you are buying this game after 9/18/2014 you are potentially buying a dead game.  You can plow through what little content is there in an hour and from Double Fine's last post it seems unlikely much content will be added for the "final" 1.0.--Spacebase DF-9 is an interesting play on the Dwarf Fortress formula.  Instead of carving out a kingdom from rock you are inversely adding a "kingdom" to the vacuum of space.  Similar to Dwarf Fortress you are given little control over your citizens.  Instead you play the role of macromanager, assigning citizens to tasks and watching them go about their day.  Certain events will trigger at random times forcing you to deal with raiders, parasites, killbots, and meteorites.While all of this sounds fun in theory the problem is that Spacebase DF9 is competing with 10 years of Dwarf Fortress development.  As of Alpha version 6 there is still relatively little to do.  You can speed run through an hour of gameplay and basically see all that Double Fine has to offer, afterwards the game offers little reason to continue playing.  Unlike Dwarf Fortress, Spacebase misses the boat on simulated empire building.Don't let my number of in-game hours sway you, 40 of those hours are from idling the game while I did work.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								Unfortunately the final release of this game is not an improvement on the earliest alpha at all. Throughout the alpha the gameplay did not change at all. Instead each alpha update added some tacked on crap that contributed very little to the game. GoodThe characters you construct a base for seem to have depth. They have feelings and thoughts and you can read about them and so on. The basic gameplay elements for a base builder are there and function.BadThe game seems to be caught somewhere between Dungeon Keeper and the Sims. Unfortunately, the emphasis seems to be on Sims gameplay. The station inhabitants have clearly had more effort put into them than the actual gameplay. This could have been a positive thing, as it is in the Sims which is a great game, except without a base and proper neccessities all your inhabitants will die. So you find yourself in a panic to build a base early, made all the harder by the fact that your workers spend more time socializing and posting to their "spacebook" than building things essential to survival. This is made even more frustrating by the single most terrible UI I've seen in a modern game ever. In conclusion, the game isn't finished. The gameplay in Spacebase is incredibly underdeveloped and clunky. There isn't even anything to do. You build a small base and then there's nothing. You could make a bigger base, but there's no reason to. There's no challenge. Despite a year and a half of development this still plays like a terrible demo.

content:

												I started with DF-9 very early on, the updates were consistent and beefy enough that it kept my attention and I didn't feel I wasted too much time with a few new stations every build. New problems would of course pop up every Alpha release, but that is to be expected and for the most party they were ignored, yet underlying and game breaking issues never seemed to get fixed that made the end game for the most part pointless while cosmetic and uneeded areas were implemented. The game is playable for the most part but feels to have been abandoned after being pushed into release after it seems it ran out of money. I would have even recomended the game had the Devs fixed what is there, I could have forgiven the game missing many of the promised features but as it stands now until it gets some much needed attention the review is going to remain negative and I can't in good faith recommend it to anyone which really is disappointing as it had such promise and I did enjoy it despite being broken and unplayable past certain points.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								If it wasnt for bad optimization on the Pathfinding and other core parts of the game, you would be through with it in aprox. 10 hours max. Comparing the current price (~20 €-ish) with what you would pay for an Alien Isolation key and the tense action and story telling, well lets just say go for A:I. To make this review more helpful, I will shortly tell you what is currently in the game: Build a base with oxygen-generators, a simple airlock and some rooms. Create a food source. Mine Asteroids around you and enlarge your base. Upgrade food source and build living and recreation areas. Research stuff. This, all the while you are defending against Pirate raids, that wouldnt be a problem, if not for the bad Pathfinding and AI in general, that paralyzes your security officer on duty, unable to shoot at the invaders. PLEASE dont buy this game as it is Vaporware and clearly was ment to be a cash scam all along. Though I see little hope, I will try my luck with a refund for my money, as many people here have been scammed into this product. If you dont believe, just watch the forums here. Thanks

Early Access Review
								This game is in ALPHA. You should expect bugs.If you are surprised by the fact that there are bugs, I honestly don't know how you're breathing right now.Spacebase DF-9 is an excellent concept for a game. It's like a space-themed Prison Architect: you micro-manage the needs of your crew, build/destroy sections, new world events happen, etc.But that concept has been poorly executed. The updates seem to be coming fewer and farther between, with not much added to keep your interest. It seems Double Fine have put this game on the back burner.And as I said, it contains bugs. The AI of characters is still a bit dumb, but it has improved since I started playing.All in all, if you're very patient, and don't mind waiting around for updates and waiting for the game to figure out what you want, it has potential. Whether that potential is worth 25 USD is a personal choice.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								Since everyone's reviews are solely their views on Double Fine's recent announcement, I'll go ahead and take a look at the game in its current state.As it is right now, Spacebase DF-9 shouldn't be called anywhere near completed.  I mean, the game works and all but there are a lot of glaring problems with it.  After a few runs through the game, I couldn't help but notice that every space sector you play in has almost zero differences between them.  The astro density determines how much asteroid is in your area to mine from, which is appreciated, but it hardly makes up for everything else.  The threat level has very little difference, as it apparently suggests how often your base gets showered on by meteors and debris, while warpgate proximity indicates how often you get potential new residents passing by.  What is evidently missing is where Raider occurrences would be placed, since they happen fairly regularly.The Raiders themselves are stupendously overpowered.  The raiding parties vary between one and three Raiders that *will* decimate your population, no matter how well-trained your Security staff is.  The reason for this is because they tank damage like it's nothing while killing a majority (if not all) of your residents in less than five shots each.  The defensive turrets don't offer much by way of defense.  As the camera is locked to only one perspective, you only have the option to face the turrets downward (i.e. towards the bottom of the map) to either the left or right directions.  Seriously, you can't really use them to shoot at the approaching vessels since they have to be *inside* the base.The base amenities are also a joke as follows:- Despite having oxygen capacity for X number of people, the second I fill the base to capacity, the oxygen recyclers eventually fail as if I was overbooked (despite each recycler to be working perfectly at roughly 80-85% durability).  This caused my residents to panic and run around, abandoning all jobs and waiting until they either starved to death (because they used up all of the matter in stock) or waited until the next Raider party exterminated them all.- The bar doesn't offer much, since it's the only thing that works in the Pub zone.  I have seen neither the fridge nor stove used at all so they're essentially useless.- I set up a Reserch Zone and set a tech to research but my Scientist was busy doing everything else while on duty rather than actually research anything.Overall, the game pretty much sucks since each playthrough is just the same thing: see how big your base can get before Raiders kill them all.  And given how Double Fine's treating the game now, I'd have to agree with everyone else.  The developers are basically dropping the project and turning the rest of the game's development over to the community after announcing that they're releasing the source code for the scripts and pushing the game out the door with a 1.0 full release version.  Avoid this game and pick up somthing better instead, like the classic StarTopia or even Prison Architect (which I also have). Spacebase DF-9 is simply a waste of time and money.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												UPDATE: The game is basically "Beta" now. From the release of 1.0 there were no new features added. They finally fixed the 3FPS that plagued linux/mac OS, but the game now randomly crashes.  The AI when building will get stuck in walls regularly. Have to close and re-open to fix. This hasn't been fixed from alpha 6. Two months ago. The tutorial is complete crap. There is no audio queues and it is VERY uniformitive. All they did was have text on the bottom and hope the random event generator triggers what to do next. Crew members will walk back and forth until they die - refusing to either fix/build oxygen supplies.  There is  no way to keep track of power usage.  Just build until you run out of power. THAT WAY when something breaks you'll be completely screwed.Proximity to the warpgate things don't make any difference on how much spam you have to put up with for people constantly trying to join your base. Everything I listed has been a problem since alpha 5/6. No fix. All they did was just plop on some text call it a tutorial and fix the 3FPS issue for linux/mac.Don't buy. Complete scam.Below is my original review.Early access linux backer. (Same review would thereby apply to Mac to some degree)Game is in last Alpha stage. They are moving to have it be labled as "1.0", aka finished. However. The game is completely unplayable in linux and barely works (from what I understand) in mac. There is no support here for it, and the developer is just claiming "modders will fix it", and we have to rely on the developer to test the game themselves, when, after this lastest aplha stage, TWO platforms that are supposed to be supported do not work. Do not buy this game. It is completely unfinished, and will likely not even work on your system due to lack of testing in development. They have completely skipped beta stage of development.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is not finished, and it has come out that it never will be.  There are a handful of hours that are enjoyable, but not in the way you think.  It seems to be building up to something.  You gather resources and put together a station, and at no time is your progress ever really threatened.  Then, you have everything built up, you've put lasers on the walls and have a small army of security and... nothing ever happens.  There are no truly challenging random events, there are no barriers that you have to work around to build your base, there's never any challenge at all.  And then there's no kind of endgame after this, you can just keep expanding and staring at your stable, boring base (that is in itself neither complex nor complicated, with no tough systems to learn or figure out) for eternity.  And Double Fine has come out and said that this is all that there ever will be.Don't buy this game.  It's all build-up, no climax.  No challenges.  Even the resource gathering and base/population management isn't difficult because it's too simple and easy.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								DO NOT BUY.Investment in an Early Access game may carry some measure of risk, sure. But from an established studio like Double Fine, there's a reasonable expectation of not only a certain level of quality, but of a completed product. With Spacebase DF9, we're getting neither of those.Deciding that pre-release sales aren't up to their expectations, Double Fine has opted to cancel further development of DF9, label the next version 1.0, and abandon it. Sure, we'll get some bug fixes in 1.0, but the game isn't nearly ready for release. Between miners who refuse to stop working and suffocate before reaching the airlock, doctors who can't be bothered to retrieve dead bodies, construction items that builders ignore, and a notable lack of features and variety, DF9 is an incomplete and sometimes outright broken product. That never bothered me much because I kept telling myself, "It's still alpha. It'll get better."That Double Fine is using sales of an alpha to determine the game isn't promising enough to finish is astonishing. The lack of commitment to invested fans is even more so. Of course it's not selling well; it's not a good product yet. This almost makes one miss the old days, when games didn't sell at all before release. Then no one could complain, "it didn't sell well enough before we finished it."This is the kind of thing we've come to expect from no-name, fly-by-night indie devs, but from a studio like Double Fine it's all the more shocking, if not more shameful.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								As an early access game, DF9 was decent. There was definable progress. I'll admit it, it was fun. There were bugs, and early access gripes, but the EA rule I use is that "As long I can visualize this being finished, done, and fun, I can consider spending money on it." DF9 met those criteria. However, as the game has moved abruptly to a "release", and with the complete stoppage of new features, Double Fine has fallen far, far short of even approaching their planned development milestones. Further, the lack of believable rationales, detailed explanations, or even breakdowns about why this came about mean that I can't in good faith recommend that you purchase this game, or any future titles from Double Fine productions until some form of publically disclosed management shakeup takes place. They reportedly raised approximately half a million dollars to develop this game. They then stopped development, citing financial reasons. They do not appear to have then offered any breakdown of where said money went. They are now confused, as people are angry and asking "WHERE DID THAT MONEY GO!?" The statements I have reviewed do not appear to show that this logical connectoin has been made.The final nail in the coffin was a "AWESOME DEV PROCESS GREAT JOB" timeline that was issued as a "We're sorry we took your money, but don't pay attention to the archived feature lists we pumped for months about what we were going to do, instead read this sleek graphic that shows what we DID do! JUST DONT COMPARE THE TWO!" Their conduct in this and other products leads me to the following unfortunate conclusion regarding Double Fine Productions:They simply are not a worthwhile investment for your consumer dollars. This is not the first time this endgame has come about for one of their product. That is not to say Double Fine is an intrinsically bad company, or that they cannot make good games. But I simply cannot justify spending money on early access titles from them now or in the future.At this point, Double Fine serves as an argument for Valve to more or less micro-audit game development companies, even basic indie ones, for management practices. Whether that is feasible or a correct response is a different matter, but Double Fine's performance definitely elicits that reaction. That or open up a "Developer Review" page to trash talk developers (This would also be a bad idea, but it is my inclination in response). A more reasonable option would be for Valve to construct a form of "Warning Stick" that it can publically shake at developers who mis-behave in such a fashion. A "We're reviewing their sales agreement" or "We're considering yanking their priviledge to post on early access" type of statement, to remind developers that Early Access is not a kickstarter equivalent, but is rather an opportunity to generate interest and feedback on your products.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is in ALPHA. You should expect bugs.If you are surprised by the fact that there are bugs, I honestly don't know how you're breathing right now.Spacebase DF-9 is an excellent concept for a game. It's like a space-themed Prison Architect: you micro-manage the needs of your crew, build/destroy sections, new world events happen, etc.But that concept has been poorly executed. The updates seem to be coming fewer and farther between, with not much added to keep your interest. It seems Double Fine have put this game on the back burner.And as I said, it contains bugs. The AI of characters is still a bit dumb, but it has improved since I started playing.All in all, if you're very patient, and don't mind waiting around for updates and waiting for the game to figure out what you want, it has potential. Whether that potential is worth 25 USD is a personal choice.

								This game is completely unfinished and is going into full release without being even close to completion, which is just an attempt to squeeze some money out of an abandoned game.They also promoted the game on Steam to try and lure people to buy it just before they dumped all the promised features and abandoned development, which in my eyes is sneaky and deceptive and best, and borderline criminal at worst.After trying repeatedly to start building the base. Just *start* the base that is, I encountered a series of bugs and issues which meant that my crew didn't go into the base I had built, died for no real reason etc etc. There is no guidance to indicate what is wrong, so it is hard to tell when it is a bug or you have made a mistake. The answer is probably both.Avoid avoid avoid.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
Perhaps some should tell Double Fine a Tutorial stage is supposed to be easy?The Tutorial stage is actually quite difficult for a newcomer - the 'area' the tutorial station is placed in has a 'high threat' level, and any time I tried to expand my station by adding a new feature, I found myself swarmed with raiders so that any residents I had out in space suits were inevitably killed. I cannot count the number of times my space station found istelf down to a tiny crew due to the rest being killed off. You will have much more satisfaction with the 'New Base' option.This is a game with  basis, but too many frustrating points. What would help:- the ability to 'jump' to a location on the map when a message is given, ie, a derelict has appeared, so-and-so is under attack, etc- the ability to 'jump' to a resident from the roster- a clearer indication of residents' moods and wants- more options for decor/entertainment- a help menu that lists the different features and what they do, instead of a too-difficult tutorial- more features!!!!On the whole, I know I will keep playing for the construction aspect, which is why I bought it, but I cannot honestly recommend it to anyone yet. Perhaps Double Fine will come back to it at some point; in light of the negative reviews it's getting, though, I rather doubt it.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								I hate writing such short reviews but I simply wish to express my opinion after many hours of gameplay (I do get to give a post 36 hour review, regardless):Post 18 hour review summary (terminated as of release information until 1.0): I would STRONGLY recommend not purchasing this project until you see what comes in at 1.0 release. The ship has sailed, so to speak, on spacebase DF-9. The money brought in for DF-9 was considered insufficient to continue the project and the developers are going to ship the product as is.  You are welcome to receive a product that, with slight and fully justified speculation, will remain permanently as an alpha (it never reached beta) in support of double fine but I would be cautious.I do recommend to all early access payers, however, to recognize how frequently we receive products that are not even identified as "alpha or beta" and to be kind to double fine. I would suggest most players refer to many battlefield and call of duty releases to see how beta's can be pushed out as "final projects". Double fine has to begin to regain some form of capital from this project and the only way they can is by releasing the game. I commend the team for being open and honest about their decision, as hard as it is. Positives:+ Double Fine was open and honest+ Graphics are well managed+ Concept well thought out and fun+ Obvious love and commitment put into the projectNegative-Game is being accelerated to final state with obvious, often game ending, bugs-From the developer: "Spacebase DF9 is still a fun, clever, hilarious, beautiful and complete game."

content:

Early Access Review
								I sank nearly 50 hours into this shambling mess of a game that had potential to be fun and interesting.I even tactily believed a team of 4 people could handle developing the game, because the reputation of Double Fine and the People on the team backed up by a firm development timeline, making good but not exceptional progress.Since my purchase in Alpha 4, a handful of small changes have made it seem to be a good overall investment and a likely turnaround. I even helped other people on the steam forums and DF forums.And yet, i was hesitant recommending DF9, because Early Access isn't the same as buying a released game, it's not even kickstarter, you can't get a refund or the money back if it fails, you have to accept a shining pile of♥♥♥♥♥♥and hope the developer has the stomach to make it better over time when you buy a game through Early Access, That's the primary condition Steam sets for you. That all changed on the 19th September, 2014 when they abandoned the game, saying there was no more money in development. If you're going to get this game, wait for a humble bundle and pay $2, that's a little high for what it's worth, definitely  not the $30 i paid to test out a failed experiment.♥♥♥♥ you Tim Schafer. ♥♥♥♥ you.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								As an early access game, DF9 was decent. There was definable progress. I'll admit it, it was fun. There were bugs, and early access gripes, but the EA rule I use is that "As long I can visualize this being finished, done, and fun, I can consider spending money on it." DF9 met those criteria. However, as the game has moved abruptly to a "release", and with the complete stoppage of new features, Double Fine has fallen far, far short of even approaching their planned development milestones. Further, the lack of believable rationales, detailed explanations, or even breakdowns about why this came about mean that I can't in good faith recommend that you purchase this game, or any future titles from Double Fine productions until some form of publically disclosed management shakeup takes place. They reportedly raised approximately half a million dollars to develop this game. They then stopped development, citing financial reasons. They do not appear to have then offered any breakdown of where said money went. They are now confused, as people are angry and asking "WHERE DID THAT MONEY GO!?" The statements I have reviewed do not appear to show that this logical connectoin has been made.The final nail in the coffin was a "AWESOME DEV PROCESS GREAT JOB" timeline that was issued as a "We're sorry we took your money, but don't pay attention to the archived feature lists we pumped for months about what we were going to do, instead read this sleek graphic that shows what we DID do! JUST DONT COMPARE THE TWO!" Their conduct in this and other products leads me to the following unfortunate conclusion regarding Double Fine Productions:They simply are not a worthwhile investment for your consumer dollars. This is not the first time this endgame has come about for one of their product. That is not to say Double Fine is an intrinsically bad company, or that they cannot make good games. But I simply cannot justify spending money on early access titles from them now or in the future.At this point, Double Fine serves as an argument for Valve to more or less micro-audit game development companies, even basic indie ones, for management practices. Whether that is feasible or a correct response is a different matter, but Double Fine's performance definitely elicits that reaction. That or open up a "Developer Review" page to trash talk developers (This would also be a bad idea, but it is my inclination in response). A more reasonable option would be for Valve to construct a form of "Warning Stick" that it can publically shake at developers who mis-behave in such a fashion. A "We're reviewing their sales agreement" or "We're considering yanking their priviledge to post on early access" type of statement, to remind developers that Early Access is not a kickstarter equivalent, but is rather an opportunity to generate interest and feedback on your products.

Early Access Review
								In this game you essenitally layout rooms on a 2d grid made to look like space.  People randomly come up and ask to join your station where you have to keep them alive and happy and also use them to help keep your station running.  Sometimes you get invaders.  The core features to make it a base-building game are there.While the developers had some good ideas, they did not get fleshed out nearly enough and there is very little content otherwise.With the announcement of release just a month or two away it's clear that the developer abandoned this title well before it was able to reach it's potential.   Fun for a couple hours but not worth the $25 asking price.  If you can grab it for 5 bucks or less it may be worth it.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
												Review for version 1.01Its ♥♥♥♥in horrible. Still buggy as hell. Still very little to do. The goals are pointless and more like achievements (get 50 people, kill 50 raiders, build every object).My 45 minute experience on the new 'release' included such highlights as:My best tech sufficating because they were outside shooting at nothing, and nothing that I did stopped them (changed role, cuff, send to infirm/brig)The 'holdables' littering that map from the countless people that just 'died' for bugger all reason.A part of my station catching fire, and 5 people dying because I locked the room down and opened it to space to clear the O2. What did everyone do? Jump in their suits and go around through the open door, start fighting the fire AND THEN GET OUT OF THEIR SUITS IN A ROOM WITH NO O2.Fire animation remains after the fire is extingished. Now my base has a bunch of camp fires around it.In a area with 'Very Low' raiders, had 10 raids between new colonists (not including the potental raids in the form of message that I know the answer to to make them not raid)Colonists are still stupidly difficult to please. I have to click through 3 or 4 menus to figure out whats wrong with them.Construction workers die pulling down a wreak because it had a alien in it. The alien attacked and killed a construction worker (who, I would like to point out I cant control to make him run away) dispite that fact that the 'room' the alien was in was open to space along the entire lenght of it. About 15 squares open to space. After killing my construction worker the alien ran FURTHER into the room, and only then was sucked into space.Raiders still use the airlock, which means to beat them: wait until the raiders desuit in airlock > pause > unzone room > lock door to base > open door to space > they get sucked out. There is no reason at all to ever fight these raiders. This is the single best way to beat them. And it sucks.Honestly Ive got like 100 more gripes just from the last 45 minutes I've been playing the new update, but I can sum it all up with:Game sucks. Feel half finished (because it is). Wish I didnt buy it. Dont buy it.

												I've logged a lot of time into this game, and pick it up every now and then and play it for stretches at a time. You'd THINK that would lead me to recommend it, but no. I don't recommend this game to purchase.I started playing the prototype that released with the Double Fine prototype bundle, and I really, really enjoyed it. I was so thrilled when the game hit Steam, and couldn't wait to see where it went. Well, it did add features to the prototype game, which I was playing regularly, so in that sense I'm still enjoying it. However, the game is extremely unfinished and buggy. Asking $10 for it is a slap in the face to consumers; they should ask no more than $1 or so for an unfinished game, if that. Basically, I've played more completed games from Pyweek, and that's folks slapping together games in a week -_- All that said, I do like playing this game; I enjoy the space sim aspect, and since I've never really gotten a successful, self-maintaining base running it's sort of a perpetual challenge. But I can't recommend it to others because it's so broken. I'm surprised Double Fine has the balls to keep it in the Steam store at $10.

This game is slightly decent though if you install the fan made patch https://forums.doublefine.com/topic/16066-the-unofficial-v107-patch/ which fixes most of the broblems many people had.Overall this was a fun game for a free experience but the lack of content doesnt even come close to justifying the $9.99 price.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
												Being a fan of the old “Tycoon” games and “Theme Hospital” I was really excited about Space Base DF-9. I thought for sure reviewers were being too hard on it, so as soon as I saw it pop up in a Humble Bundle I was ecstatic… But, all of my excitement was for naught. Almost 6 hours wasted and I can pretty well guarantee I will never touch this title again.TL;DR There is a ton of promise here. When the game is running smooth there’s not a lot to complain about (except maybe lack of construction options), but eventually that smooth ride will be over and you’ll realize nothing works like it should, if at all. So while playable you’ll hit a point where the effort to advance isn’t worth it. If you still think you want to punish yourself by playing this game make sure you check out http://www.spacebasehub.net/ for the unofficial patch, the mechanics are still broken but everything else has been improved.In-depth ReviewOverall Gameplay: The basic construction and management section of the game is fairly well done. It’s very similar to “Theme Hospital”, but with a slightly improved interface. That’s where the positives end. So many things are broken that it becomes unnecessarily difficult, and not in a fun, challenging way but in a “oh there’s another thing that doesn’t work right” kind of way. Here are just a few examples of things you’ll see characters do:- Die of suffocation despite being surrounded by rooms with oxygen and having access to an airlock with space suits, - Become incapacitated (not dead, just lying around uselessly) indefinitely. If they’re Raiders they actually might be back up and start killing people!- Be marked for the brig or infirmary but never go there- Scientists not researching (despite being assigned research and having a research station).- Ignore the 3 fire extinguishers near the fire, and instead stomp on it until they catch on fire, then run around the base being ignored by everyone else until they burn to death… Actually that might’ve been the most entertaining part of the game!Presentation: The user interface is easy to navigate but overly simple. You only have 1 save slot and the game auto saves by default, so if you’re not careful it’s quite easy to erase a save game by clicking on the wrong thing and not exiting before it overwrites your game.The graphics are fine. They’re quite obviously a throwback to “Theme Hospital” (how many times can I name dop?). It works well for the genre, and they’re fairly sharp. The sound is outright boring, the music is nothing impressive and off the top of my head I honestly don’t remember any sounds other than that and the chirping alarm if you zoom in far enough.Summary:This game could be so good, but as in so many cases now it looks like the developer took their money and ran. In my love/hate relationship with Early Access this is why the hate portion exists. I’d give it a 3/10, it’s playable and as long as things work right it’s quite enjoyable, but the unpredictable and frustrating broken mechanics make it another EA Trash title. Pick it up in a bundle with some good games or for $1 or less and get a couple hours of fun… But DO NOT, under any circumstances pay any more for it than that. Especially when you could get the vastly superior Theme Hospital and forget this all together.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2014
												Alright, due to the negative reviews I'm getting I'll go ahead and make a slightly better review.Edit: I just saw that DoubleFine is paying people to write them reviews, yeah no. ♥♥♥♥ you Doublefine.Pros:+Interesting Idea+Cool 80s Atmosphere (e.g. funiture)Cons:-Doulbefine has actually dropped development on this game, so unless you're a modder/want to waste money on an incomplete game then move on. I understand that not all alphas go well, but Doublefine being a sucessful company really has no excuse for this sorry pile of crap. To make up for it they did give all owners of SBDF9 a free copy of Hack n' Slash, but for me personally that really doesn't make the cut.-Game gets pretty repetitive, build base, start colonizing the base and doing well, get ♥♥♥♥ed by an asteroid and repeat. Maybe that's a little harsh of me, but that's basically my experience of this game.-Lots of bug to completely ♥♥♥♥ up your run.-The amount of content in this game is enough to keep you entertained for about 6 hours.-Price is way to high for an alpha, and that's what hurt everybody in the long run.-Payed reviews.Conclusion:I  do not recommend at all that you buy this game, no devolpment on this game means no new features, bug fixes, etc. I highly doubt modders will be able to save this game. As well, with the current amount of content it's just not worth your time and or money. Thank you for reading my review on SpaceBase DF.Final Score: 4/10

												Got this game for free all of the sudden today. So I said, "why not"? Ive played many isometric strat type games like this and this one is pretty horrible. Right away glitches with people in space suits, glitches with building, glitches glitches glitches. So naturaly I head right to the bugs report / forum for this early access title to report it. Come to find out, its NOT early access. This is it, this is what "shipped". I'm going to give it another try just to make sure I wasn't too far off the mark. But ya, it's pretty horrible. Building anything is a chore, rosters are a nice idea but the UI leaves something lacking, te game "feels" like a poorly made reboot of an old game I ued to play in the late 90's. (It's actually 90%+ desgined like that game, just poorly executed.) In short: If you get this for free, try it so you know what you wont like in a game. If you paid money for this, i'm sorry. I'm so so sorry.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
												I really wanted to like this game. I saw it featured very early on and picked it up. It was ok, there was a decent core game, but there were some bugs/glitches etc.This was when the developers were updating the game.Since that time, there have been very few, limiting updates. To my mind, there is no real point to the game. The whole thing about choosing where to have your base is very cool, but in reality there is little to no difference. There are lots of rooms you can put down, which is great, but I can find nothing to do apart from put all the rooms down and defend myself against the waves of baddies.Which leads us onto another problem: CombatIf I was to be nice, I would say that the combat was... flawed. The truth of the matter is that even when you assign people to security, and give them a place the have to defend, if they are talking or playing a game or eating etc, they will simply ignore you while the baddies are quite happily blowing the c*** out of your base.There are many bugs with game, including the priorities problem as outlined above. This was ok when the game was in development, but now that the developers seems to have abandoned it, there are too many for it to be considered a full game. That basically sums up my review. It had promise, but there is not enough actual game or polish for it to be considered a complete game. Save some money, go and buy Prison Architect or donate to/download Dwarf Fortress.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												This game could be so much fun but it needs rebalanced and tweaked a bit.  Raiders attack far too often and are too hard to kill before they decimate your base.  Then after one or two such raider attacks all of the citizens fall into a deep depression from having their friends killed that they go on a rampage and make a bad situation even worse.  When this happens the only solution is to abandon the game and start over again.I have tried building a decent base 7 or 8 times at varying locations in space and become equally frustrated each and every time.  I'm done playing this game unless a future update makes it more enjoyable.  Perhaps allow doctors to double as psychiatrists or something.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												Like so many have already said, this game was abandoned. They've simply polished the game to look appealing but the game play is downright unpleasant. It's very apparent that some of the decisions that were made in game play should have been better thought out. My advice to the creators: you should have looked to games like Evil Genius to get a better understanding of what's wrong.Some things that bothered me while playing: - no prioritization system in place for construction ( example: watching your workers finish building an empty room before constructing an oxygen recycler can be frustrating, especially when people start asphyxiating)- I watched a worker box themselves into a sealed room and then remove her suit. Instead of finishing the job and building a door to gain access to the base, she preffered to starve to death. In summary, unless you see any news about much more development in this game, don't bother. It's sad to see a game with such potential be abandonned like this.

content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												(I wanted to redo my review for a better viewpoint and whatnot. This review also comes from someone who played early access, and played post realease)I can say, that the concept for this game was great! A spacebase that half the time acts nicely, and runs like clockwork, then raiders show up and wreck s**t up. I was really excited when I heard this, and boughtit in early access. When I bought the game, I thought it was doing quite well for an early access game, and I enjoyed it!But, there were some signs that the game development was having problems. Updates, weeks and sometimes months apart. And these updates were adding barely anything to the game, and even bug fixing was quite slow. The AI, was and still is unbearable. And will do stupid things. The variety of things you can build in specific rooms is extremly limited.And, of course, this game was pushed out the door, being realeased way to early. An example, was that your station's power supply. That was not even a factor until the update before realease. Reasearch was the same story, the update before realease. And the tech tree is pretty much worthless in the game anyway. If you looked at the planned features for this game, they say that they were possible ideas, but some of the content they said were possible are needed in this kind of game!My last words on this are, Don't buy this piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥ in fact, don't buy any sort of thing from Double Fine, unless you can at least make sure that production will finish on the game fully2/10- Fun for an hour or two, but no storyline, not enought content, and lack of any new things happening after half an hour of gameplay, makes this game awful. Classic example of why you should buy early access games unless they are dirt cheap and you like the idea, or if you have a undying love in your heart for a concept that someone using early access is trying to make. Long story short- STAY AWAY!!!

content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Not worth the money.The game started nearly unplayable. The menu system is hard to use, the citizens would run to their own death, it was impossible to keep things repaired, and there was little to do except wait for the inevitable collapse. Too many people in a room? The oxygen drops low and they become unable to leave the room because the game doesn't distinguish pressure from oxygen. Some of the issues were fixed; most were not.Going in, I expected many more features by this point, and for development to continue for at least three years. The game simply did not deliver. Instead of fixing core design issues (like oxygen/pressure not being split, inability to respond to crises, and terrible AI), the developers just added on a few features (like asteroids, which quite simply make the game more annoying) and fixed the easy flaws (like technicians doing lots of damage, flying off to repair derelicts, and taking too long to train).

content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												While there are still many issues in Spacebase DF-9(such as bugs, outdated graphics, and so on), despite the years of production and work, I understand that this is still an incomplete product. Therefore I am not reviewing this game as a complete product, but rather I am reviewing its creative process. As a building management and construction simulator, Spacebase DF-9 fails the most important criterion in any simulation, uniqueness. Uniqueness is a core aspect in simulation games because it is there in which specialties and creativity come together to make an enjoyable and memorable simulation game. Examples of popular simulation games are Goat Simulator, The Sims, and Train Simulator, which all can be easily identified by each of their unique points. That being said, it is hard to find unique points in Spacebase DF-9. As I am writing this review, in trying to remember things that were unique I find myself fixated more on the bugs than actual gameplay. Overlooking the bugs, let me break down the gameplay. You build a base, gather resources, and make the base bigger and repeat. You have raiders that attack your base but they don’t present a threat if you properly maintain security. You have asteroid showers that happen every once in a while that start fires and destroy structures such as walls and they need to be patched up. You will get transmissions every once in a while so that people can move in, attack, or attach themselves to the base. The difficulty ramps up as your base becomes larger and more populated; you have to keep track of people’s morale, energy consumption, and security.  That is about it. As I have stated earlier, it lacks uniqueness. The simulation itself is very basic and there seems to be a large amount of creative work in creating the characters. Unfortunately, the programmers made the characters expandable, having them die very easily and having a lot of them makes the characters feel insignificant and therefore, their uniqueness insignificant. As a simulation, this game will not stand out in sales or reviews unless the creative department decides to do some major reworking. Furthermore if unchanged and published, this game will stand out as one of many examples of morale hazard in pre-release gaming.   Note: As I was about to post this I realized that this game was published a year ago. I could not fathom that a game this unpolished and lacking in content could be deemed complete by anyone who took pride in their work. In the end, it seems that DoubleFine just took everyone’s money and fled.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a potentially really good game. It does have the feeling of the old "Theme XYZ" games, and it has an overal oldschool feel, which is greatly appreciated.The graphics are neat, gameplay is potentially superb and endless, there even is some subtle, underlying humour which makes life in space more tolerable. The audio is also fairly standard, but fitting and nice.Unfortunately, at this early stage of development, the game is nigh unplayable. The AI is just, well, close to non-existant. "Events" are a tad too catastrophic and can easily lead to total failure (usually because AI doesn't do what it's supposed to, though). There is very little control over the space station's inhabitants' actions, there is no way to prioritize tasks. Occasional bugs will result in a lot of citizens dying for random reasons (eg, can't open a perfectly functioning door, or they won't come back from space when low on oxygen, and so on), whose corpses nobody will remove (again, AI failure). I'd say the AI  is what really needs some tweaking, right now.All in all, the game has a very nice backbone and quite some flesh, along with a few interesting quirks, but needs a lot (A LOT) of polishing yet. I recommend you try this game with this in mind.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												First let me say this: I have a very deep love for Dwarf Fortress. I absolutely adore that game so I have bought almost every dwarf fortressesque game on early access.However, this game: Spacebase DF-9 is not a good game. Why? Several reasons, but most relate to really bad controls. To build stuff or select or anything is really fiddily because it has a hard time registrating where the mouse is pointing on the grid - so you have a really hard game just controlling the damn game. Also the UI is hard to understand sometimes. The citizens all have their own individual "twitter feeds" where they write what the think of your space station, but the problem is that it's hard to understand exactly what their problems are. The game is also very unbalanced so it's hard to get a space base running and the nature of space means that it's important to make sure that you build correctly the first time. More so than in dwarf fortress where you can occasionally correct mistakes or convert rooms. Here your items often take more than 1 space on a grid so you'll find that its harder to convert rooms to other things. Also the rooms needs to be substantially bigger and you cannot put stuff like beds beside walls because they need all of the bed's adjacent squares to be free.EDIT: It has been a long time since the developers decided to abandon this project. I think I speak for all of us who bought this game when I say that we're all deeply disappointed in them. We all think it's a scam, and that it was not finished like it should have been. They never fixed the interface or the controlling problems. Stay away from this scam if  you  know what's good for you.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a potentially really good game. It does have the feeling of the old "Theme XYZ" games, and it has an overal oldschool feel, which is greatly appreciated.The graphics are neat, gameplay is potentially superb and endless, there even is some subtle, underlying humour which makes life in space more tolerable. The audio is also fairly standard, but fitting and nice.Unfortunately, at this early stage of development, the game is nigh unplayable. The AI is just, well, close to non-existant. "Events" are a tad too catastrophic and can easily lead to total failure (usually because AI doesn't do what it's supposed to, though). There is very little control over the space station's inhabitants' actions, there is no way to prioritize tasks. Occasional bugs will result in a lot of citizens dying for random reasons (eg, can't open a perfectly functioning door, or they won't come back from space when low on oxygen, and so on), whose corpses nobody will remove (again, AI failure). I'd say the AI  is what really needs some tweaking, right now.All in all, the game has a very nice backbone and quite some flesh, along with a few interesting quirks, but needs a lot (A LOT) of polishing yet. I recommend you try this game with this in mind.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Not worth the money.The game started nearly unplayable. The menu system is hard to use, the citizens would run to their own death, it was impossible to keep things repaired, and there was little to do except wait for the inevitable collapse. Too many people in a room? The oxygen drops low and they become unable to leave the room because the game doesn't distinguish pressure from oxygen. Some of the issues were fixed; most were not.Going in, I expected many more features by this point, and for development to continue for at least three years. The game simply did not deliver. Instead of fixing core design issues (like oxygen/pressure not being split, inability to respond to crises, and terrible AI), the developers just added on a few features (like asteroids, which quite simply make the game more annoying) and fixed the easy flaws (like technicians doing lots of damage, flying off to repair derelicts, and taking too long to train).

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
												I honestly thought other reviewers were being a little too harsh and demanding in their comments, and as a big fan of Double Fine, I thought I'd still enjoy this game. Boy was I wrong.It looks amazing, and the idea is fantastic! But the game IS indeed unfinished. It offers no goals that keep you excited about what's next, such as unlocking new rooms and items as you progress. There's no campaign, no mission, nothing. You get what you get at the start of the game (and it is ridiculously little), and that's that. After about 2-3 hours, you've gotten a taste of what the game is, but meanwhile, you've had to deal with tons of bugs, stupid AI characters that block themselves in whenever you try to build something, mechanics that won't fix your broken machines, fires that will forever burn even though they've been put out, sparks that fly everywhere even when you rebuild the broken doors... It's just really annoying.Such a shame. This game could have been amazing. It certainly looks the part!TL;DR- Not worth $20- Not even worth half that- Boring and incredibly lacking in content- Go play something else, like old school Theme Hospital for example... *sigh* I miss those days.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								I really want to like this game, because it seems to want to have so many elements that I like in games - however it is ultimately so frustrating and hard (not difficult) that I inevitably put it down after a short while.  One of the very basic problems is that the 'dangers' feel too contrived.  One starts playing and within a period of time there will be a 'space debris strike' aimed at your balls.  This doesn't feel like randomness, it feels like designers clutching at introducing adversity.  The other problem is that the AI in the game is suicidal at best.  While building structures they will seal themselves into rooms with no air, or no exits.  They will do stupid things such as ignore danger when someone is shooting at them while building or destroying structures.    Also and finally the game's biggest problem of all is that there is no 'border.'  Enemies enter anywhere on the base by attacking in the faux-3d of the game's world.  This means that there is no safe area, no main gate or wall.  The bigger your base gets, the more likely you are to suffer an attack or air leak where you can't contain it and you'll lose half of your crew to something utterly stupid.All in all, I keep starting the game but then I quit in disgust and frustration,  I see what they are trying to do, but it just feels very unsatisfying and annoying to me.  I'll try again later and report back with the new builds.
