number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												This game is not merely incomplete, not merely flawed, it is magnificently flawed. It is the crack in a marble statue which serves to accentuate the glorious beauty of the whole. It is "the flaw as art". The game it pretends to be, that of building and managing a space station, is a mere cover. What it really is, is a grand commentary on the futility of existence, a plucky crew doomed to be obliterated by the forces of a cruel and uncaring universe, inevitably descending into madness and all-consuming rage, smashing the very machinery that keeps them alive with their bloodied fists in inchoate rebellion against an ethereal tormenter. Your base, which showed such promise, such hope, a seed among the scattered stars, will inevitably become a corpse-choked space necropolis, asphyxiated space pirates drifting, mixed with your own crew's plague-riddled forms in a macabre embrace, a scene of terror and death ruled over by the killbots which inevitably turn up to breach the fragile hull that protects your base from the endless night.And that is just the tutorial level.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20
												Spacebase DF9 is a space management simulator where a small pod of astronauts set out to create a new space colony. You have to manage oxygen, food, jobs and the happiness of your intergalactic residents. As you progress, you will need to continue expanding to make space for new residents. The game had the potential to become an enjoyable simulator, but fell short in so many ways. PROS: The graphics are decent. The sound is fitting for the game. Most of the astronauts are not human, they are alien, making for more interesting looking characters. CONS: The game is very repetitive. After only an hour of gameplay, all the messages are the same, all your residents are saying the same things, everyone behaves the same etc. The game is severely lacking in variety. The A.I. is brutally stupid. Your colony can die because your mechanic is to depressed to fix the oxygen generators, killing everyone. There is quite a limited amount of things to build. Once you build each type of room, all you can do is keep making the same things as more astronauts arrive. No matter what, the gameplay is boring after the first hour or so. There is a lot of waiting, even when you speed things up. When you encounter problems, there is a fixed solution to deal with them. It gets even more boring and repetitive when you are forced to do the same steps continuously as the game progresses. It all comes down to is repetitiveness and a loss of interest. The game could be so much better if there were more scenarios and problems and multiple unique strategies to use. Unfortunately, this game is not worth the price when there are so many better alternatives available.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20
												Spacebase DF9 is a space management simulator where a small pod of astronauts set out to create a new space colony. You have to manage oxygen, food, jobs and the happiness of your intergalactic residents. As you progress, you will need to continue expanding to make space for new residents. The game had the potential to become an enjoyable simulator, but fell short in so many ways. PROS: The graphics are decent. The sound is fitting for the game. Most of the astronauts are not human, they are alien, making for more interesting looking characters. CONS: The game is very repetitive. After only an hour of gameplay, all the messages are the same, all your residents are saying the same things, everyone behaves the same etc. The game is severely lacking in variety. The A.I. is brutally stupid. Your colony can die because your mechanic is to depressed to fix the oxygen generators, killing everyone. There is quite a limited amount of things to build. Once you build each type of room, all you can do is keep making the same things as more astronauts arrive. No matter what, the gameplay is boring after the first hour or so. There is a lot of waiting, even when you speed things up. When you encounter problems, there is a fixed solution to deal with them. It gets even more boring and repetitive when you are forced to do the same steps continuously as the game progresses. It all comes down to is repetitiveness and a loss of interest. The game could be so much better if there were more scenarios and problems and multiple unique strategies to use. Unfortunately, this game is not worth the price when there are so many better alternatives available.

												Spacebase DF-9 was a really cool idea, pretty much summed up as "Dwarf Fortress in space! ...with at least a slightly more user-friendly UI." Unfortunately Spacebase DF-9 was also a really bad plan, pretty much summed up as "Hey those Prison Architect and Dwarf Fortress dudes have been making tons of money off their unfinished base building simulations while they're still in production! number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												This game is not merely incomplete, not merely flawed, it is magnificently flawed. It is the crack in a marble statue which serves to accentuate the glorious beauty of the whole. It is "the flaw as art". The game it pretends to be, that of building and managing a space station, is a mere cover. What it really is, is a grand commentary on the futility of existence, a plucky crew doomed to be obliterated by the forces of a cruel and uncaring universe, inevitably descending into madness and all-consuming rage, smashing the very machinery that keeps them alive with their bloodied fists in inchoate rebellion against an ethereal tormenter. Your base, which showed such promise, such hope, a seed among the scattered stars, will inevitably become a corpse-choked space necropolis, asphyxiated space pirates drifting, mixed with your own crew's plague-riddled forms in a macabre embrace, a scene of terror and death ruled over by the killbots which inevitably turn up to breach the fragile hull that protects your base from the endless night.And that is just the tutorial level.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												Spacebase does well enough for what it is - an alpha build rushed to release - but it lacks the strategic depth that a simulation needs in order to keep the player's interest. It doesn't even have enough pretty distractions to make up for the spartan gameplay. This is the kernel of a game that could have been great, but unfortunately that game will never be completed.On the plus side, Spacebase remarkably stable. I experienced no bugs, glitches, or crashes.A tip for those frustrated by raiders: build at least one turret in every room and leave them deactivated when not needed. When raiders attack, simply activate the necessary turrets and seal the doors. No muss, no fuss. Don't bother claiming derelicts; they are difficult to defend. Rather, explore them to acquire new crew members or loot and then let them disappear.In its current and final state, Spacebase is definitely not worth $20; I would not recommend this game at any price other than "free" (I got a complimentary copy with my Hack 'n' Slash purchase).

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								A great concept squandered by mismanagement. The game is buggy and has extremely shallow gameplay.I played the early prototype of this game that I got with HumbleBundle's Amnesia Fortnight bundle, I liked it the concept but it was clearly in very early stages. Sadly, what we have now is not very different, even though the graphics have been improved.DoubleFine was looking to cash in on games like Prison Architect. They even said as much themselves. They got investors involved (and successfully paid them off with the huge volume of Steam customers) and then when it wasn't as hot as they wanted, they cut development, did some more sales to lure in a few more suckers and then pulled the plug. In that order.Most of the people who hadn't bought it yet were waiting for beta or full release, but DoubleFine wanted to make all their money up front. Their business model for this title depended on it, and it is a flawed and presumptuous business model that screws over the consumer."Obviously, spending more money than we were making isn’t something we can afford to do forever." - Tim SchaferConsidering that in traditional gave development the developer puts in all the work up front, making the investment in themselves to deliver a great product. In this case, we, the consumer took all the risk. And they took none, while never intended to deliver a full game if it wasn't a pre-release hit with a cult following. Does this sound like a sane sustainable business plan to you? Well, if it does, then congratulations your name is Tim. And Tim, we can't afford to keep spending money on products that never materialize.I own Prison Architect and its a much more complete game, I recommend getting that instead. It lacks the character and personality of DF-9 and the setting and style is radically different, but its clear that they share the same underlying concept.

FucX Xhit!This game is totally waste of moneyIf U wanna know Y, comment, I'll plus review in English솔직히 2013년도 후반기정도에 계속 스팀 상점 특집탭에 메인으로 떠있어서 우와.... 우주정거장이라.... 잼겠네... 거기다 심즈같은 삘도있다고해서 샀는데 이런게임은 처음본다. 얼리엑세스 라고는 하지만 이게 뭐냐.프리즌 아키텍트 같은 건축물을 바라시는 분들은 차라리 스페이스 엔지니어를 사세요이게임이 왜 별로냐우주, 정거장, 개개인의 요구나 기분 같은것을 표현한것은 아주 좋은 아이디어임그러나메테오 스트라이크 쳐맞을때 혹은 누군가 누구를 폭행하거나 죽이고 있을때, 아니면 일좀하라고 시키고 싶을때, 전혀 컨트롤 할수 없음심즈와 우주 정거장의 결합이라는 말개소리다 리얼 우주 정거장만 있고 초반에 설명도 거지같다베이스 씨드로 부터 파워가 나온다 하지만 스테이션에 연결되어있지 않다.  연결되었나 확인하라 라는 메세지는 뜨지만 어떻게 연결을 해야하는지도 안알려준다. 내가 봤을때 베이스 씨드에 플로어 하나 깔고, 그 옆에 그냥 건물지으면 파워 공급된다. 일단 이런것도 안알려주고, 제일 거지 같은것은 컨트롤 ㅈ 병맛 아주 씹병맛심즈는 이 새퀴가 재미가 1퍼가 남았든 뭐든 명령을 할수 있다. 하지만 이겜은 아예 자율신경계다 우주비행사놈이 하고 싶을때 일하고 놀고싶을때 그냥 쳐 논다.그로인해 나오는 병맛1. 시큐리티로 듀티 지정해놓고 우주비행사끼리 싸울때 다른애랑 대화하던 중이어서 전혀 신경안쓴다2. 일 한번하고 '반드시' 놀아야함3. 메테오 스트라이크 맞아서 건축가 녀석보고 이 상태 안좋은 산소 발생기 띄고 다시 달아라 (다시 달면 상태 100퍼임) 라는 명령을 내림3-1. 떼어내긴 아주 기가막히게 떼어냄3-2. 14인이 살던곳에 15인 수용량의 산소발생기가 있었음 그중 하나를 떼서 12인의 산소분만 발생됨(개당 3인의 산소가 발생)3-3. 산소가 부족해지기 시작하고 사람들이 갑자기 모두 숨을곳을 찾고있음 상태가 됨3-4. 건축가 이 씹빨놈도 산소찾아 빙하타러 내려감(이 개새끼가 그냥 산소발생기 쌔거 달면 될걸 AI조또 개 병신이라 그냥 seeking for cover상태로 그냥 뛰어다니기만 함)3-5. 산소부족으로 다 뒤짐^오^컨트롤 안되서 ㅈ빡치는 건 이정도고 더 빡치는건1. Mining을 해야되는데 자원 20-35같이 Really High 인 지역이 아니면 자원 ㅈㄴ 없음 High여도 엄청 없음2. 위에 말한대로 컨트롤 안되는게 파워 공급도 따로 컨트롤이 안되는거라 리엑터 새거 달고 베이스 씨드 해체하면 파워공급안되서 질식사 할 때도 있음3. Airlock좀 병맛이라 seeking for cover상태일때 문그냥 열려서 우주로 빨려나가기도함4. 연구 오질나게 느려터짐5. 테크니션도 기계상태나 똑띠 볼것이지 애새끼들이랑 대화하느라고 기계 체크도 안함6. 아니 시발 대체 빌더 하기 싫다고 빨간얼굴에 인상 팍쓴새끼가 빌더 스킬 3개는 나보고 어쩌란거냐 뭐 우주에 신분이라도 생겼냐 평생 노예로 빌더만 하다와서 빌더 스킬은 만땅인데 빌더하기 싫은겨?7. 간혹가다가 해적들이 기지에 지네 함선 도킹하고 공격할때 있는데 해적 다 처리하고 이 함선을 vaporize나 teardown시키면 간혹 안에서 뻗튕기고 안나오는 시발놈들 있음 그러다가 도킹부분 먼저 해체하면 ㅈㄴ ㅈ같음8. 메테오가 아주 ㅈ ♥♥♥♥♥♥임 위에서 말한 자원없다고 한 부분이 문제인게 자원이 많은데는 메테오가 ㅈㄴ 자주옴 나 3연타 맞고 기계 병신되서 산소발생기 갈다가 위에꼴 난거임 근데 또 메테오 피할라고 High만 해도 우주 정거장(씨드가 중심임)에서 ㅈㄴ 먼곳에 아주 찔끔 자원있음9. 자원이 오질나게 쳐 비쌈10. 내가봐도 우주비행사가 머무르고 싶다는 메세지 거절문구가 ㅈㄴ 병맛임 오죽하면 거절당한애가 그정도로 과장할 필요없다 이 개새끼야 그냥 싫다고 해라 라고함(뭐라 하냐면 어.... 음... 미안한데 넌 지금 1357번째 입주 대기자야 이러고 있음)아주 ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ㅈ같은 개새끼 게임임 개발자가 대가리가 있으면 지금 알파6가 아니라 알파 13은 나와야지 최소한 프리즌 아키텍트가 괜히 ㅈㄴ 사랑받는줄 아냐 어? 페이데이2가 괜히 광빠가 생기는줄알아? 업뎃을 자주자주 해야될거 아니야 이 개♥♥♥♥♥♥ 호로새끼들아이 좆같은 리뷰읽어줘서 고맙다 한글로 된 리뷰 없어서 몇자 적는다

FucX Xhit!This game is totally waste of moneyIf U wanna know Y, comment, I'll plus review in English솔직히 2013년도 후반기정도에 계속 스팀 상점 특집탭에 메인으로 떠있어서 우와.... 우주정거장이라.... 잼겠네... 거기다 심즈같은 삘도있다고해서 샀는데 이런게임은 처음본다. 얼리엑세스 라고는 하지만 이게 뭐냐.프리즌 아키텍트 같은 건축물을 바라시는 분들은 차라리 스페이스 엔지니어를 사세요이게임이 왜 별로냐우주, 정거장, 개개인의 요구나 기분 같은것을 표현한것은 아주 좋은 아이디어임그러나메테오 스트라이크 쳐맞을때 혹은 누군가 누구를 폭행하거나 죽이고 있을때, 아니면 일좀하라고 시키고 싶을때, 전혀 컨트롤 할수 없음심즈와 우주 정거장의 결합이라는 말개소리다 리얼 우주 정거장만 있고 초반에 설명도 거지같다베이스 씨드로 부터 파워가 나온다 하지만 스테이션에 연결되어있지 않다.  연결되었나 확인하라 라는 메세지는 뜨지만 어떻게 연결을 해야하는지도 안알려준다. 내가 봤을때 베이스 씨드에 플로어 하나 깔고, 그 옆에 그냥 건물지으면 파워 공급된다. 일단 이런것도 안알려주고, 제일 거지 같은것은 컨트롤 ㅈ 병맛 아주 씹병맛심즈는 이 새퀴가 재미가 1퍼가 남았든 뭐든 명령을 할수 있다. 하지만 이겜은 아예 자율신경계다 우주비행사놈이 하고 싶을때 일하고 놀고싶을때 그냥 쳐 논다.그로인해 나오는 병맛1. 시큐리티로 듀티 지정해놓고 우주비행사끼리 싸울때 다른애랑 대화하던 중이어서 전혀 신경안쓴다2. 일 한번하고 '반드시' 놀아야함3. 메테오 스트라이크 맞아서 건축가 녀석보고 이 상태 안좋은 산소 발생기 띄고 다시 달아라 (다시 달면 상태 100퍼임) 라는 명령을 내림3-1. 떼어내긴 아주 기가막히게 떼어냄3-2. 14인이 살던곳에 15인 수용량의 산소발생기가 있었음 그중 하나를 떼서 12인의 산소분만 발생됨(개당 3인의 산소가 발생)3-3. 산소가 부족해지기 시작하고 사람들이 갑자기 모두 숨을곳을 찾고있음 상태가 됨3-4. 건축가 이 씹빨놈도 산소찾아 빙하타러 내려감(이 개새끼가 그냥 산소발생기 쌔거 달면 될걸 AI조또 개 병신이라 그냥 seeking for cover상태로 그냥 뛰어다니기만 함)3-5. 산소부족으로 다 뒤짐^오^컨트롤 안되서 ㅈ빡치는 건 이정도고 더 빡치는건1. Mining을 해야되는데 자원 20-35같이 Really High 인 지역이 아니면 자원 ㅈㄴ 없음 High여도 엄청 없음2. 위에 말한대로 컨트롤 안되는게 파워 공급도 따로 컨트롤이 안되는거라 리엑터 새거 달고 베이스 씨드 해체하면 파워공급안되서 질식사 할 때도 있음3. Airlock좀 병맛이라 seeking for cover상태일때 문그냥 열려서 우주로 빨려나가기도함4. 연구 오질나게 느려터짐5. 테크니션도 기계상태나 똑띠 볼것이지 애새끼들이랑 대화하느라고 기계 체크도 안함6. 아니 시발 대체 빌더 하기 싫다고 빨간얼굴에 인상 팍쓴새끼가 빌더 스킬 3개는 나보고 어쩌란거냐 뭐 우주에 신분이라도 생겼냐 평생 노예로 빌더만 하다와서 빌더 스킬은 만땅인데 빌더하기 싫은겨?7. 간혹가다가 해적들이 기지에 지네 함선 도킹하고 공격할때 있는데 해적 다 처리하고 이 함선을 vaporize나 teardown시키면 간혹 안에서 뻗튕기고 안나오는 시발놈들 있음 그러다가 도킹부분 먼저 해체하면 ㅈㄴ ㅈ같음8. 메테오가 아주 ㅈ ♥♥♥♥♥♥임 위에서 말한 자원없다고 한 부분이 문제인게 자원이 많은데는 메테오가 ㅈㄴ 자주옴 나 3연타 맞고 기계 병신되서 산소발생기 갈다가 위에꼴 난거임 근데 또 메테오 피할라고 High만 해도 우주 정거장(씨드가 중심임)에서 ㅈㄴ 먼곳에 아주 찔끔 자원있음9. 자원이 오질나게 쳐 비쌈10. 내가봐도 우주비행사가 머무르고 싶다는 메세지 거절문구가 ㅈㄴ 병맛임 오죽하면 거절당한애가 그정도로 과장할 필요없다 이 개새끼야 그냥 싫다고 해라 라고함(뭐라 하냐면 어.... 음... 미안한데 넌 지금 1357번째 입주 대기자야 이러고 있음)아주 ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ㅈ같은 개새끼 게임임 개발자가 대가리가 있으면 지금 알파6가 아니라 알파 13은 나와야지 최소한 프리즌 아키텍트가 괜히 ㅈㄴ 사랑받는줄 아냐 어? 페이데이2가 괜히 광빠가 생기는줄알아? 업뎃을 자주자주 해야될거 아니야 이 개♥♥♥♥♥♥ 호로새끼들아이 좆같은 리뷰읽어줘서 고맙다 한글로 된 리뷰 없어서 몇자 적는다

Early Access Review
								Spacebase DF-9 is a fun interesting concept of a game, but unfortinitly that's all it will ever be. While what is in the game is fun the game is far from being a full game and will be released as such relying on modders to finish the game.  If this barely more then a prototype costed more around the $5-10 range then I would say its definitly worth picking up for that price even though it will never be a full game, but at a $25 price point I can not reccomend this game. Hopefully Doublefine doesn't keep with the trend they are on right now between this game being abandoned and who knows how long it will be untill the second half of Broken Age. Hack 'N Slash was pretty good, but I don't want to see Massive Chalice fall to the abandoned development that Doublefine seems to be doing because Massive Chalice looks like a interesting concept of mixing the reboot of XCom with having your soldiers inheirt good and bad traits (possibly just one side or the other depending on hidden dice rolls) from previous soldiers you retire.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is an example of how bad the Early Access model can be. The plan of the developer, Double Fine, was to fund the development from the start with the sales of the (prototype of the) game, reduce drastically their initial investment, and hope that their good name and promises on how they imagined the final game were enough to attract customers. The 'experiment' failed completely because most people interested in the game were holding their purchase to see how the developers were updating the game. It became a self-fulfilling prophecy of failure, in which due to the lack of sales the developers were not able to assign more efforts to the game and, at the same time, exactly that slow development was the reason behind the low amount of sales.To come to an end to this grotesque scenario, Double Fine decided to stop the development and release the game as it is currently. The game is still in its bare bones and the experience is lacking in many areas, but they will create a tutorial, tools to create mods, and hope for a nonexistent community to continue its development.About me: I've been a big fan of Double Fine games during the last years. I loved Psychonauts and Monkey Island, funded the Kickstarter of Broken Age and enjoyed other games like Costume Quest, Stacking or The Cave. This is the first dissapointment. It has destroyed the trust that I had in DF and, in the future, I will behave with them as if they are an unknown dev without credentials. I will investigate with caution about their games before buying or I will simply ignore them. Also, I won't buy any Early Access games and advice others to do the same.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												I bought this game via greenlight thinking the developers were committed to providing the vision for the game. They stated themselves on their forum before Alpha 6."Double Fine is not a random fly-by-night indie dev and we are not going to silently pull the plug on Spacebase or any other in-development project. Doing so would be disastrous for our reputation and it would kill us emotionally" by JP LeBreton @ Double Fine.Oh wait what has happened going from Alpha 6 to 1.0 Release without a Beta. It looks like the developers didnt realise greenlight didnt mean everyone would buy it pre-release and seemingly they have ran out of money. They are to release 1.0 soon so wait at least until that so you can find out what has actually made it into the game.It is a shame because this was looking like a very good little game, but now its to be left to modders to finish. As I don't really have time to search for mods as I kind of play games quickly between jobs, this looks like I'll have to write-off this game as a loss.See TotalBiscuits critique on the matter below.

												I really want to like this game, despite it's flaws (it's ceased dev, pre-alpha). However the end game is always the same... even if you manage to survive the constant onslaught of raiders, and space diseases, bodies persist long after death... and corpses have a detrimental affect on crew morale which can prevent crew from wanting to enter areas where these bodies are (which can prevent maintenance and production), or crew end up rioting among themselves. It's a massive shame because it had a lot of potential. If the community gets behind this game and manage to produce mods to fix major issues, then I'd recommend it, but as it stands atm it's only worth a punt if it's going cheap.

												This game had so much potential. Go ahead and watch Scott Manly play this game on youtube. It was early access and it was shaping up to be a pretty decent Dwarf Fortress style game, but in space. Progress was made, bugs were clipped, and features added on a fairly regular basis, it had every indication that it was an early access game being developed in good faith for your investment. For whatever reason it got frozen, and released, unfinished, warts and all for the world. That's why you see so many negative reviews. This game isn't done, it makes no pretensions to being done, don't buy it unless you are fully aware what it is you are getting, and you don't have any lighters around to burn 10 bucks.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												Game showed such promise. I enjoyed what the game was shaping up to be. Loved the premise and enjoyed it and watching it grow.Unfortunately, the game is now ABANDONWARE. I do not recommend purchasing this game unless you can accept the game in an unfinished 40% state the game is in. It is fun, but there is little content, the AI is crap, and will wear out on it fast due to odd bugs and little content.While I do understand when games have to be abandoned, with the new Early Access system, this is one many people got burned, and burned bad with. What was supposed to occur with the game, and what actually happened, were narrow. They released the game from Early Access and called that that. Did a few fast patches to shut people up about the big items and continued on their way. The dollar signs weren't big in front of Doublefine's eyes apparently, and took what they had and ran. I wish Steam would have forced their hands in this situation, but didn't, and Doublefine continues along its way like nothing happened.I'm even more disappointed with Doublefine that they put it on sale right before they terminated development (And I can't imagine them NOT knowing they were going to can it a couple weeks before they did) and continue to sell it with no disclaimer anywhere on the Steam page that it is abandonware and no longer being worked on, AND have also put it for sale as if it's still being acknowledged.I will not purchase another Doublefine title (or anyone who is part of their team if they move on again) in prerelease, and I am GREATLY nervous about buying a title from them ever again.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								At the moment, don't buy the game. That doesn't mean don't pay attention to it, just don't put your money into it at this juncture.  The AI pathing is questionable at best (space requirments for individuals to navigate around larger items within the base is different considering the dimensions available). AI would rather sleep then do a job you have assigned them to; AI get's stuck within a structure with no doors or other forms of escape after you ask them to build it. Way too many individuals ask to your base than you are obviously ready for (I had over 10 within the first 15-20 minutes in one play attempt). The mechanics are fantastic. I will personaly be continuing to attempt playing this game, but can't recommend it to others that haven't already paid for the alpha.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Spacebase DF-9 looked quite interesting, from the Dwarf Fortress-esque room management to the quirky characters and random event system.  Unfortunately, it hasn't had a significant content upgrade since I initially saw it months ago on an Evening with Sips episode or short series.  What is in this game is a wide gamut of bugs combined with sheer stupidity when it comes to the AI, arguably the most important part of the game, and they screwed it up.Not being able to build rooms, place objects, or cancel construction orders without having to move the camera around until the game sees fit to finally let your commands go through was the most common bug, and it persisted in being terrible from the moment I tried to start building a base to my eventual giving up on the game.  Random events seem to pull from a pool of maybe 5 different things, the most frequent of which was a ship encounter that featured a squeal along the lines of "EEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE!!!!! WE FINALLY FOUND YOU!!!!!!!!  WE'RE COMING ABOARD THIS INSTANT!" to which no matter whether you select to allow them on or not, you are forced to take on additional crew members, all of which will be more of a liability than a help due to their universally crap skills.  This will culminate in your base having to constantly expand its oxygen suppliers and eventually even building a second reactor, just to provide for these new idiots while avoiding losing your valuable crew members to oxygen deprivation as the wastes of space use it all up.Oh, and if you want to expand your oxygen room to make space for more recyclers, or any room in fact, make sure you set the entire station to become builders.  Because when you have four builders dismantle a wall, immediately head back into the base to go to sleep, and refuse to build the floor in place of the wall you just tore down, your entire base will asphyxiate and your builders will sleep themselves to death, dooming the entire station.  Absolute rubbish prioritizing and programming.Do not buy this game.  Do not buy Early Access games.  Early Access games are a plague on Steam and should not be allowed a store page or a sale until they have a finished product.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								I remember first encountering this game during Amnesia Fortnight 2012, Double Fine's crowdfunded event in which they put out a series of rapid prototypes to test out a bunch of different game ideas.I'm going to bottom line this for you: the game hasn't evolved significantly beyond what was originally shown off as a rapid development prototype nearly two years ago. Updates are slow and add to the backend with new features that increase complexity, but don't actually add content or meaningful gameplay in any way. Worse, the developers have completely removed the "Future development plans" backlog from their website with no explanation. This is to say nothing of the numerous game breaking bugs and brick-dumb AI which have survived for release after release.And yet I could deal with all of that if the game were fun to play... but it's not. Games like its inspiration, Dwarf Fortress, are fun because of their emergent gameplay - the stories and situations which unfold around you are completely unique to each playthrough, creating a different experience every time you play. This frankly isn't true in DF-9, at least in its current state. Fire up the game and start on a random map and you'll have built and encountered everything there is to see in around an hour; there's no point in starting a new game since the same story unfolds every time.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								Don't buy this game. It is a broken promise and incomplete.You guys (DOUBLEFINE) say you are not-fly-by-nighters; just last update you said you’d keep us in the loop going forward because there was silence for the weeks prior....then you pull the plug completely?The game is nowhere near finished - it’s potential is untapped. Those of us who bought into early access to support the vision and take part in the development of something special have now had the rug pulled out from under us as you guys cut and run.I can see this happening with any number of development studios but I would never have thought DoubleFine would join the list. Now I’ve seen it all.Have you considered the impact this will have on gamer confidence? On trust? What sort of message do you think it sends that you effectively say ‘that’s it guys we’re out - you finish the game yourselves!’The whole Amnesia Fortnight process is undermined - nobody will care now because they will know that whatever is chosen may or may not be finished. The veracity of the process, the thrill of the journey and the move to a final product… none of it matters when you don’t deliver.Disappointed doesn’t begin to describe it. I never post on these forums - but I had to come and say my piece in this instance. And while the mods may desperately fly to your defense - we all know on this one… your conduct is indefensible.I expected more from DF, from Mr Schafer.Suffice to say - you’ve lost a fan; and probably a customer. But it’s the former that hurts the most.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								I can't recommend this game.It has a lot of potential and I'd really love to see it done. I also really like the ideas the devs have.BUT and that is a huge but...... I purchased this game like a trillion years ago and hoped for updates. But there are just minor ones like nothing happened.I feel a bit ripped off, because in the state it is, it is not really playable. The AI is just dumb as hell and it gets really frustrating (the citizens are like lemmings).And after a short time you have done everything there is to do. I'd say after a 100 minutes you have seen everything and it gets to the point where you are just tweaking your base or you are eager to fight the trials caused by bugs. I really tried to befriend with this game the way it is but it just gets worse, because the unfinished state and slow development starts to aggravate me more and more.Also there are a lot of known bugs, but they fix them really late or never. Who knows? The devs prefer to remain silent about nearly everything. I just read something about “We’re nearing our goals and the complete state of the game is not far away”, so I decided to write this and warn everyone about this. The way it is, this game could be a free to play iPad thing. I'd pay about 4-7$ for this max, given that I wouldn't know what I know now.For all the people, who think I'm just being pessimistic:Look at their Website, or the updates here at Steam. It seems like they are releasing updates labeled as huge success, which are little more than some minor bug-fixes (or sometimes a bunch of new ones adding to the old ones).  And you can't know whats to come, because the devs decided to delete the "Future developement plans"-website, which is a huge issue for me and just another indicator, that this game is dead and light years from being finished.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												This game has a lot of promise as a building / management / simulator for space stations but right now it's more of a tech demo. I will definitely take another look once it gets further along in its development cycle but as of right now it doesn't have much that you can really do in it yet.It has various props that could do something in the future (like a reactor) but currently the only real bit of management you have to do is mining and a little building (plus the occassional raider). You can't fortify your defenses really nor can you customize the space station as much as I would expect from a building management game. I'd pass on this game until it gets more content and substance.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												Saw all the negative press for the game, so I waited until it was less than $5. Wow it is really sad to see how AMAZING this could have been with, like, an extra year of indie development. Or, hell, maybe even just a few months more.The art is great and the mechanics work fine. It's hard at first, but then you get your base starting to work, some hydroponics, a nice little bar, and your colonists go from mildly sad to somewhat happy.*Then* what?They added in these achievements but they don't feel worth the effort. The colonists have tons of traits and thoughts and everything, but ... What do they amount to? Why should I care? They don't really affect anything other than how pissy they get over time.Raiders stomped my first base, but then I realized I just need a turret minding the entrance, and boom, problem almost entirely solved.There are so few objects, with so little placing options, you can't even really decorate it. The colonists don't even mop up blood from fights that break out.I understand now why everyone was so disappointed. I just don't understand why they would make such a fantastic foundation, if they weren't gonna build on it.I give it 4 sad faces out of 4. Couldn't even keep me mildly amused for more than a few hours (the rest was added on when I paused it to get up and go AFK for a bit).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												This quote is from someone called Rhadamant posted on steam forums before Spacebase was announced "finished". I complete agree with what he has said. This thread is no longer available.Title: "Clearly Vaporware"Originally posted by Rhadamant:"A person on the spacebase df-9 forums asked if this game was abandoned back on August 17th. It took over two days for a person NOT on the spacebase DF-9 team to even notice the post and say'Hey - heck yeah Spacebase is still in development! I'm not on the team, but JP and co are working hard on the next update and I think you'll hear more about it soon.'Clearly this game is vapourware, another developer abusing the early access system. Go spend your money on another indie game, that has proper monthly updates. Even if they release an update, it'll be four months since the last one. Prison Architect and RimWorld and a dozen other proper indie games have got monthly updates of ACTUAL content, not the tiny micro-updates of Spacebase where gameplay is not affected at all."

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2015
												Ugh. All Spacebase needed was time, and that's exactly what ran out. This is a great concept for a game. Build and manage a space outpost with a focus on resource & personnel management and design. It has a great, fun art style, and a cheeky sense of humor. It's also abandoned, unfinished, and now, unloved. Double Fine mismanaged this project from the start, and the result is a "game" that has no goal, no progression, and few failure conditions. A "simulation" where there is little beyond the most basic needs management that can be solved in a few minutes, with no further complexity or depth to ever grow. A "product" that's buggier than The Temple of Doom. If you're really curious to look at what happens when a game project gets aborted but somehow thrown at the public, stillborn, then pick this game up and watch as the first few promising minutes of fun fade into unoptimized monotony. If not, stay away and check out either Cosmonautica for a similar "Silly Space" atmosphere, or Startopia for a better Spaceport management simulation.

												I backed this game when it was still in development.  I was really looking forward to a diet-dwarf-fortess-in-space type experience. content:
Posted: December 16, 2016
												I have mix feelings with this game, i really enjoy it, i've spend a lot of time playing it, and I feel that if the devolperers have not abandoned it could turn out to be the best space base management sim ever.... it's too sad it's basically abandonware.Imagine theme hospital, one of my favorite games as a child, but in a space setting.... you build the base, gather resources from asteroids, set defenses against space pirates.... it's so fun in so many ways. BUT.... Keep in mind before buying this game, that this is an alpha.... a really good alpha, but the game is never going to be finished, so actually there's no campain missions, no goals, no achievements, and lot of features not in game, the random "encounters" get repetitive after a while....  in the end you'll end with a big well armed base, and nothing to do but let the time fastfoward till the next "event" .... it makes me angry cause the core of the gameplay it's wonderful.yes there's a "user-made" update, that fix some things, adds a thing or two (like the happy bot) and also adds bugs (example.. update adds the squad mode for your security personel, cool.... game crashed if you disband a squad, not cool), in the end,  still feels like an alpha, so if you think that the user made path will make the game complete... it's not gonna happen. So be wary.That´s really sad because what is done here...  it's done in a beautiful way, so much potential wasted...And that´s the risk and problem with Double Fine, on one hand they make wonderful out-of-the-box ideas, games with a lot of charm, funny, different from anything else on the market ... on the other.... they have failed the customer more than once before (Broken Age anyone?)Ill update this review if the User-made path is updated and the game gets better.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 29, 2015
												I think what hurts the most about this game is the completely wasted potential. When updates were actively coming out it seemed pretty realistic to expect a very well made if modest game. The art assets were there, what had been worked on and put in the game was of a reasonably high quality with some later updates excepted, the sound seemed like time and effort went into making it fit the tone of the overall game. Somewhere, this all fell through at the last minute.I know Double Fine has to find a way to pay the bills, so cutting the project to work on something more lucrative is the smart thing to do for them. Leaving it on the store and calling it 'finished' to try and squeeze it for cash is simply ridiculous though. They could have easily left it in early access and said something along the lines of "We need to work on some other games to generate revenue. We'll leave the game on Early Access and when we've made enough money on additional early supporters we'll continue development." and I wouldn't have batted an eyelash. There's a pretty distinct line between putting a hold on development and blatantly releasing a mess as a finished product in a crass attempt to get more money.I'm not mad that you ran out of money. I'm not mad the game is unfinished. I'm mad that you're taking advantage of your audience and lying to them.

								This game is so far from being anything that I don't understand why they're selling it. It's everything wrong with early access. There are numerous game-breaking bugs and bad ai behaviors that don't seem to be getting fixed, and a number of systems that might do something on day (power generation, happiness, etc), but are useless at the moment. Given how long it's been out, and the ammount of development actually happening, this one's probaly just a cash-grab by the developers.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 29, 2015
												I think what hurts the most about this game is the completely wasted potential. When updates were actively coming out it seemed pretty realistic to expect a very well made if modest game. The art assets were there, what had been worked on and put in the game was of a reasonably high quality with some later updates excepted, the sound seemed like time and effort went into making it fit the tone of the overall game. Somewhere, this all fell through at the last minute.I know Double Fine has to find a way to pay the bills, so cutting the project to work on something more lucrative is the smart thing to do for them. Leaving it on the store and calling it 'finished' to try and squeeze it for cash is simply ridiculous though. They could have easily left it in early access and said something along the lines of "We need to work on some other games to generate revenue. We'll leave the game on Early Access and when we've made enough money on additional early supporters we'll continue development." and I wouldn't have batted an eyelash. There's a pretty distinct line between putting a hold on development and blatantly releasing a mess as a finished product in a crass attempt to get more money.I'm not mad that you ran out of money. I'm not mad the game is unfinished. I'm mad that you're taking advantage of your audience and lying to them.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
												In an hour and a half of play I have encountered most everything the game has to offer, as well as 3 major bugs (disappearing tiles, bugged builder AI refusing tasks, and bugged security AI which finally lost me my station). This game was promised to include many basic features of a management game that were never implemented and will never be implemented. All that is left is a very subpar blend of basic features mixed with a hint of bugs that leaves a final product that tastes poor and unfinished. Were it 5 dollars and still being worked on I would heartily recommend it as with bugfixing and some addition of actual content it would be a very playable game. However, at the moment there is little to be said for it. Additionally, and separate from the review of actual gameplay, I have to express disappointment in Double Fine for letting down their customers like this. I do not support companies that do not live up to their promises and that follow unethical practices like covering up negative reviews, and as such I would like to urge anyone else who does not wish to support these practices to avoid buying this game and to look more closely at Double Fine products in the future.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								I purchased this game during a steam sale on september 3 for 50% off early access.I had been following the progress for a while, and was hoping for a more finished product, but when I watched the Alpha 6 video from Double Fine, it looked like this update finally added some more content and there were also certain assurances from JP, the lead developer, that they would strive for better communication in regards to content and issues in the future. I decided to pay up and try it out. Well, it was still very broken. Aside from the known bugs that weren't resolved, the new "mood system" introduced some hugely game breaking bugs and it was hard to progress very far at all in the game without having to restart for one reason or another.I frustratingly put the game down for the weekend, and only played it a few more times until they ironed out some of the more severe mood bugs by 6e-f. Once those game breakers were (pretty much) out of the way, I was able to successfully establish a base and build it to fair size before wondering the inevitable.. "okay, now what?" of an unfinished sandbox game. The derelict ships provide a little interest, but can sometimes be a pain to deal with. The breaches could be a very fun aspect of the game, but instead balance issues make them either ridiculously easy, or painfully hard with no real explanation as to why one way or another.This lead me to decide (as I have done with other Early Access titles) to "put the game down" for a bit, and come back later when they have added some more content to make the game more interesting and challenging to play. It is now two weeks later, and the lead developer has stated that they will be finalizing this game and releasing 1.0 in a month.This is a woefully unfinished game that is severely lacking in content. While the idea and core features seem real enticing, the truth is there really isn't much at all to do and I dont see the developer adding that much more before actual release.If you would like a "space base" type game, I would suggest an alternative in Startopia. Yes, it's almost 15 years old, but its funny and entertaining and actually has goals and stuff to do. I guarantee you will get much better gaming enjoyment out of Startopia than this unfinished, yet released product.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								I read about the game getting canceled. Saw some youtube videos and game looked awesome. Reminded me of theme hospital a bit. It looks fun even with just its existing feature set. Unfortunetly it is super buggy almost to the point of being unplayable. Builders lock themselves in rooms. Cannot place a door until room is built.In one game got raided every 10 mininutes or so, astroids the same. It's not really fun after first 5 attacks, just annoying. I picked average for density and like almost low for (dont remember wording) for raiders. Tells me I dont have any doctors when I do have a doctor assigned. Tells me I dont have a tech when I have one assigned.A pirate ship "docked" with me. I could not get inside the ship no matter what I did. I endeded up having my builders tear down half way.  The game crapped out on me before I could finish the rest.I "pacified" a raider instead of killing him. I dont have a brig yet. He is now sitting in the hall way just staring at everyone. Everyone and a while I get an alert saying I am being raided. After this happened everyone started doing stuff even slower than before so I had to restart :(People spend lots of time doing nothing. Right now I have 6 out of 9 people doing excerises and chatting in hallway. When I need something done in a hurry I just assign everyone. Like when a dude is about to starve because of being locked in a room. In the you tube videos people were joining left and right. I just have 7 people and no new people are coming :( I picked near to space gate or whatever when starting. Cannot scroll when constructing... This really sucks, literally need to cancel to close construction, scroll, and then start all over :(The starting area selector thing is no good. Why cant it just be like minecraft where you can just pick easy, hard, flat, etc. Its adds no value whatsover having that picker thing with the map. Just annoying each time you restart and want to experiment with different world type.The description of magnetic interfernce is caught off, cannot scroll, and I have no idea what it means in the game.	Wanted to change roll of hallway. Building first generator, room was tool small, knocked down wall, built generator and built new wall that extended one block into hallway. Hallway become "reactor room". Tried to click on and change, instead clicked on unclaim by accident. Couldnt reclaim after that, lost all power and had to restart.Builders get stuck in rooms behind objects. Need to knock down the wall to free them.Twice at start of game, I finished my base with working airlock and life support but not everyone comes inside. They die outside.A weird green line tripod/triangle thing appeared in the middle of base. Save/quit and restart and it went away.In one game the refiner didnt work? The tech came around and repaired it but miners just came, stood next to it, and then threw there rocks on the ground :( Had to tear down and rebuild.Twice this has happened, a reactor I built just disappeared. I placed in construction tool and confirmed. Didnt pay attention to see what happened.It would be nice to have more than one save? Especially with a super buggy game like this.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								So like many other people I had great hopes for what this game would become in the next year or so.  I bought it late in the year 2013, maybe a month after it was available through early access. Initially the game was fun even though it was still broken in many ways.  However I'd just play a game once every month or so to see what they had added or fixed since my last run. I played around the middle of last month for the last time. When I played they had added a total of three new room types into the game since the barebones they had at launch. These rooms were excercise, science and medical. Excercise like it sounds was a gym, but it only has one single item you can place in it, a very boring gym machine, literally nothing else can go in there that actually helps your people excercise.Science was pretty much the same. One big machine that is all you need, and some research projects that are very few in choice, and really don't add anything new to the game once completed.And finally nmedical. Exact same deal, one structure can be built and only one, and its effect is negligible at best.Long story short is this game barely had a years worth of development put into it, and is being released for a tag of $25 !?!?If your thinking about buying a dwarf fortress type game with better UI get Banished or Gnomoria, or even deal with DF's crazy style, but DO NOT BUY THIS GAME! Doing so supports a studio that should know better than to treat customer like this. I learned to never buy an early access title from Double Fine, please don't make the same mistake.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								So like many other people I had great hopes for what this game would become in the next year or so.  I bought it late in the year 2013, maybe a month after it was available through early access. Initially the game was fun even though it was still broken in many ways.  However I'd just play a game once every month or so to see what they had added or fixed since my last run. I played around the middle of last month for the last time. When I played they had added a total of three new room types into the game since the barebones they had at launch. These rooms were excercise, science and medical. Excercise like it sounds was a gym, but it only has one single item you can place in it, a very boring gym machine, literally nothing else can go in there that actually helps your people excercise.Science was pretty much the same. One big machine that is all you need, and some research projects that are very few in choice, and really don't add anything new to the game once completed.And finally nmedical. Exact same deal, one structure can be built and only one, and its effect is negligible at best.Long story short is this game barely had a years worth of development put into it, and is being released for a tag of $25 !?!?If your thinking about buying a dwarf fortress type game with better UI get Banished or Gnomoria, or even deal with DF's crazy style, but DO NOT BUY THIS GAME! Doing so supports a studio that should know better than to treat customer like this. I learned to never buy an early access title from Double Fine, please don't make the same mistake.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've given this game a lot of time and it has the potential to be a lot of fun. It sufferes from some very serious flaws however. There is no real tutorial or guide. I had to go to the Wiki to figure out how to really get started. Part of this is not really knowing what to do and part is many of the things the game asks you to do are hidden about 4 menu layers down without telling you WHICH menu trees they are down. Once you know the trees, they make some sense but it is puzzling for new players.The menu options need A LOT of work. It is not easy to understand what you need to do or how to do it. After you suffer through a few bad games of learning how to build an airlock, life support and the associated gear it starts to become fun.  Having the bulk of what you need to do hidden under several menu levels makes the trree feel lop sided. If I wasn't building a floor or wall, I was forever going down additional menus. Once you get past the start, it gets fun. Until you get a larger crew. Even if you give everyone the job they love to do, build all the comfort items and have everything you possibly can, your crew still gets depressed and sad. The crew want to be assigned their own beds but keeping track of who has what bed for 60+ people is not easy. Add to that the new people who come in and the people who die to raiders (or suicide in space) and you never know who needs what. The interface is increadibly clunky in this aspect. There is no way to direct anyone other than security and even then sometimes they just don't respond to a beacon. Critical structures that need building will often be overlooked for unimportant ones, equipment will remian broken while an army of technicians ignore them to chat with each other in the bar. This means the simultaneous building of objects is either best avoided (to direct workers to where you want them) or thrown to chance if something important needs to be done. Maintainence is best done by changin all technicians to builders and then reclaiming (destroying) degrading equipment and rebuilding it. When raiders approach, there is no way to direct non-security personnel away from an area. To be able to direct a worker to a specific task is such a basic tool it is amazing it has been overlooked.There are some notifications (information) that should be alerts (clickable). What good is it warning me that I have an airlock somewhere I haven't built something in if you won't take me to it? This leaves you hunting down building errors, that may not be your fault, when it should be a simple click and fix. The AI is very stupid at times. Workers will starve to death while standing in front of a food dispensor. Builders will build themselves into a room and then suffocate because they can't get out. You can't even pull them out before they finish because you can't direct them. There is no screen rotation. Sometimes you will get missing floor tiles hidden behind walls. They may have been missed in construction, they may have come about from damage (fire, space debris). You can drop the walls most of the way but sometimes they can still hide. Being able to rotate the map would help this significantly. For something that borrows so much from RTS games, it is a game that fails to learn from lessons RTS games had to learn as they matured. As a result you get a game that could be (and at times is) increadibly fun but is severly hindered by its lack of basic features.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								While it appeared promising on launch to the Early Access register, already having the framework for a novel and engaging space-station based administration/colony game, this Early Access title is now one of many that have failed to achieve even a half of their potential, and is instead being rushed into 'full' release and obscurity.The game's feature list has been aggresively pruned, and while the ones which remain there are not outright fabrications, they are misleading as to the scope and function the current game has. I'd advise caution towards any of DoubleFine's releases in future, as the end product may be subject to extreme and massive change, or be unduly delayed as development drags on and stagnates in favour of more profitable ventures.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												Spacebase DF-9 is one of the 2 games that taught me to never again invest in either an Early Access of Kickstarter video game. The other was Peter Molyneux's Godus. I had a lot of faith in Double Fine's ability to produce this game, and after a long period of slow progress and bland features, Spacebase DF-9 has died in development. It's not an uncommon occurnace in the video game industry for a project to fail while in development and most of the time we players never see this happen. The lesson Spacebase DF-9 teaches us is that early access/kickstarter games are not exceptions and are not sacrosanct. If you're foolish enough to give them your money for something that does not exist yet while they are not contractually bound to provide you with a product then you deserve to loose your money.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 7, 2016
												I bought this game so long ago. It looked promising, giving us barebone functions to make sure we can grasp how the game works, and how stupid the colonists are. I was definitely hoping the game would be published to its fullest potential because, despites its numerous bugs and AI mishaps, it was a fun ride.But then Double-Fine decided to say "F--- You" to everyone and stopped working on it.So, basically, here is what you have, in clever bulletpoints:-Buggy AI akin to the Sims without the instinct for survival. Your colonists could very well die of asphyxiation if you forget to stop them from doing whatever they were doing-a faction-based territory system that barely works, where you could very well f--- up the enemy base if you just dismantle a wall or a door while they attempt to invade you. This causes strange bugs all around.-Limited space and resources, you mostly end up relying on the so-called enemy invasions to dismantle their clutter so you can have anything, at a later point in the game.It's an interesting micromanagement survival game, and a challenging one at that, but it became so buggy and out of control that I couldn't see myself play any longer each session. Plus it seems Double Fine deemed this game a dud, and stopped working on it. Wrong move, guys. Finish your games before calling it quits.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												Lets begin.I can not rate this game on steam by using start 1-5 but if I could, I would give it 3 stars. I give this game 3 stars because it is very glitchy but also can be an adicting game for a short period of time. If you are looking for a game to pass your time for a few hours and never play again (becuase there are so many bugs), this is your game.One of the biggest problems that I think exist right now is: after about an hour of playing, raider start spanning 1 after another (even if the threat level is at low). Another problem similar to this is that debri begin showing up all the time.Also this game is frusturating because your builders and tech either never listen or do there jobs but not where you want them to it. For example, you may have many "oxygen recyclers" but the one that is about to burst to flames is ignored by your tech and he goes to the "oxygen recyler" that is in good condition.Additional problems may be that when a derlict appears, all your people go there and then will begin to ignore all your commands (except security and miners)After writing this review I now think that I would rate this game as 2 stars. Do I recommend this game: Absolutaly NO! But if this game were free, "Go nock yourself out." This game is just too much money for its quality.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												The idea behind DF9 is awesome. A City Builder meeting Sims in space. And that's about all I have to say to sell the game to you...Now why I'd recommend NOT to buy it. Reasons are numerous, and most already mentioned by others and this blogpost[wildwoodgeek2.blogspot.nl] explains most of it I think.In addition to the blogpost I'd like to add an other reason why NOT to buy DF9. Once again the AI, which just plain sucks! My personal experience with the AI sucking balls is that after a debris stike, my oxigen tanks and power supply got hit. Without power and oxigen, the whole crew starts to panic, including the whole technical team. WTF? You guys should run to the power supply and oxigen tanks to fix them instead of running around like headless chickens!An other problem is the Sims part of the game. The people have a (hidden!) worklist of stuff they have to do. So far so good I'd say. But technical maintenance (yes once again) should have a top priority for lifesupport, but noooo..... Ocigen tanks are about to break down and they fix ...a bar stool... FFS guys get real please! Or at least let me point the Sims where they should go next instead of fully automated.Bottom line, the idea behind DF9 is real good. Sadly the developer dropped the ball and the project, leaving us with a half-baken, bugged and dumb game :'(

content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
												Owned it since very early on. It looked interesting and I love space games as well as "theme hospital" type sims so I gave them $50 on Kickstarter. Went to play it but it is literally unplayable. Not just unenjoyable, actually unplayable. But hey, it's early access, I'll open it up in a month.A month later, almost nothing has changed. Development is slow but yeah, it's early access, I knew what I was getting into. Did this for a few months and again, very little has changed. It eventually becomes playable but very incomplete so extremely unenjoyable.Left it for 6+ months and recently heard they made it version 1.0. Opened it up again, it's playable but still extremely incomplete, there is very little to do. I ate my $50 and wrote it off as a bad decision and feel that you can't trust DoubleFine. I then heard that they ran a sale in September a few days before slapping the 1.0 on it. Brought in a horde of new young hopefuls like myself who believed in the studio and what the game could be. A week later they slapped the 1.0 on it and called it finished in its incomplete state.In short, don't buy it, it's incomplete. And seriously consider whether you want to support the studio when buying any of their other titles.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												This game had a lot of promise when it was first put on steam and I had high hopes for it as did many other people, it had promise to be a great Dungeon Keeper styled game where you could make a sprawling space station, tend to the needs of the astronaut's living there and of course fight hazards...but what we sadly got was an unfinished mess.Not only did DoubleFine release the game WAY before it was ready, they had the nerve to call it 'finished' and continue selling it even after they announced that work on it had been ceased...this was followed up by a party on DoubleFines end that didnt exatcly look cheap to host, and seeing as how the game was cut due to money issues I suspect that DoubleFine had not only left the game in an unfinished state, but outright stole from their customers and fans..and as a result got quite a bit of backlash from the community. I enjoyed this game for a while as you'll see on my profile, and I sometimes revisit it only to see wasted money on my part...DoubleFine is truly scummy for doing this and for still selling this game at it's current price.Bottom line: Do not buy this game, it is a waste of money and will only feed the greedy beast that has become DoubleFine...oh how the mighty have fallen.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												As you can probably tell by my hours played, I was a huge fan of this game while it was in development. I could live with the bugs, knowing it was all an Early Access alpha, and that it was being worked on regularly. Some day, it would be finished and fun.Except that never happened.Tim Schaefer himself gave the order to pull the plug on development, claiming that not enough people bought the game during Early Access to fund the development. That's right, the business "plan" was to use Early Access money to fund the actual game (smacks head).If they'd done a standard crowdfund (like Kickstarter) and said "We need X dollars to make this game", they probably would've gotten the money because, you know, Double Fine -- but, apparently, they completely misunderstood what Early Access is for (hint: it's not for funding the majority of your game's development).Short version? Same as everyone else has been saying: the developer abandoned the project, but called it finished anyway. It's not finished. Do not buy.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												Double Fine cancelled development of this title due to lack of sales in the Early Access phase. Although they claim to intend to remove the remaining bugs, some of which are game-breaking and require you to restart from the beginning (and still have not been addressed as of mid-December 2014), they will no longer be adding or balancing new or existing features. What's left is a collage of incomplete or broken concepts on an otherwise compelling gaming platform that will never see a proper implementation. Please save your money for more worthy titles.

Posted: November 24, 2016
												Broken, unfinished, shallow crap. They went into early access to grab some cash, did virtually no work on the game to develop it then dumped it as "finished" and ran away with the money, Tim Schafer is a scammer with a long track record of financial mismanagement and failure to deliver.The AI is non functional.The content can be fully experienced in an hour.Everything (not exaggerating) is bugged to hell and back.The most basic of tasks become nightmarish due to the bugs and clunky brokenness of this "game".Here's how dishonest Tim Schafer (the guy in charge of Doublefine) is - His steam profile listed Spacebase as his favourite Steam game and he had about 1 hour of playtime on it. LOL!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												The genre of roguelike and city builder probably shouldn't crossover so often. Spending hours building up a little city only to lose half of your population because the game didn't tell you a turret attached to a friendly docking ship isn't friendly (which makes no sense) is infuriating. There's no way to reload the save either because it's a roguelike and losing due to meaningless randomness is part of the 'genre'. It wouldn't be so bad if your citizens weren't seemingly suicidal, preffering to walk right up to the turrets face instead of just swining behind it. And there's no way to force them into doing so.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												this game has a few too many problems for me.1: no one ever does their jobs. the builders and the miners do their jobs, though when you tell the builders to take appart a derelict they go inside, take off their space suites, and drill a hole in the hull and kill themselves.i got attacked by raiders and they got into my life support room and got killed, but then the room was full of dead bodies so no one wanted to go into the room to fix the oxygen recyclers. how do you get rid of dead bodies? well, the doctors are meant to come in and take them away, but whenever they enter the room they get upset by all the dead bodies and leave. THIS IS YOUR JOB! not to mention that they leave all these unconcious and injured people all over the base.then there's the science team, there was a disease i needed them to reaserch so i assigned them to it and checked back on them about sixty minutes later and they had done NOTHING. i had a special room and everything, i double checked and they had just been standing in the hallway chatting the whole time. eventually they got to work, but people were sick and going to DIE!the security job is nearly pointless, and what they actually do can hardly be considered security. people assigned to security patrol a small area around a single security beacon, and the only real use for this is to have them explor derelicts. i just ended up building defense turrets everywhere, but they have limited view. 1.5: you can't tell anyone what to do, so even though this room is on fire no one knows and your fusion reactors are going to burn down.2: given how little you're actually able to do as a player, the game asks way too much of you. every five minutes it's telling you there's a new disease that needs to be researched, when instead you want to research new technology (because apparently the scientists who research dark matter also research medicine, and not the doctors), raiders seem to attack more and more frequently untill you're perpetually under attack, and the game is always telling you that, even though you have 30 reactors and twice as many oxygen recyclers than you need for your population, you don't have enough power or oxygen.3: the AI is stupid. outside of not doing their jobs, when i got attacked by raiders the AI does nothing to avoid them. when they walk into a room and see a raider, most of them just stop and hold up their hands in fear before being shot. raiders aren't even that smart, one broke into my pub and started punching my fridge.4: i'm not listing all the problems, i'm glad this game was so cheap when i baught it, because it's too late to get a refund.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								I cannot recommend at this time. The two biggest problems are the citizen AI and zoning. The citizens do the dumbest things and there is no way to micro-manage them to do what they really need to do. On more than one occasion I have had people die because they wouldn't build a door or they'd take off their spacesuit in the unoxygenated. The zone system limits what you can do with your base. You can only put certain types of objects in certain zones. This means you can put a life support system in the same room as the bedroom or pub. This is a pain when you are just starting out and can't really afford to layout an entire space station.A lack of content is to be expected but these issues harm the gameplay.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												I love the concept of the game. I love what it could be but quite frankly, the devs either need more resources or more dedication. They claim this is "their baby" but all I see them doing is adding fancy backgrounds, fixing 2 or 3 relatively minor or non-gamebreaking bugs, and adding a new half-finished feature every 1.5 months or so. This is unacceptable and this is exactly why I am absolutely DONE supporting early access titles.I don't believe early access reviews anymore unless they look honest and there's enough of them. Too many people review a game and say they love it despite its flaws simply because of the premise (Kinetic Void is a good example). I love the concept of Spacebase DF9, but if I still had a choice whether to back it, I wouldn't. The devs are pathetically slow on this and I see no excuse for a 4 or 5-man team to take this long especially if it's their "baby." Yes, they did say that in an update a while back. Claimed something to the effect of, 'oh we reallllly are working on this game we promise. This is our baby" <paraphrased>I'm sorry DoubleFine. you have my money but I can assure you I will be attempting to convince anyone I know interested in it to hold off until you get your act together.  You've had close to a year and you have barely made any progress.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Alright, I enjoy aspects of this game very much, but the A.I. is, quite frankly, awful. Disasters like space debris and raider invasions happen fairly often, but your civilians have almost no way of actually responding to them, unless you make them a security guard and give them a beacon. And even then, only about half of them will do what you say. Then sometimes they'll start suffocating in space, but they won't even attempt to head back inside the station. And if you order them back in (by sending them either to the infirmary or to a beacon), they'll take the most roundabout route possible and still die. Once, I sent a worker to tear apart a derelict for extra scrap, but when he got on, he took off his space suit, so when he removed the walls, he suffocated.I really want to like this game, I really, really do, but the A.I. needs to be fixed desperately. I'm talking priority 1, above all else. Either that or give the player some sort of option to order any worker (not just security guards) to different parts of the station at will. Honestly, I was enjoying it for the first 2 hours, but the last hour I was tearing my hair out as the terrible AI constantly killed off my best people.I realize this is still alpha, and I expected some bugs. But my gosh, I expected the AI to at least be somewhat competent. If you're going to release an alpha, DoubleFine, at least have the game be somewhat playable.I'm sure my feelings for this game will change later down the line, but honestly this alpha has left a bit of a bad taste in my mouth. There's so much here that I really like, but the AI ruins it for me.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								Has much potential but to be honest progress is painfully slow. There is often no update from the devs for weeks at a time and the 'monthly' updates when they do come, late, are small.I have totally given up playing the game as after a couple of hours you've been through the same repetative cycle of building, loosing everything and starting again twice or more. There are very few item/rooms to build. One of the things I really have a problem with at the moment is the rediculous way it handles breaches. I can remove a section of wall then watch the O2 level in the room slowly drop off over a minute or so. This makes dealing with raiders hard as the security are next to useless and you best option is decompression which doesn't work.I hope they get all this sorted, there is so much potential here for a great game. But its not worth buying now while even the very basics don't work. For now save your money, there are more bugs than working componants it seems and every belated update just introduces more.I'm going back to prison architect for now, if you want an alpha builder, thats where to invest your money right now.I have heard the team is only 3 people, considering the funding sales in this game has already brought it I have to wonder if this is true, then how much they really are behind it. It has certianly made me reconsider my feelings about buying early access in the future.PS I have much more than 8 hours outside the steam time as of writing this.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								Do NOT Buy this. It's been an interesting ride, but Double Fine is already discontinuing development.After they recouped the 400k investment through the initial Early Access purchases rush, the plan was to pay for the game's development through early access sales.The lack of an actual game or engaging mechanics left no animo for word of mouth excitement and Spacebase DF-9 is losing them money. Say what you will, perhaps they should focus on not repaying the investment before the game is actually fun to play/worth selling, but let's hope Double Fine learns their lesson on overpromising or underestimating their budget needs.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								EDIT: (12/24/14) This game still has very annoying bugs. The door graphics still has a bug where the doors are other graphics instead of doors. The way the power usage on base works is unblanced, hostiles can plow through your whole base in nothing flat, the illnesses are unblanced; frankly everything is unblanced. For a supposedly finished game it is terrible. Don't waste your money.EDIT: (9/23/14) Don't buy it. Just don't waste your money on it. The bugs are still there and pathfinding is still horrible, possibly worse than ever. I can't play more than 30 mins before I rage quit over some stupid bug that is seemingly never going to be fixed.I was very hopeful when I reviewed originally, but with the annoucement the game is leaving Early Access still as broken as it currently stands is extremely dissapointing. I will not be buying from this developer in Early Access ever again.Original (8/23/14):Each update it gets better, but it has some bad bugs in it. I play on Mac and for me the most annoying bug is that the door images are never doors sometimes they blink between a chickenhead in the shape of the door that should be there and nothing at all. In this game you run a spacebase that's constantly falling apart around your ears. If the workers aren't killing themselves the raiders will do it for them.Currently you can only play one game at a time. If you start over you lose the base you were building. You usually lose the base to something stupid before you get to the point you would want to start over anyway.Everything needs worked on. AI, pathfinding, how the spacewalkers handle their oxygen timelimits (they ignore them and die last I played), how often metors strike, how the bartender wants to eat which jams up everybody as they wait on the bartender to be served who can't serve himself (only fix I know is to change the bartender's job to nothing which unsticks everyone and then change him back until the next time), how the builders decide what to build next, just everything.The game looks promising and when it decides not to kill me within the first 15 mins of gameplay I usually can have fun until the door images being wrong get to me or raiders invade while the turrents do nothing and I get mad. I open it after an update, start a new base, play until I rage quit, and wait for the next update to try again.My suggestion is to put it on your wishlist and check it early next year. See if the bugs have been fixed and even then only buy on sale.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								It was really hard deciding whether to recommend it or not. Here's why I decided not to (followed by what I like):At its current state (Alpha 6e) there are a few bugs I consider gamebreaking.1. When exploring a derelict that for various reasons doesn't refill it's oxygen, citizens will walk around and even go there (!) - like technicians wanting to fix something, botanists if there is a garden, etc - until the oxygen is low at which point they start running around panicked. With no way to add oxygen, they do this until they die, often wiping out most or all of my security crew, along with a couple of other idiots who went there.2. I can't seem to get them to calm down after throwing a tantrum. Most of the time, they wake up (or when they're released from the brig) and throw another. Rinse and repeat until someone kills them.3. Technicians are quite useless at their work (which goes for all citizens, really, but it's most noticeable with the technicians). It takes forever to fix something.4. (Related to 2) It's too damn hard keeping your crew happy. I just can't seem to do it, at all! Ok, so that's why I would not recommend the game at this point. If these things are fixed in a coming update, however, I would definitely recommend it! Here's why:I really like the challenge it is to build a base in space. Things like broken or incomplete walls are suddenly a major deal. It's fun with the research letting you get better and I like that there are derelicts appearing that you can explore. I see much promise in this game and think it can get really good once the team has had a chance to develope it a bit further.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								What can be said ?...: Spacebase DF-9. [ An Early Access Preview ]*Uninterested exhale/grunt.**Leaves to get coffee.**Returns, sips coffee.**Writes this prologue in a way, that hopefully delivers the feeling of indifference.*This, is exactly why. You cannot properly review an Early Access game, since most of the games content is not present. It is like Minecraft in Alpha, its a proof of concept with not much context, polish or content.And thats why, i cannot write a review about it...What ? Dont look at me like that, when you think about it properly. You'l see exactly what i mean, it would be like reviewing something just based on its trailer.  *Cough* Colonial Marines .But allright... Spacebase DF-9 is a game, where you try to build a working Deep Space outpost. This is only hampered by the AI and its questionable prioritisation. Multiple times, my only technician thought it would be more important to talk to Johny the SpaceSlug than to, lets say, repair the Life Support systems.And this is one of those games where there is a certain build plan. And deviating from it will just result in failure.That is, if you can get the builders to do everything in time.And speaking of "doing stuff on time". That is an ironic statement/joke, that i hope several of you will get. The citizen of your station are complete and utter lazybones.. 'ses.Most of their life consist of eating food and talking to others. And this they will do even if they have other, more important stuff they need to do. Like maintenance to make sure the station wont disintegrate like a clown car.  Another rather ironic thing to say about this...So to compress that all:Spacebase DF-9  is like Minecraft in Alpha, very lacking in content. But the concept is easy to get, now it just needs some care and attention to make it a full game. And for gods sake, repair the AI.
