number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								Spacebase DF-9, or as I like to call it “The one game where I want to throw everyone out the airlock and watch them all die” is in my opinion one of the reasons early access games should not be on steam. While the page fully warns people that this is still in its alpha stages it should not have been allowed to until at least a better running beta. As of right now the game is computer destroyingly broken as there are multiple problems with the game.The Intro: As of right now there is not even a full bare bones intro to this game. While when first picking the area you will settle in you see multiple aspects in the upper right corner which mean nothing to you. However it does give the player some heads up after picking it what everything means. That is the only good thing I can say about the intro as is. The next second you are placed in space with three aliens and a pod which can be broken down for scrap and a few minutes of oxygen for each to try and figure out how to build a base. While I understand people hate the idea of tutorials that really drag on I would have preferred at least something to give me more information. My first time playing my entire crew died because instead of building as I instructed they mostly floated around space and then began to panic when their oxygen got low because no one worked.The AI: Ok… Day One: Garry’s Incident I feel is one of the best examples of bad AI… this nearly reaches the same level of incompetence. In order for a crew member to do anything you must assign a job and where they will be in regards to some of the jobs like mining and building. While that’s fine by itself the AI doesn’t know what to do often times. They will lounge about the base or flat out ignore build orders or security beacons for when intruders come in guns blazing or fires because… I have absolutely no idea. The AI is unresponsive and more lazy than helpful and I feel like this would have been aided greatly by being able to tell them what to do The Sims style but the AI of course has free will… the free will to walk around doing nothing while I have set up a build order for oxygen recyclers which they need to live while their oxygen quickly is used up.Building: There is barely any direction as to what to build when starting but common sense plays a part here. Of course they need oxygen, food, and a way for more resources and while all those work when the AI actually does their job… the rest is very lacking. There is no explanation as to why a pub, or a reactor, or really anything is important beyond just common sense guiding my actions to make me build them because, they are there so they must be useful. After all if they can make their own food they stop eating the same stuff from the food replicators. But again things don’t seem to need reactors for power or crew quarters, or fitness rooms, or a pub since things work without them. Again direction would be nice here and even diversity since for example there is only one air recycler, no better one.There is more I could go on about and while I love Double Fine… I cannot in good conscience recommend this game to anyone until at EARLIEST its full release. But even then I would wait a few months if this is any indication of what the full game will be like.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
												☰☰☰☰☰☰☰☰☰☰☰☰☰☰☰☰☰☰☰☰☠☠☠  Avoid, avoid, avoid, avoid!  ☠☠☠☰☰☰☰☰☰☰☰☰☰☰☰☰☰☰☰☰☰☰☰This game has been classified as hazardous space debris.  Set your navicomps to avoid this sector at all costs, lest you find yourself wasting space credits.UPDATE: Developer has released the game as "done."  Oh, but we'll get the source code so we can finish it ourselves, right?  Right??  Well, let me say this:  Tim Schafer is the new Peter Molyneux.  *drops mic and walks away from Double Fine forever*UPDATE 2:  Just played 1.05, the "release" version of the game.  Some of the bugs I've mentioned have been addressed, but only a few.  Now features a "tutorial" level that is basically just a pre-built base with some lame text overlays telling you to perform a few tasks.  I played the level after the tutorials were complete, and was immediately swamped by a continous stream of raider vessels.  Base went from 12 occupants to just 1, and when I saw that last "Raider breach vessel incoming!" message I just quit the game and un-installed it again.Pros:☑  Er.  I wish it were a good game that had potential?  Cuz I would love me a Sim Starbase game.Cons:☒  Very buggy user interface.  I commonly had to "trick" the game to build an item by building another and then canceling it before completing it in order to get it to build the second item (which is the item I wanted in the first place).  If items overlap, then it is impossible to click on one or more of the overlapped items.  (Say if you have a claim-territory flag that is overlapped by an oxygen generator.)☒  Obtuse needs and wants system.  My crew fights and kills each other, and I am never sure why without carefully inspecting each cluttered needs/wants screen for each crew member.☒  I've lost dozens of crew without even really knowing why.  The notification bar fills up with tons of "XXXX needs medical attention" and "XXXX is dead" messages before I can even react to whatever is putting my crew in danger.☒  Your first base is going to result in dead astronauts.  So will your second, third, fourth and likely fifth.  Margins are extremely thin at the beginning of the game, so if you screw up in the least (such as build a room too small to hold a refinery, without knowing how big that refinery is) you have to start over.  There is no way to undo or fix a build mistake, so if you make any at the critical first few minutes of the game, then kiss your space-butt goodbye.☒  Zoning system is clunky and requires you to build a special-purpose room to simply place one item.☒  Annoying fixed view that cannot be rotated, nor is there a "fade behind" effect when someone or something is behind another object, so it's easy to lose people or things.  This will likely never change either, because while the crew are rendered as 3D models, it's clear the walls and objects are static sprites, and if the devs didn't account for rotating views at this point in the dev cycle, they probably never will.☒  Overall quite buggy.  UI elements end up becoming corrupt, crew get stuck in rampaging loops and can never be subdued, miners will drop ore in the middle of space during a crisis and never pick it back up, etc.☒  Feels very unpolished, and like an early WIP.  Expected more progress for this game since the last time I looked at it (about a year ago).

number of helpful: 8 of 15 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												I'm sure everyone knows this, but I must include it on my review. This game has been abandoned by the developers.The developers are also expecting modders to finish the game for them...but didn't make a workshop compatability...*facepalm*. Seriously devs? so at the moment, there are very few mods out there and they are scattered all over the internet, and google search is no help. However, there is a new mod called "unoffical patch" to fix some bugs and add some features. I recommend you download that mod or be greeted with bugs apocalypse. Now lets talk gameplay.I don't know what they normally call them, settlers? austronaut? pawn? I'll just name it "people".Unfortunately, you can't move your people, which can be very annoying when raiders are on sight.You can assign them up to 9 jobs, some people are more skilled on certain job and also enjoy/hate certain job.The jobs are;Builder: self explanatory Technician: maintain and fixes objectsMiner: self explanatorySecurity: shoot hostile enemy, and follow security beacon that you can set.Bartender: Tends the bar which increase happiness.Botanist: tends the garden.Scientist: Make researches to unlock things.Doctor: Heal and cure diseases/illnessJanitor: Clean corpsesUnassigned: defaultPeople have needs, and they can go up and down shown on a graph. I don't know what most of these does to the person.Duty, Social, Morale, Stuff, Energy, Hunger, Fun. Those are the 7 needs of a person.People also have "thoughts" that you can read. Some of them are about friends and enemy they made, an object they built, or even a certain doom they are about to encounter. Thoughts really define them and I enjoy pausing the game and reading them. They also have a nice hand drawn avatar so you know what they look like and perks, if they have low self esteem or they are anxious, etc.Each person really is different from the rest and it's amazing how much detail they have. It's ashamed this game is abandoned.Now let's talk about building.There are 13 rooms you can build, and they are;Airlock: In and out of the space stationLife Support: For placing Oxygen machine Reactor: for powering the entire space stationRefinery: smelting rocks into matter (money)Residence: Build beds to increase population limitPub: increase happinessGarden: Grow foodFitness: gymResearch: build research table for scientistInfirmary: HospitalBrig: prisonCommand: Threat monitoringUnzoned: plain old room Each of these rooms have certain objects that can only be placed on that room. All objects (and wall/floor) cost matter to build.Matter can be obtained by mining rocks and smelting it on a refinery machine. To build a room, you need to inclosed it with walls and floors. If a wall or a floor is destroyed, and a person is in that room, they will be sucked into the vacume of space and die.Walls/floors and objects can be destroyed from astroids and raiders. There are random encounter in the game.There are people that you can communicate with that randomly pops up (when they are near you).If you respond to their message, then you can either gain a person or be targeted by raiders.This is the risk you need to think about before accepting their calls.There are also an actual spaceship that shows in your game. You can either send your security (via security beacon) or leave it alone until it leaves the game. Spacebase DF9 had potentials, but its been abandon before it can even fly. I really wish someone would make a similar game. SOMEONE PLEASE! That being said, would I recommend this game? Not on full price. Buy this game when it's 90% on sale.

content:

Early Access Review
								This game was supposed to be one of my favorite games ever, I played and enjoyed throughout early access and looked forward to every single minute of playing. Sadly the dev is rushing out 1.0 and with not even half the promised features.Spacebase DF-9 tasked you with building a station then maintaining it amongst the stars, with research, raiders, new arrivals, and multiple room types the future of this game looked bright and full of potential. But, everything changed when the fire nation attacked...SB DF-9 has followed suit of Towns, Starforge, and a few other Early Access titles in that, they made all the promises but only lived up to a few. With the community left with a unfinished product.Please do not buy this game, developement is mostly finished and it will be abandoned go buy Clockwork Empires, Gnomoria, or Rimworld if you love these types of games. Idk if there will ever be a spacebase sim and, even if there is there will never be one in my opinion that felt as good as SB once did.... Truly tragic.

Early Access Review
								I was hopeful this would be a build, conquer, research game. And it is all that; I love this concept: Build and survive, personnel management, with a twist of exploration thrown in.However, all of the positives this game has to offer is decisively destroyed by its horrible, horrible AI.The technicians should have an editable queue. That would make life better.Security should have a route display that is editable.And if there is no door (only a wall) why am I still supplying it with oxygen? Maybe I want to decompress the room. And that takes waaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaay too long.And where are my multiple saved games?Devs, please consider my suggestions.At this time, I can no longer play due to these issues; the game is almost unplayable for any extended period.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
												I'll keep this review short and sweet.I got this back in Early Access as I liked the idea. Pretty solid progress was made along the way and while it was nowhere near what I'd class as "Complete", it was showing lots of potential.Then suddenly it got released as version 1.0 and that was that.What's there is relatively stable and it's fun for a few hours. But it's easy to see it's incomplete whether it's some missing tool tips, room zones where there isn't much to do, etc. There's no reason to keep playing after you've built anything in your base and enjoyed the inhabitants for a while unless you really enjoy aiming for the "Goals" which just seems like grinding numbers.Great idea but incomplete, released as "finished" too early and they seem to be relying on mod support to fill out what's missing.

content:
Posted: October 7, 2015
												It's a shame to say, but unfortunately, this is just an incomplete game. That's really the best way to describe it. With bugs and glitches abound, and an astounding lack of ability to implement even the most basic mechanics without running into huge balancing issues between AI abilities (which are stunted by a bad AI setup) and the horrifically timed Raider events, it really just reeks of Double Fine saying "we need to get something that at least looks half decent if you close one eye and squint real hard".Don't waste any of your money on this. I got this as a gift copy, and I still feel offended for the person that was kind enough to gift it to me. This is one of the few games which makes me genuinely angry to play, and is a blight in anyone's game library without some future huge rewrite by an independent coder of some kind.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								I want to preface this review by saying it is about the update schedule, or lack there of, not the game play itself. Knowning this game is early access, I bought it back in January expecting that it would have bugs, lack of content and be a work in progress. I also expected steady progression on the games development. In half a year of owning it I have seen two full alpha revisions and maybe seven or so minor patch/bug fix updates. There is no posted schedule or hint at when updates can be expected. It feels like this game is on the back burner and a one man team is working on it. All the while the rest of company is putting time and effort into they 5-6 other games listed for release this year from DoubleFine. In short, if you are looking for a game with a set alpha release time frame and/or constant status updates this is not for you. Paying the money I did I was hoping to see progress more like Prison Architect and Space Engineers and that is just not the case.

 £18.99 For a Cancelled Game This title is broken in its current form. More often than not it is unplayable due to unbalanced mechanics and truly awful ai. There was once promise, promise enough for many people to shed out a lot of money when the game was listed under Early Access, now the developers have declared that no more updates will be coming to the game - that there is not enough funding to warrant the amount of work it would take to deliver the experinece the devs described to us (back when they asked for our money.) The investors who spent 400k on this title have recouped that amount but players who supported this title are receiving a mere token update that hopes to fix a few bugs and add a tutorial. Do not waste money on this broken and unfinished game.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
The first 'promising' Early Access gameDouble Fine had lot's of plans[archive.is] for Spacebase DF-9. The game those plans outlined would be well worth the $20€ price.As development continued however, more and more of those plans were laid to rest[archive.is] and in the end a very select few were ever realized. As such, the game as it stands, is just nowhere close to being worth the price, and should've been priced more like Hack'n'Slash, the game it's being bundled with now, is priced.Spacebase DF-9 is a perfect example of a phenomenon that continues to this day: wholly unfinished but 'promising' alphas on Early Access.As Steam's own documentation states, both developers and customers should treat Early Access games as they are know, not as what they might one day become. Devs shouldn't sell promises, and customers shouldn't buy them. But alas, here we are.I regret buying into Double Fine's promises during Early Access. Because of the few genuinely good games they've put out, it's easy to forget Double Fine's catalogue is more 'miss' than 'hit', Spacebase DF-9 being a prime example of that fact.Bottom lineOnly buy Spacebase DF-9 if you want to support Double Fine. Even then, it might be better to just buy a DF t-shirt or something, rather than to inflate the sales numbers of this mediocre dissapointment.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								I want to preface this review by saying it is about the update schedule, or lack there of, not the game play itself. Knowning this game is early access, I bought it back in January expecting that it would have bugs, lack of content and be a work in progress. I also expected steady progression on the games development. In half a year of owning it I have seen two full alpha revisions and maybe seven or so minor patch/bug fix updates. There is no posted schedule or hint at when updates can be expected. It feels like this game is on the back burner and a one man team is working on it. All the while the rest of company is putting time and effort into they 5-6 other games listed for release this year from DoubleFine. In short, if you are looking for a game with a set alpha release time frame and/or constant status updates this is not for you. Paying the money I did I was hoping to see progress more like Prison Architect and Space Engineers and that is just not the case.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												It occurred to me that I should actually write something after the couple of years I've had this game. For those who weren't aware, this is an unfinished game that went from Alpha to Finished virtually overnight after Double Fine got all the money they thought they were going to get from it. It's buggy, it's extremely barebones in features, and if you buy it now you'll "miss out" on the Hack/Slash consolation gift they offered to us paying customers who got royally screwed by Tim of Legend. There is a modding team attempting to do (for free) the job Double Fine Entertainment couldn't be bothered to do, but buying this game will give those welchers yet more money that they can roll into their new Early Access project, which they're totally going to finish this time, honest guys. My advice: avoid.I can't say the $20 I spent on this game was a complete waste, though. It taught me two valuable life lessons: never buy a game for the promise that it'll be awesome later, and never buy any more Double Fine products for as long as I live.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												Starts off sweet but quickly becomes sour.As far as abandon titles go, this one seems like it is close to being complete. However, two big elements are missing. First, there is gameplay balance. The game starts off feeling like you can do anything in it, if you just put the time and effort into it. And for the first 20 or 30 minutes this feels true.  You expand your base, explore ships, and manage your people to get the most out of them.  But then the raiders, and meteor strikes happen. And this is where the missing gameplay balance is most obvious.  Negative events are important to any game, if things were always good, than there wouldn't be any challenge. But the speed, and frequency of the negative events needs to be balance out against what the play can and cannot do, so that they can overcome them, and not just suffer.  I found that during the few games that I played, that I would get close to having a decent base going, only to have ruin by constant attacks, to the point where I was losing a lot more people than I was generating. Which resulted in me having a large empty base that I had no chance of defending or using.The second element is content. There isn't much in this game... Overall, this is not a game that you should spend money or time in.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												I liked the concept of this game, but ultimately it proves so frustrating to play.Everything from the UI to the AI slowly starts to grate on you. Take when the player has to first build the room for power and life support and an airlock - even though I did it fine each time, a bunch of times the little crew members would refuse to go inside and instead ran out of air while floating and wandering around outside while marvelling at their craftsmanship.Send your virtual minions to collect rocks so that you can build more areas for them to live in and shelves for their..tentacle monsters and sooner or later you will encounter... SPACE PIRATES! Okay, it is not nearly that dramatic, it becomes such a casual occurrence (so much so you get invasions right after each other, yaay..), the problem is these visits throw stuff into chaos. Security team, arm phazers, set them to stun or kill, I don't know, just get rid of these guys! Mr Wol--, what the... So even if you go to the security tab and tell your security team to defend a breach point a lot of the time they will stand idle and just be cut down one after another and the SPACE PIRATES will go on their merry way butchering your whole crew.How to prevent this? Set EVERYBODY to security since that is the only way people defend themselves properly, afterwards you can try to figure out who does what job. CHAOS, Chaos everywhere, send in space marines to purge all this chaos.After learning that my security were completely incompetent I instead put turrets, over there, outside, in that room there.. EVERYWHERE! Turrets are far more effective than actual people, you don't need to worry about losing something that took ages to level up and they kill raiders near instantly. <3 Turrets.Base is defended - rockin'! Crap, tons of dead bodies in the base, mostly raiders but also my own people sometimes too, but they are making the crew depressed. No worries, the doctors will clear these bodies and recycle the matter, or at least they should. Doctor doctor, emergency paging dr. Beat, corpse rotting in life support room, whole station being flooded with smell of rot and bacteria! DOCTOR! I stare at my doctors and notice two standing in the infirmary playing videogames (curse you videogames!) and another one in the pub getting drunk and brawling. I sigh and decide that if they want to look at them so bad then sure, they can keep their cadaver friends.Despite my doctors being either drunken masters or videogame addicts, I don't have any huge illnesses or parasitic worms devouring the crew lately. Still no work is getting done, so I change all the bartenders to other stuff hoping this abolition will get people to work.I have miners and builders getting picked off by raiders and kill bots because the AI does not avoid danger and there is no way I saw to tell them to stop and go home. I stop caring if my crew die, it is worse than herding sheep because at least sheep run away from danger, crew numbers drop, bodies piling up, nobody cares and just drinks away their sorrows on Spacebase. I decide to quit playing the game before the chaos and stupid mechanics get to me and I become as apathetic as the crew, right before I quit - I notice that a doctor is finally removing all the dead bodies on the ship. Double Fine, could have done better. The game had potential, but abandoning it rather than fixing stuff was much easier for them.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												Unless this has a serious discount, don't buy it. It has a lot of things wrong with it, and the devs dumped it before finishing the game. BUT some modders have taken up the challenge of releasing patches for the game anyway using its source code, and so far they've been consistent in their releases.The most annoying thing about the game by far is how your station residents are incredibly sluggish when it comes to doing anything. I've had two starts where everyone suffocated in their space suits because they took a million years to actually get around to building oxygen recyclers when ordered, and another where everyone suffocated because they refused to build an airlock to actually get into the mini-station they'd just built. When you order a squad of security officers to move to an area with raiders in, it's a coin flip whether or not all of them will actually go there. I lost one citizen and one of my two officers to a raider attack when one of the officers decided to - I♥♥♥♥♥♥you not - stand around playing a handheld game instead of actually doing his job and shooting the raider that just killed someone.It's quite frustrating sometimes, but worth the whole 69p I paid for it. I wouldn't pay much more than that for this game in its current state, though - if you do want to pick it up, I would advise you to not pay anything more than £1.50 or so for it.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2015
												This game is just a failed experiment I suppose? Basic playability is barely functional.At a base level in games, you generally want to know what you can and can't do, and a certain amount of intuitiveness is necessary in UI elements. You cannot place objects on walls if they face ne/nw (Isometric view). You cannot rotate a camera despite the 3D models, I spent about five minutes confused thinking no surely you must be able to make it face the other way? Considering objects are NECESSARY in one room, to go into another, (Two spacesuits in a room, with an airlock, to move out) the only answer is making gigantic rooms or a ton of small rooms. The tutorial doesn't really tell you to do this, and while you can then retry, and do it "right", it sets the tone for the game. You won't be using your intellect or planning skills, you will learn that the game isn't capable of some things, and how to work around it. There is no space efficiency, which is one of the key "fun" things to do in a base building game. Learning is of course a key part of games and design, but they should be learning mechanics not limitations. In ten minutes I ran into several of these little "Oh. You can't do that? Or am I doing it wrong?".I bought it because it was DoubleFine and it DID NOT say it was early access. I checked if there would be updates, and it says sure there will be one more, and then development is done. Unfortunately I think this is a kind of cool game that will never come to fruition, like  many in this harsh industry.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2015
												Originally, I had a positive review of this game.  It was an interesting start.  It was basically Dwarf Fortress in space with graphics from the list of planned features, and looked to be quite promising.  Even with what was in the game, it was at least worth playing for a couple dozen hours, even if it lacked any real depth to keep you playing for too long.  Then, it was cancelled while still in pre-alpha...The developer abandoned it because, as far as I can tell, they just plain didn't think it was selling well enough to be worth putting money into finishing the game.  It's kind of crushing that a company that had a positive reputation like DoubleFine would just abandon a half-made game like this.  (And for the record, my first real notification of this was that my previous positive early-access review managed to get a near-constant stream of downvotes for the simple fact that it had been a positive review...)  The "consolation prize" was that they handed out free Hack 'n' Slash games to purchasers of this game (limited time, already over), although it raises the question of why players would trust in the next early access game when the last one was abandoned...That said, I don't have the same bitterness a lot of people seemed to have. (Likely because I don't live in hype of upcoming games when I'm sitting on a mountain of Steam games I've got in reserve.)  As for the game, itself, it's fairly simple.  Start with nothing but a few resources, build an airlock and air recycler quick to not suffocate when your suits run out of air, build a mining station, and start mining for more resources.  From there, use resources to start making more rooms, and stuffing them full of all the random things in the menu until you have a little of everything.  Then have random visitors stay at your station, and start building MORE of everything.  Then have asteroids slam into your station (just lock everyone out of the threatened rooms), or have some raiders (set everyone to security, and bum rush them all), or have other mystery stations drift nearby (remove their walls from the outside to suck all the likely hostile inhabitants into the vacuum of space instead of letting your guys get killed). By and large, the game just lather, rinses, and repeats from there.  If you really like managers, I can say you might have fun with it for a few hours, but don't get it unless it's absolutely dirt cheap, because you're probably going to experience everything this game really has to offer in about 6 hours or so, and from there, it's just a matter of building a base larger and larger to cram more and more population in.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2016
												Not really much to say on this one.I picked this game up when it was still in early access, spending what little money I had free to use on video games at the time, excited about all the plans the devs had. What was already there was a solid base game to build on, and I figured with a studio like Double Fine behind it there would be a lot to look forward to.The joke was on me, I suppose.Double Fine bailed after they decided the game wasn't as successful as they wanted, and left everyone who supported them with the very beginning of a game and nothing else. What's there may be stable, but there's just no content. I wouldn't even call it a beta; it's not complete enough. It's fun for all of an hour or so at most, and then there's nothing left to do. Starting over doesn't really change anything, either. There's nothing to really do differently, so there's virtually no replay value.To this day Spacebase DF-9 continues to be one of the most infamous cautionary tales of early access, and for good reason. Not sure I'll be doing any further business with Double Fine either, but only time will tell.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												Spacebase DF-9. I've played some terrible games in my time but this one takes the cake. 90% of my seven odd hours spent in this game was spent screaming at the screen because the AI, which you could easily equate with a turd, weren't going into the oxygen filled station that they just built to get air all whilst panicking because they were sufficating. The base building was the only fun part about it but it was always a worry that the builders would go out, stay out and die. The roster of jobs was a feature I liked though. Rather than hope you get what you need you just make them what you need whether they like it or not. However...some of them didn't work all that well. For example: Security guard, armed with a pistol, stood and had a fist fight with an attacking raider. And what did the others do? After running around like headless chickens for 2 whole minutes which, by the way, was made even more amusing once paired with Benny Hill, they all got their suits on went out the airlock...and stayed there.One thing this game needs desperatly, but probably won't get, is the option to tell the members of your shambling corpse of a base where to go to combat the amount of deaths that can happen in the first five minutes. I can't remember how much i paid for this, whether it was on sale or not but either way it was by far the most regretful purchase i've ever made. Don't make the same mistake I made. Leave this game in the cesspit it tried to crawl out of.

This is unfortunate, because I rather like the game and think it could be improved a lot, especially if I can get ahold of the developers who were tasked with this specific game and give them my detailed unbaised input on things.  Having talked to several other game devs in my time, I've learnt several things about the development scene so I know how to work around certain issues with development to help make a game better.  However, it seems thathis game is abandoned.In its current state, it "works", but you have to be real lucky to get a good base going and you need to place lots of turrets everywhere and rapidly expand as fast as you possibly can.  I guarentee you're going to lose, a lot.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2016
												Spacebase DF-9 was broken when I first began to play it...crashing within the first ten minutes. I was bummed out 'cuz it looked like a cool space station builder. THEN...I don't know what happened....maybe an update (maybe the last one), but now it runs reliably and I can't remember the last time it crashed. I have had immense fun with this game. It does have quirks that will be unacceptable to some people, many have been covered by other reviewers. I just, for some reason, really enjoy building building outposts in space and don't take my "crew" too seriously if they asphyxiate themselves because, after awhile, my space stations tend to get big and busy....starting over and rebuilding is what I enjoy about this game. I've not run out of ideas for construction of the ideal station, yet. That's what I like about this game...the building and crew management and watching something I've created actually function...until aliens board, or a new crew member's mental illness comes to the fore with disasterous results! Or someone leaves a door open..yeah, this game reminds me of Planetbase...I get to build things my way, but in the end, a billion miles from nowhere, I can only forestall eventual doom.I am glad I bought it.Frankly, I would give Spacebase a 8.5/10 for concept.......umm, I don't know what I would give it for execution, I just know I pick it up when I'm in the mood  for making things in space..."It scratches an itch very well"...7.5/10

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 11, 2016
												I like this game, simple, dumb.  It lacks a lot of items, randomized events, and it's most likely when you really need an action taken like saving an incapacitated crew member, or fight back against enemies you are going to lose.  That is pretty much it, three things you have to deal with.  Bad A.I. that are stupid and the events of ships coming and going being either new crew or raiders, that's all.This is, sort of worth the price but sort of not, since it still plays like alphaware (even fan-patched, you want to do that) If it's on sale like $4.99 (or free/bundled cheap/$1) I think it's worth just a few hours of play if you want a really dumb space simulator that is pretty much rogue-lite if you don't absolutely micro like a mo-fo against any early first 15 minute rage quits.  I followed all the hype and bad blood and finally sitting down with it, (had it for awhile) I really like it.  If there was one thing I'd like added it would be abit more control with your crew, rather then somewhat bad hit/miss pathfinding and que actions. Like at least make one crew promoted to Captain and you at least can do everything on your own seperately and remotely while everyone else just does their business.Like I said, it's a more unforgiving repetitive rogue-lite experience with either very bland gameplay or very frenetic broken attacks and your crew just being dumb.  It won't be this sim that is easy or, hey build a base with hundreds of items beautiful space life thing.  The gameplay is somewhat vapid, and a bit weak in a few areas but to me it was okay for what it is, regardless of any pie in the sky promises.  I've certainly played far worse games that cost more and games that truly are shovelware/abandonware.  It isn't going to be evil genius, or dwarves, or even rimworld.  It's okay for an unfinished game.  Believe me, there are much much worse out there.  Out of 5 I'd give this game a 3.  Out of 10, I'd give it a 5.  Out of 3 I'd give it a 1.5You send a guy to a derilict and he dies, go send a builder to vape a few walls and kill everything inside.  You got miners/builders outside about to be attacked, switch to guards.  Use the alarms/beacons.  Put sentry guns everywhere, build air/power and research.  Then build.  That's about it, build another base layout, then another base layout. Most of all, get this game as cheap as possible.  Not more then $4.99 and certainly $1 is a bargain for you to waste an hour or 2 just to see how rediculous your crew will act.  They will leave crew to die on the floor with broken knees no matter how many doctors you have, they will fly around outside and do like one action and return with 7 mins of oxygen.  When the crew does work it makes you happy, when they all leap out the airlock to die like lemmings... well... ya, it pisses you off.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												It occurred to me that I should actually write something after the couple of years I've had this game. For those who weren't aware, this is an unfinished game that went from Alpha to Finished virtually overnight after Double Fine got all the money they thought they were going to get from it. It's buggy, it's extremely barebones in features, and if you buy it now you'll "miss out" on the Hack/Slash consolation gift they offered to us paying customers who got royally screwed by Tim of Legend. There is a modding team attempting to do (for free) the job Double Fine Entertainment couldn't be bothered to do, but buying this game will give those welchers yet more money that they can roll into their new Early Access project, which they're totally going to finish this time, honest guys. My advice: avoid.I can't say the $20 I spent on this game was a complete waste, though. It taught me two valuable life lessons: never buy a game for the promise that it'll be awesome later, and never buy any more Double Fine products for as long as I live.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												Starts off sweet but quickly becomes sour.As far as abandon titles go, this one seems like it is close to being complete. However, two big elements are missing. First, there is gameplay balance. The game starts off feeling like you can do anything in it, if you just put the time and effort into it. And for the first 20 or 30 minutes this feels true.  You expand your base, explore ships, and manage your people to get the most out of them.  But then the raiders, and meteor strikes happen. And this is where the missing gameplay balance is most obvious.  Negative events are important to any game, if things were always good, than there wouldn't be any challenge. But the speed, and frequency of the negative events needs to be balance out against what the play can and cannot do, so that they can overcome them, and not just suffer.  I found that during the few games that I played, that I would get close to having a decent base going, only to have ruin by constant attacks, to the point where I was losing a lot more people than I was generating. Which resulted in me having a large empty base that I had no chance of defending or using.The second element is content. There isn't much in this game... Overall, this is not a game that you should spend money or time in.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												I liked the concept of this game, but ultimately it proves so frustrating to play.Everything from the UI to the AI slowly starts to grate on you. Take when the player has to first build the room for power and life support and an airlock - even though I did it fine each time, a bunch of times the little crew members would refuse to go inside and instead ran out of air while floating and wandering around outside while marvelling at their craftsmanship.Send your virtual minions to collect rocks so that you can build more areas for them to live in and shelves for their..tentacle monsters and sooner or later you will encounter... SPACE PIRATES! Okay, it is not nearly that dramatic, it becomes such a casual occurrence (so much so you get invasions right after each other, yaay..), the problem is these visits throw stuff into chaos. Security team, arm phazers, set them to stun or kill, I don't know, just get rid of these guys! Mr Wol--, what the... So even if you go to the security tab and tell your security team to defend a breach point a lot of the time they will stand idle and just be cut down one after another and the SPACE PIRATES will go on their merry way butchering your whole crew.How to prevent this? Set EVERYBODY to security since that is the only way people defend themselves properly, afterwards you can try to figure out who does what job. CHAOS, Chaos everywhere, send in space marines to purge all this chaos.After learning that my security were completely incompetent I instead put turrets, over there, outside, in that room there.. EVERYWHERE! Turrets are far more effective than actual people, you don't need to worry about losing something that took ages to level up and they kill raiders near instantly. <3 Turrets.Base is defended - rockin'! Crap, tons of dead bodies in the base, mostly raiders but also my own people sometimes too, but they are making the crew depressed. No worries, the doctors will clear these bodies and recycle the matter, or at least they should. Doctor doctor, emergency paging dr. Beat, corpse rotting in life support room, whole station being flooded with smell of rot and bacteria! DOCTOR! I stare at my doctors and notice two standing in the infirmary playing videogames (curse you videogames!) and another one in the pub getting drunk and brawling. I sigh and decide that if they want to look at them so bad then sure, they can keep their cadaver friends.Despite my doctors being either drunken masters or videogame addicts, I don't have any huge illnesses or parasitic worms devouring the crew lately. Still no work is getting done, so I change all the bartenders to other stuff hoping this abolition will get people to work.I have miners and builders getting picked off by raiders and kill bots because the AI does not avoid danger and there is no way I saw to tell them to stop and go home. I stop caring if my crew die, it is worse than herding sheep because at least sheep run away from danger, crew numbers drop, bodies piling up, nobody cares and just drinks away their sorrows on Spacebase. I decide to quit playing the game before the chaos and stupid mechanics get to me and I become as apathetic as the crew, right before I quit - I notice that a doctor is finally removing all the dead bodies on the ship. Double Fine, could have done better. The game had potential, but abandoning it rather than fixing stuff was much easier for them.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								I am really excited by the potential of this game and it is for this reason I purchased at this early stage expecting to get a discounted future AA purchase.This game at this stage all told should not be selling for anymore than £4.99. Yes I do enjoy it, yes I see the potential and yes I do understand this is a Alpha release. This game is good but it seems to be nothing more than the best of genres from decade past - not a bad thing but a thing that retails at £12.99 as a complete package.This feels like a game from experienced developers going back to their roots and as such I belive they should have the courage of conviction by offering a discounted Alpha and not a inflated overpriced one. I should not be expected to pay a premium for their mid life crises.

content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is quite a fun game but even when all the problems are fixed it will still be a failure.Current issues: The game A.I. is broken which means everything else is currently broken too. Every type of crewmember forgets how to do their job every now.. builders wont build, botanists ignore plants etc (restarting the game every 15 mins helps).  Game settings (all 6 of them) dont always work. Some features are unfinished (which is understandable). There are a lot of graphical glitches & bugs.Game issues: There is very little to do. You can research everything and build a fully functional space station in 30 mins.  Then you just sit and wait for the RNG to do its thing and thats it. Even if the A.I. & everything else is fixed it'll still be broken the same way most god/build/sandbox games are. Every game will end the same way, you'll keep building until some RNG event inevitably breaks things ruining your game.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												The game seems like it has potential, but it simply isn't even close to being there yet. Releasing it to the public in this state was a mistake. Everything feels extremely barebones, and I've encountered numerous bugs that forced me to start over (such as people getting stuck in an airlock). There's even a room type that does absolutely nothing (why even add it in yet?). I'm assuming said room will, in the future, function as a power plant for your station, but at the moment it's purely for decoration.The character relationships aren't close to being where they should be, and it doesn't seem like there's any reason to build separate quarters for each character over one communal bedroom. I was looking forward to the inhabitants becoming friends, getting married, having kids, etc. At the moment it seems the only relationship types are "friend" and "enemy".The random events seem limited to a debris pummeling your station, raiders arriving, and new recruits arriving. Debris is easily dealt with by installing a fire extinguisher in each room, raiders will leave if asked, and new recruits offer to stay no matter how poorly you're running your station. I bought this game expecting to build my very own Babylon 5 or Deep Space 9, but it simply isn't anywhere close to being there yet. I'm very much looking forward to new features and improvements, but at the moment I cannot recommend this game. I do think that will change in the future if the game lives up to the potential of its concept.Edit: Since I wrote this, Double Fine has announced that they're leaving this game an unfinished mess. Stay away. Far away. And boycott Double Fine.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
												Post v1.06 Update:Derlict games (a community team) has picked up the task of fixing what Doublefine left for us.Progress is slow but allready with v1.07 and v1.071 the game is noticably improved. Many bugs are fixed and there are quite a few new structures avalible.Unfortunately becuase Doublefine only released the Lua Scripting what can be done is very limited in nature and many aspects of the game are being rewritten from scratch to make them more eaisly worked with.I dont reccomend buying Spacebase DF-9 yet. In time that will change but there still are better games out there like Startopia.Origional Review:I previously had a negative review of the early access for this game due to various bugs, quicks and gamebreaking issues. I went into 1.0 with the intent of  viewing the game as a clean slate and giving it a fair chance at a positive review.Unfortunately though nothing has changed.The AI is terrible, and incapable of even the most basic levels of prioritisation. Crew will get stuck behind objects which is a new issue for the game this sort of thing wasent a problem in previous alpha releases. The initial seed powering system is still buggy. I had to rebuild the room around it 3 times before it registered leaving me with very little resources left to actually continue my station. The predicted resource gains from mining is completely inaccurate. It gave me an estimate of around 1000 or so and i got maby 200. The event system is still stupidly unforgiving and 9 out of 10 new game attemps will fail because of massive ammounts of meteor showers hostile invaders or generally just incompetent AI.The only thing i can tell they did add was a tutorial that nobody wanted or needed. For all intents and purposes the description of the 1.0 update is nothing more than a lie, there have been no bugfixes, there is no new content.Do not buy this game. No matter how much of a fan of this genre you are this game is not worth the cost. Dont make the same mistakes myself and the rest of the community that bought into this project.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2016
												I can understand completely why this game has such poor reviews. Two years after its release, it remains littered with bugs that devastate its playability. I am reccommending it because for what it costs, I think you're getting your money's worth.This game is very screwy. You've been sent deep into the galaxy to help seed the remnants of human civilization throughout space after the fall of Earth. You're not alone, you get help from nearby strangers in similar situations. You never get to actually take control of anything though, the people do whatever they want and all you can do it provide some guidance. More often than not, succeeding involves less strategy and skill, but simply getting lucky.With that said, I've been having fun with it. There isn't a whole lot to the game. I really wish they would finish it, or perhaps publish it open source so we could develope it further, because it has enormous potential to be an exceptionally entertaining experience.If you get it, you're going to notice a few problems right away. There are almost no settings. I think you can basically turn the sound on or off and that's it. The game's artwork is quite simplistic and usually runs smoothly, but the HUD menues are overloaded with special effects and animations that will make your framerate drop to crap any time they open. Once you've done the tutorial level and are ready to actually play the game, you may spend more time just looking for a decent place on the galaxy map to build your base than the time you spend actually getting to play. The whole game then gets quite confounded by the mood mechanics. While there are things you can do to help people be happier, and I've had lots of happy folks in some of my bases, they all inevitably gravitate towards depression and then stop working and everything goes to crap and the oxygen runs out and they all suffocate.Once you get to that point, you discover that there is no way to actually loose the game! Even with everyone dead and your base in ruins, you can still get new people on random chance and continue playing, even though they are almost certainly doomed.The whole game is wacky that way. It makes a whole lot of no sense. But, still, it's fun, somehow. As long as you don't think abut it too hard or take it too seriously, building one base after another while being hounded by pirates and metoeor showers and ocasionally having some suicidal idiot walk out the wrong door and drift away into space can be pleasantly amusing. This is a game you can just relax with and generally expect to fail at every time you play.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												Wow. Do not buy this game.  I've wanted it for a long time but never bought it due to the god awful reviews. It starts out stupid, the first time you try to build a station from scratch.  If you don't know what you are doing you will run out of money befor having all of the life support stuff ready.  So after you create your 5th station and have mastered the exact money(matter) management you need to get a reactor, air cleaners and a matter recycler thing, youre finally good. Then one of your dudes , about 10 minutes in, gets infected by a space parasite.  You only have 3 guys.  No infirmary yet.  He turns into a giant bug and kills your entire crew.  That's really crappy.  Now, you build a new station again and no infection happens.  Good so far.  Everything is great except about 4 hours in and you love your station very much, boom raiders.  3 raiders killed all 22 of my crew, including my two 4-star security guards.  I'll never play this again.  I want this exack game minus the hazards.  I just want to build and manage, not fight parasites.  Also the order the builders build is ridiculous.  There doesn't seem to be a way to actually research things. Screw this game.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								It was fun for a while, until you start noticing the stupidity of the AIs: - Miners don't use the nearest airlocks and suffocate. - The techs spend their day getting fat instead of repairing equipment (especially the turrets outside the station). - Doctors don't always grab the bodies floating in space. - Everyone runs around panicking when the station loses air instead of suiting up and repairing the hole. There are also graphical glitches: - Sometimes phantom fires stay lit in the floor if the crew put the fire out without a fire extinguisher.- Airlock LED indicators often stay floating in space after the doors are removed. There are more problems, and the game features don't feel fleshed out enough. I would recommend trying this game later in its life.Edit: Now that the developers have stopped, well, developing, the game isn't a worthy investment unless you want to cry tears of sadness.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
Early Access Review
								This game has potential, but in its current state, there is about 3 hours worth of somewhat buggy gameplay.   Simple things like citizens of your base being unable to figure out how to navigate through/around other citizens, or to the place where they need to do their assigned jobs.It's easy to imagine this could turn into something great (with more tech and numerous path finding bugs worked out).   Let's hope it does.At the moment, it is not a recommend for what I paid (around $15 USD).  Hope to change this in the future as the game improves and sometimes very frustrating kinks get worked out.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
Early Access Review
								There's something very engaging about this little base building sim.  The character of your citizens, the flavor of the room types and furnishings, the banter with incoming vessels.Bugginess aside, the game is still very incomplete.  It serves to give you a taste of what the finished game will be, but it wont satisfy.  For Alpha 3 though, it's in a pretty good place.But even ignoring it's alpha state, there are some issues with the design I find a bit lacking.  Issues I'm not sure will be resolved by the official launch.  For instance, there is no vertical building.  Your citizens can space walk in 3D, but you can only build in 2D.  There is also only one material to mine and build with.  Some of the other issues I could list off are relatively minor, or things that they're likely to address for RC.  But these two core design points are things that fundumentally narrow the experience, and it's not clear if they'll be resolved.Ultimatley I say wait, unless you want this sitting in your library and eyeing you until it's finished (and I'll probably update my review at that point just to be fair),

content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												I bought this a long time ago, back when it had really just entered the Early Access section.  My play time is more than what's shown as I play offline a lot.  The idea was sound, and I really enjoyed the game when I first tried it.  Obviously, I expected more as time went on since the game was still in development.  I also understand that development takes a long time, and isn't exactly the smoothest ride, so after a while I uninstalled and just let it sit for a while.  Seeing it just get officially released, I decided to check in on it again and find that, really, not much has changed.  I'm disappointed in the scarcity of things to do - it's a game of "build each facility, bam you're done", when it comes down to it, like the tablet versions of city builders such as SimCity/Metropolis/Anno/etc.  Just not much to it.I don't recommend it simply because it's not worth playing more than once, and I'm not happy paying for something like that.  Even the most single-player of experiences I tend to come back to after a while, but SpaceBase didn't have anything to it that made me say "yeah, I'll pick it back up after I play this or that".  Not worth a buy, not worth the time, especially given how lackluster the support has been over the period it's been available.

												An incomplete game they slapped a release on to call it complete, so they could make a little bit more money from being on Steam's front page for a while. I got scammed by the developers and will never purchase another product from Double-Fine again. The game went on sale literally 3 days before they announced they were cutting development and just releasing the game as is. I got suckered into that purchase assuming there would be at least another year of EA, and at least most of the features on that list would be completed. Double-Fines horrible calculation of finances and not wanting to dip into their own-pockets for a game not even released yet shows a lot about their business practice. Avoid anything from these guys in the future!As for the actual gameplay, well it's early alpha still with about 2 hours worth of gameplay before you run out of things to build and at that point you will just get raider after raider attack, meteors, and parasites mutilating your base with no chance for recovery. This game has been the biggest let-down for me since Fable 1 on Xbox back in the day :(.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												Wow... Had a lot of potential, but the product that Doublefine crapped out here.. I won't be buying anything else made by that "game" developer.The project is abandoned and unfinished. The build number claims to be 1.06, but it feels more like a 0.7 beta. Nothing is balanced and I encountered several glitches. This game was made to be modded, which in this case means the dev handed over game development to the players instead of finishing it. I would be happy with some awesome mods that finish the game out, but there is no workshop support.After four or five failed bases I thought I had got the hang of it. I had beaten every disease and easily defended against 20-30 attacks. Then a wave of attacks hit (they often come in threes within seconds of each other) and I took out the first two no sweat with my five man security team with a combined star rating of ~14 out of 25 (which is quite good). Then the last raider boarded all by himself, and killed my entire crew.I was boarded by the main antagonist of a space pirate anime apparently.I would have researched better weapons and armor, but my two man scientific team were busy trying to develop anti-viral air scrubbers to counter the relentless spread of disease.My entire population was 18. 5 Security, 2 Scientists, 1 Bartender, 2 Doctors, 1 Botanist, 4 Miners and 3 Builders. They were all busy non stop. Also, they were all assigned to professions that made them 'happy' and I had every accommodation in the game available to them in abundance, but they were all still sad/angry. I had only lost one crew member to a sudden chest bursting that I don't think could have been prevented.I really want to play this game. It is really fun up until that moment that it becomes overwhelmingly unfair and you lose three hours worth of work. Maybe they made the game so hard to compensate for the lack of content. Every so often something comes along and takes out 90% of your crew. Then you have to build back up, thus 'adding' more game play. Not fun.I give this game a 3/100. I'm going to give it one more try because I am stubborn, but I have no expectations other than a severe cussing fit.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												An incomplete game they slapped a release on to call it complete, so they could make a little bit more money from being on Steam's front page for a while. I got scammed by the developers and will never purchase another product from Double-Fine again. The game went on sale literally 3 days before they announced they were cutting development and just releasing the game as is. I got suckered into that purchase assuming there would be at least another year of EA, and at least most of the features on that list would be completed. Double-Fines horrible calculation of finances and not wanting to dip into their own-pockets for a game not even released yet shows a lot about their business practice. Avoid anything from these guys in the future!As for the actual gameplay, well it's early alpha still with about 2 hours worth of gameplay before you run out of things to build and at that point you will just get raider after raider attack, meteors, and parasites mutilating your base with no chance for recovery. This game has been the biggest let-down for me since Fable 1 on Xbox back in the day :(.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2015
												Ok, so this game.  Great concept.  Great idea, and it is done really well.  Except for one main thing.  The game constantly throws stuff at you, and sometimes there isn't actually a good answer.  Let me explain.  You are building a big section of your base.  Things are going well.  You then see a message appear on the side of the screen saying how one of your builder's space suit oxygen is running low.  Sometimes they quickly make their own way back to the airlock, stopping them from dieing.  Sometimes they just carry on working and then die.  You can try to avoid this by sending them to the infirmary (which is obviously inside) manually.  But sometimes they don't bother to listen and still die.  Another example of this game throwing rubbish into your face would be those raiders who have high tech weaponry.  It takes one of them to take out tonnes of vital parts to your station as well as many many people with inferior weaponry, and thats it.  Your space base is broken and/or on fire and half your population dead.  Yay.The random space debris causing major fires and ruptures within your base can easily kill a room full of sleeping people, again almost half your bases population. But the main thing that gets me is that for a game that is meant to be a mix between economy and fighting, all the fighting is unfair (see the first paragraph) and the economy lacks whats really needed.  The AI don't know when to prioritise fixing vital oxygen recyclers over fixing an unused door.  They also don't know when it is useful to take a break - many will take a break and not perform tasks during critical points in gameplay, causing negative effects (most prominently the players mood).  In conclusion this game has a lot of potential.  A lot.  But it doesn't have basic concepts like manual prioritization and decent AI.  The whole game needs a huge amount of balancing, and until this happens I recommend you simply follow this game, rather than get it.  If and when the devs make the changes necessary this game will definately worth the money.  But for now, I recommend you spend it elsewhere.And one other thing.  I can't for the life of me find out a way of keeping the people happy.  It may just be my incompetance, or this too may need balancing...

content:

												A grate idea that showed endless promise, up until it was axed my Double Fine after Alpha 6. That's right; the game was released as a 'finished' product before it even went into bata!I enjoyed my time with the game, even in its unfinished state, but given how it was shamelessly shoved out the door and given a price slash to entice in new players who had yet to see what a half-baked product they were buying into, I cannot recommend this game in good faith, nor can I even say that you should pick up the game if you think it might appeal to you if you don't mind a lack of polish.As a moral consumer, I strongly advise you to NOT give money to this game! number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												There is nothing more infuriating than an almost good game.  I really like the concept and mostly still had fun playing it.  The game has an annoying tendency for bases to implode (figuratively) for no discernible reason ruining hours of work. The game has no easy ability to save and as far as I can tell no way to have multiple games at the same time.  People are made of tissue paper.  Fights break out and the player has very little control as the denizens pummel each other unconscious.  I have had airlock glitch and deplete the air in the base and suffocate people. I have had people run screaming past fire-extinguishers while their co-worker's burn.  The lack of ability to prioritize building often leaves a room only a single floor tile left to be constructed.If the issues that make it un-playable were fixed then I would change my recommendation but until then a waste of money.

number of helpful: 7 of 16 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9
												Obviously there is no shortage of hatred on this game. And it is not undeserved by any means. Double Fine betrayed all of the supporters of this game by making many promises, delivering very few, and eventually completely abandoning this game. I've owned it for quite some time, as I purchased it very shortly after it was greenlit. I'm not here to White Knight in any way for the Dev(Double Fine).  Screw. Those. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.  I will never purchase anything from them ever again.However... There is yet, a glimmer of hope. Now, it's no secret that this game is riddled with bugs, and malfunctioning features. But due to the hard work of a dedicated group of gamers, coders, and modders, an unofficial patch has been released for the game. It fixes -many- of the game-breaking bullsh!t that plagued the game, and even adds some additional features. It's easy to find via the game's forum page, for any who are interested.So in my opinion, with that patch, the game is worth a try. Don't like it? Refund it. I find it extremely fun, with some very unique mechanics and concepts that I've never seen elsewhere. The promise that this game had was immense. It's very obvious that, before they decided to run away with the cash, the Devs were being extremely creative when making this game. TL/DR:  The game deserves a shot, as long as you use the unofficial patch.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												In its current form the game is worth less than $1Unfortunately it may never be improved beyond that state. If you want to buy it for $1 (on sale) and hope that several years from now the playerbase mod team actually turns this into a working game, go for it.But don't say you weren't warned. I bought this for a $1 knowing what I was getting into and I can't say I'm disapointed simply because I wanted to poke around and see what all the negative hype has been about. And the reality is, this game can not be recommended with a good consience.All the potential for a good game is here and than you realize your content ends shortly after figuring out how the controls work. There's no campaign, the tutorial is laughably poor at even explaining the basics and the sandbox play (which is pretty much all that exists) is laughably short before it becomes an endless loop.You start with a random team of 3 with random skills in a random zone of space with random resources and (almost) random difficulty. You have some minor influence over how to skew the randomness (by choosing different zones of space); but in the end the only real choice you have is:pick a dangerous area or pick a non dangerous area (or rather: pick an area where you cant play because you die instantly or pick an area where nothing happens until later and than goes into an endless loop of the same easily defeated enemies)I don't know, I had some silly fun poking around with it for about an hour but there's just not much here and while I applaud the playerbase mod team for making an effort at improving the game I know full well that it could take years before there's enough fixes and content additions to make this game playable. I'll probably replay it for a few minutes every year or so just to see if they ever do anything with it.Edit: And I fell asleep listening to the music while playing, which is the only reason it looks like I have some hours of play time. Content was over in less than an hour. The rest of the listed play time was watching the spacebase like a fishbowl or sleeping with the music from the game playing.

number of helpful: 25 of 53 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												Theme Hospital meets FTL.It's a roguelike space station building game. You start with three astronauts and some supplies. After you've got the basic stuff laid out - everyone needs air and food - you're free to start kicking back and just...building a base. Positioning sleeping quarters, infirmary, dropping plants, opening a pub.Challenge comes in the form of enemy attacks. Sometimes enemy ships will close on your station and invade, other times you'll come across a derelict wreck which you can explore, though in doing so you'll generally have to fight stuff.And why are so many negative reviews around?Fan base doesn't like the way this game came from an early access to a full release, so the most of them changed their reviews to negative ones.Nevertheless the game is really good and definitely worth trying!

												Everything works well and nicely on intel and windows 10.My dear Daar has just asphyxiated because of lack of oxygen, I was a little bit attached to him. He made his work so happily. He had no enemies and did his work well. I can see what they say , their friends, enemies, what kind of music they like and their food. You can see them arguing, chatting exercising, and see their dialogues. They seem to me “real” people Several types of:  	 rooms (restrooms, infirmary, research, airlock etc) 	items to put inside (beds, closets, shelfs etc etc ) 	races	events that makes you smile and wonder what could happen if….           .- Anna invited me open the door!... 	    .-Hey We dont have any  Anna!!All that offers a wide variety of gameplay.  and replay value.It seems developer used too much money and time to make it work and profit was not good. so he decided to release the code for this game so someone could improve and patch it if they like to do it)It seems he loved so much his game that he made some  poor financial decisions and have to abandon it at the end, not without any pain.(like a divorce of someone you love so much but that is unsustainable and it is better to set it free.) This game is a treasure and there are some new unofficial patches that fix some gameplay balance issues but the game works well and I will be testing it this days. content:
Posted: November 20, 2016
												November 2016: Now that the game is not so buggy and it is unoficially supported by the comunity, it is good and I really liked the time I had playing it.The major problem is the one-unique save-upon-exit (but there is a bypass for it). Permadeath is not a bad idea, since a careful strategist can beat the game and build the 'perfect' base farely easy. BUT the game still has some minor bags (once my 5 guards squad was stuck running on a wall wile 1 intruder was destroying my life support systems, another time the guard with low oxigen in his spaceswit didnt want to follow my waypoint to safty and prefered to suffocate etc). If i had only one save, I would had abandon the game in the obavo acations, writing a rage review.BUT: I reguraly exit the game and copy-paste the two save files at another folder, so I can paste-overwrite them agan later, to properly handle buggy or annoying situations. That, made the game a really nice experience: A more casual Rimworld type of base building.I strongly recoment if you go on with SPacebase, to get the unoficial patch 1.08. It adds things in the game and helps for better control of the guards (really useful).So, I recomment the game, but since the publisher is not supporting it any more and community/freelances do the job instead, I am a bit sceptic about the 10 euro pricing... Check on some gamply videos and comunity feedback, and then deside if you would prefer to wait for a high discount before purchasing this actually good game.(ps. Rimworld has also still many minor bugs, but the save system is there to make me forget about them...)

content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
An enjoyable space simulation game, simple, fun and entertaining for a good while+Has trading cards+Can name your people+Wide Array of building options+Citizen management is a fun aspect, gives a bit of a sims feel+Good game mechanics, managing everything makes the game really fun+I love the social building options with the citizen management system, space sims! +Added challange of enemies that try to assault your base, you must build to defend yourself+Graphics can be a hit and miss depending on the person, I am rather fond of the graphics though-Difficulty can jump a lot-Some bugs, not game breaking however-Management of everything gets boring and tedious-No achievements, not a big deal but I like to go for 100%-Jobs citizens are good at are sometimes the ones they hateDownload Size: 601mbTrading Cards: 6 cards in the setOverall a good and enjoyable game, interesting to play and gives a decent amount of entertainment for a good amount of time. Worth the price on sale definetely.

content:

Early Access Review
								Bottom line is, never trust Tim Schafer with with your money again.  He put something up here that fleeced the people investing in the game, while taking no financial risk himself.  Calling him an indie developer is an insult to indie development (PS JP, Your not a developer until you develop a finished product).  All they did was take peoples money, determine they weren't going to break even based on pre-sales, returned no ones money and banged out after a year of development.There are people breaking their backs out there to make a game.  Meanwhile your developing a quarter of a playable game in one of the most expensive cities in the US.  Try a little, or fail at your job and get offended at people for being reasonably upset at your hack job.
