number of helpful: 6 of 16 people (38%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												A pretty fun, unfinished, Sims-meets-FTL.Started playing about a year ago, during early access. Have played the game as it developed, up until 'official release'.The theming and art of this game is excellent. It's cute without being saccharine, the dangers of space are presented realistically, which somehow feels acceptably couched within the hand-drawn avatars and cartoon 3d models. I love it.The game starts off viciously (excluding the tutorial), dropping your three spacefarers off in the blackness with a small pod of resources and 8 minutes of oxygen. Within those eight minutes, you have to build a small space station that can support a oxygen-producer, and an airlock.All my astronauts suffocated before I was able to do this, and it was excellent.The game presented me with such a challenge, I was glued, it was excellent. The first time I successfully got my guys into that little pocket of safety, I felt like that scene from Gravity.And thus ended the difficulty curve of Spacebase DF-9.From that point on out, excluding game-breaking bugs (to be addressed later), the game gets easier and easier. Your first foothold allows you to establish resource collection, you invest wisely, and eventually you have a thriving base of about 40 personnel, you've run out of local resources, and are colllecting recycled resources from passing derelicts.Some playthroughs got to be so easy, I'd just start building massive space-station shrines, or just interior hallways that stretch across space to the next resource deposit, because it was fun.Sometimes, I'd have enough surplus to just install double-walls around my entire station, so when boarders attempted their namesake, they'd just drill a entrance into the interior bulkhead.There are some minor issues I have with infrastructure, for instance, for oxygen, the recyclers produce oxygen that free-flows through the station, but aside from that, there's no real way to control it. Usually it's best to center the recyclers in the base, and build the other rooms off as spokes, but if you have say, a long hallway, the oxygen just ceases to flow down the hall, since it's 'range' is too far. The addition of oxygen ventilation, and power conduits, would be a much appreciate increase in control and complexity.This game had/has such potential, if well balanced and bug-fixed, but there are powers higher-up putting an end to that. Developer Double-Fine has recently seen a round of layoffs, shorty after CEO Tim Schaffer announced that production would cease on Spacebase DF-9. While I've not gone through the process of comparing Spacebase's credits with the current Double-Fine roster, the coincidence is certainly suspiscious. Double Fine, who since Brutal Legend have been relying on Kickstarter and Early Access to fund their products, may have found that charitable funds are not an effective way to bankroll game development.Regardless, the premature cessation of development on Spacebase has it's noticable effects. Massive, game-breaking bugs still exist, that completely ruin the expierence.For instance, technicians are tasked with repairing damaged or worn-down equipment around the base. At it's peak, I had around 20 assigned, and I typically ignore them, as they automatically prioritize things to repair.Instead, I'm focusing on the Marines I've send out to a derelict to clear any threats. Surprise, surprise, there's a xenomorph on this derelict, and I haven't committed enough troops to deal with it. As it chases the final doomed marine around the derelict, it's tail flicks a door, damaging it. I sigh as I watch the marine die to the monster, when I notice that there's movement elsewhere in the derelict.A conga-line of technicians stroll through the airlock, ready to fix the broken door. As the alien rears it's head on the first, I'm frantically trying to do anything I can to get them back into the main base. But it's too late. They're all panicked, and it's not like the game has any system to give independant commands to a single unit. I lose half of my base's population to bad AI. This is not a one-off; it has ended essentially all of my long-running playthroughs.Other bugs exist, such as the game having trouble determining what is and isn't space, which leads to things like units being sucked through an interior doorway into a bedroom, only to hover there, trapped, as if it were zero-gravity, until they starve. Or the fact that something about scientists causes them to almost immediately 'go insane' when assigned the position, causing them to run around fighting other crew, and breaking things.Some of these bugs may have been fixed since, but they were present in the game when it went 'Final', so I am writing about them here.I really, really like what this game could be, and maybe mods will get it there. You'll noticed I've 'Recommended' it on this review; while it's certainly one of the most ambivalent recommendations I've given for a game, it's entertaining and unique enough to definitely be worth playing.Get it on sale, though. And don't trust Double-Fine to not release another half-baked product... definitely wait until the next title is complete before putting cash down.

												Fun diversionary game.  If you get it for a few dollars, it is worth a purchase but don't pay full price since there just isn't enough content.   The tutorial is decent.  I haven't found the Lua modding community for this game that the developers were hoping would expand their content.  For a lower price and some DLC, or more content at its full price, this game would have been a great afternoon or light weekend game. Helpful ObservationsInstalled turrents in quantity seem to be the best bet for security but lack the ability to investigate the derilict ships.  Watch the lights on the airlock doors (they go from full lights when pressurized to no lights when depressurized).  The airlock will only handle as many characters at a time as there are spacesuit lockers and space for.

number of helpful: 5 of 15 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												Ok let me start by saying I love this game. The best way to describe it is that it is kind of like SimCity and also the Sims but it is in space. You have to build a space colony from scratch and take care of your people. You build things for you colony to aid in research, life support, things to do for your crew and so on. You have to mine materials and manage resources in order to last a while. You must make sure you keep an eye out for raiders and derilect ships. This game is like a Sims game on steroids. If you don't like games like the Sims or SimCity you may want to pass this by but if you do enjoy games like that then this is a must have. The neat thing is that all of this happens in a sci-fi setting and the game can be addictive as you want to do the best you can for your crew and protect them from raiders. Make sure you get the The Officially Unofficial v1.08 Patch! Now with Brainworms! to make the game even more enjoyable. Trust me.

number of helpful: 2 of 9 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												I guess this game has gotten such bad reviews because the previous developer dropped it after people had already bought it.  Well now it seems like it's finished.  Great UI, great concept, lots of fun.  Reminds me a lot of the old Outpost series, but with a greater focus on your people/birdmen/chickenmen/frogmen etc. I really like that you can plan out the design of a room before confiming it and having your builders build the objects, but wish that you could do the same thing when laying out the room initially.  Something like a building simulation mode where you can place the walls and then place the objects to make sure that you have the room dimensions correct.  I've built a few rooms where I've discovered that the walls need to come out another tile and then had to send my builder back outside again to fix it... If the devs did this I think it would be the first sim that I've played with this feature, design first then build.  Then I wouldn't need to keep drawing my rooms first on grid paper... haha.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												I'm writing a positive review to this game only for 1 reason - current fanpatch(v1.08.1) made this game quite playable - when you`ve figured out this game at least(i made a little guide for the game anyway - "Nova-class fortress").As game in raw - you are building a space base populated by lazy idiots. They dont do what they must, fight for no reason and die for that reason. 10/10 simulator of why idiots must not be around base. Ppl jump off airlocks, fight fire with bare hands - that's raw spacebase.Anyway, you're building yourself a spacebase. From scratch. You need to get Air recyclers, beds, medical care, food and later - garden-made food. For all of that you use matter mined out of asteroid chuncks. Ppl have different skills and job preferences. Sometimes you gonna get raiders, sometimes - derelicts with raide/parasites/killbots. You also need to research new stuff in order to survive. And in the end - fight off massive raider attack.For great idea this game had, it's a shame that the game was never finished, but with fanpatch and other stuff game is quite funny and can test your wits and nerves. Also, bought game with discount - so it's worth it's price for me. Shame no achievements evne though game has goals(things like achievements).

												ONLY BUY THIS ON SALE!!!!!!!!!!Admittedly at first with this game I bought it in early access, I ranted and raved about it and it had amazing potential to be an extraordinary game. The game itself offers good game play and a decent UI, the tutorial is standard, does the job. The only thing that annoys me about this game is that although the features the game has are damn cool and entertaining (at least for 37 hourish ahaa) it had the potentially to become one of the best but sadly double-fine as per usual started as being active with the alpha community but did the inevitable thing they almost always seem to do and screwed everyone by being half arsed and essentially slapping a for sale sign on an alpha despite many things 'in the pipeline' so they claimed (including workshop compatibility which would have only made this game even more fun to play, more features, more control, more events and ultimately a better game). So i will still recommended this game, but however please ONLY BUY THIS ON SALE!!!!!!!!!! I only say this as double-fine seem to developing quite a habit of not fully developing their games that they release early access and shafting what is always an active community of fans to 'work on other projects'.... In other words they wants to see the $£$£$.... like a street hooker who starts buy giving you some amazing head and then bolting down the street leaving you to realise they've provided an albeit enjoyed but unfinished and overall crappy service while stealing your money and running onto the next chump.... (I use that analogy as it actually happened to a friend of mine once, hardest I've ever laughed).... Despite all of that however I cannot find it in my heart to not recommended this game as I thoroughly enjoy it....

number of helpful: 12 of 32 people (38%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Spacebase DF9’s 2,859 “mostly negative” reviews (at the time of writing) are probably more a testament to Steam’s ubiquity as a content delivery tool than to the game’s own (very real) problems. And it does have problems, to be sure, but depending on your outlook and how much you pay for it, they’re not insurmountable.Its gameplay appears at first to be something along the lines of the legendary Dwarf Fortress, Mucky Foot’s 2001 classic Startopia, or Firefly Studios’  2003 Space Colony, but its flaws – the result of a suddenly-abandoned development process – make it play more like a Roguelike. Your rather nebulous goal is to re-populate the galaxy by building endless space stations, staffing them with an ever-increasing supply of wandering space travellers and keeping them happy and safe from weird diseases, bloodthirsty raiders and each other. Material for building comes from mining asteroids or disassembling passing wrecks and derelicts, and your rooms and corridors are built and then assigned different uses – residential, life support, various social, scientific and utilitarian functions. There’s a strong people-management aspect too, as each new arrival at your base can be assigned to one of eight different duties, each of which will make them feel varying degrees of satisfaction or frustration, and each of which they’ll be good or bad at according to a 1-5 star system. In all respects, the UI is super friendly and makes juggling your people as easy as possible. Which is great, because you can eventually build gigantic structures with literally dozens and dozens and dozens of crewmembers. Crucially though, you have almost zero direct control over your people. You can only order them to report to the infirmary if they’re injured, and even then it may take them a while to limp their way over.At first, as you learn the ropes, each new game comes hard and fast. Death comes as a result of being ill-prepared to research a disease cure, or not having sufficient defences against a surprise Raider attack, or for any one of dozens of interestingly unfortunate and unforeseeable reasons (usually often as funny as they are frustrating). But the actual process of making your space stations is so much fun that the urge to immediately try again keeps you clicking, again and again, learning more and more each time, developing and abandoning new ideas and strategies as you go. Spacebase DF 9 is very much one of those Civ/Morrowind-type games that suck the hours out of your life without you realising. Be prepared for some really late nights if you decide to have ‘just one quick go’ before bedtime.Adding to this feeling is the game’s own save system, which by default consists of toggle-able silent autosaves and a Save and Quit menu option. Like a psychopathic lover, Spacebase DF9 doesn’t want you to be anywhere other than inside it, grinding at full speed. Played like this, the feeling is very much of a  Roguelike’s ‘one life, one death’ trip, and all of this helps mitigate the pain of being screwed by one of the game’s terrible bugs or imbalances.Yes, they are quite terrible, unfortunately. But in the twenty hours that I’ve played it so far, the problems have been all about imbalance and lack of tweaking, rather than outright bugs. One of the worst of these is the fact that the guns on enemy ships, once they’ve boarded you, remain ‘hostile’ even after you’ve killed or captured the invaders (sometimes they can even be reformed and will join your crew to start a new life), or claimed their ship as your own. Only by eventually disassembling enough of the enemy ship will you be able to cut off power to the gun, thus making it safe. But getting to the bloody thing can be a real game-breaker – these defensive turrets have great range and cut through people in spacesuits like a lightsabre through yogurt. It’s at times like these that the lack of direct control over your spacemen becomes a real tooth-grinder, and you can end up with piles and piles of floating corpses made up of the Builders who foolishly crossed in front of the guns to get behind them (in space, the AI paths in direct lines from point-to-point), as well as the Doctors who went to retrieve their corpses. As far as imbalance in the invisible numbers, the worst offender is the near-constant brawling that goes on. At best this leads to a trip to the brig to cool off for the aggressor and a trip to the infirmary for the victim. At worst, guns will be drawn, and people and facilities start falling. In-fighting is a result of a brilliant system of cabin fever that is determined by various things, including job satisfaction and a host of actual personal feelings and emotions, all of which can be monitored on the crew’s individual profiles. Assigning two people who hate each other to a double cabin is a recipe for disaster, while the sight of bloody corpses littering the place has an obvious impact on depression (especially if the deceased was someone’s friend). But again, due to the abruptly aborted development process, it’s one of several crucial, glaringly imbalanced systems. Which, unless Double Fine release the source code, as they’ve promised to but still not yet done, may never be properly sorted out. This is doubly frustrating because a lua-based modding system is present and correct, but so far nobody’s done anything with it.Like the similarly blighted and similarly great fun Aliens: Colonial Marines, it’s a game with a bad reputation that in reality is only partially deserved. Early adopters and those who saw the potential for a Dwarf Fortress in space have every right to be annoyed (and to make those thousands of “negative” Steam reviews). But for those of us coming to the game in its ‘finished’ state, and aware of the lingering problems, there is still much fun to be had. Double Fine’s original plan for the game was hugely ambitious, ultimately requiring much more funding than they could successfully raise for it (hence the truncated development). It was only unfortunate that they had already taken it well into the Early Access phase at USD 20 a pop before they realised this. But that’s one of the risks of public alphas, crowdfunding and transparent game development. Like condoms, no one's happy when they go wrong. If we’re looking at it in financial terms, then in my case I bought it in the 2015 Steam summer sale at -50%, or EUR 4.99, and have played it now for nearly 21 hours. My feeling is that I’ve had at least 20 Euros of fun from it, and that’s quite important. With some AAA titles costing nearly 60 Euro-dollarpounds and offering dozens of hours of gameplay, but failing to deliver even half as much fun, for a flawed gem like Spacebase DF9 to give you that elusive feeling of true, full-belly satisfaction is, I think, quite a feat.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												/edit I love how I posted this and then they did the 180 on the game like a couple days later. Belief misplaced. I really wish someone would finish this though, it was really fun.I recommend this game because I believe in Double Fine and really want it to work out. I played the super early super basic demo a long time ago and it's came a long way from that, but still has a lot to go. At this point in early access, you're paying to help support the game's creation as well as beta testing it. There's a lot that needs work, but you can see where it's going.Some very weird things that happened:-A room got hit with a meteor, caught on fire, and they would just kind of use the room normally. I thought ok, I'll put a fire extinguisher in there. The guy walks into the fire, builds the extinguisher, walks out, room stayed ablaze until I quit for the night. They would seriously walk in, use the console to research something, and walk out. Hilarious, but buggy.-Ships would dock with mine, then nothing would happen. Nobody would come from the ship, nobody would go into the ship. Nothing. One time one of my people had a panic attack and ran into all the rooms of the docked ship that allowed me to claim them, but there was nothing in there. -I had to rezone the Brig to something else so prisoners would maybe leave there and get food instead of starving to death. -I had an incapacitated invader just kind of chill out in my main room doing nothing. I eventually forced the cop to put him in the brig where he slowly converted to being a member of society, but couldn't figure out how to unbrig him so he also slowly starved to death. Added food processor in the brig, they kind of just decided death was better, and died. I mean really? Those are bugs, but they're also pretty hilarious. I'm backing this game because it's fun, even in it's buggy state, and I believe Double Fine will hammer this stuff out.

												I once had a base bustling with 30 highly skilled workers working together in flawless harmony. Then raiders came and killed EVERYONE and destroyed all the oxygen generators, which then led to their death, leaving my base as a graveyard for me to revisit any time. Occasionally being visited by more raiders to add to the body count of suffocated ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.The game itself is actually pretty fun, one thing that was never fixed was the AI. The AI will build a base then float around until they die instead of entering the airlock, they take forever to do their jobs or just won't do it entirely. The game also lacks content in general, the bases get bigger but still get filled with the same♥♥♥♥♥♥ lots of repetitious dialogue amoung other things. Having a pub doesn't seem to actually do anything, they eat chicken instead of paste and that's really it. My crew was also very depressed and just liked to beat the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of each other all of the time, I tried to make it better but no matter how many shelves I put up they just wouldn't be happy. The gameplay is fun but it needs work, work that isn't being put into the game anymore.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								I must say that despite my disappointment that many of the features that were suggested as possibilities did not make it into the alpha and most likely will not make it into the 1.0 release.  It would be nice if Double Fine Productions were willing to keep this game in a beta state and continue active development of it, but despite this, I still find this to be a very fun game with a lot of potential.  Thankfully, that potential won't be wasted.  Double Fine is including the lua source for developers to mod this game.  While, this would be a very fun project to undertake, unfortunately I don't have the monetary resources to take a year or two off of life to mod this myself.  While this game in its current state is fun and enjoyable, it lacks the depth to justify the price tag in my opinion.  I think with a little more effort to add these features instead of relying on the modding community, a lot of these reviews would be a lot more favorable.  That being said, I love this game for what it is and even more for what it has the potential to be which is the only reason I'm recommending it.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												After glancing at the review page for this game, I feel obligated to share my experiences with this game.Some of the positives:*You have to actually plan a base and monitor your resources in order to survive*Every play through is different.  *You choose what type of game you plan on embarking on from the very start.   - Do you want a lot of hostiles?   - Do you want to build your base close to a warp gate so you will have visitors (Friendly & hostile?)   - Stellar Density: Do you want to have an abundance of "money" or do you want to have to really work for it?Some of the negatives:*Yes, the game is no longer being developed*Yes, there are many things not completed   -The game is still very much playable*Yes, there are many features that should have been added in, via the Dev’s constant updates, such as:   -Multi-level base construction   -Teleporters   -holodecksThis game started out as an early access game and unfortunately it also ended that way.  The way I see it, anyone on steam, including myself, takes a chance when buying a game that is in early access.  Will it be phenomenal? Will it suck? When will development finish? Will it ever finish? Will this new bug fix crash the entire game? The game may not be 100% complete, but at least Double Fine released the source code to their fans to continue development.  Sometimes, it's the fans that understand the game on a much deeper level than the developers ever could.  With that being said, should you purchase this game at $20?  In short...NO WAY!!  Should you never play this game though? NO!!! Wait for it to go on sale and purchase once the price drops to a good amount.  You can get HOURS AND HOURS of play time out of this game - and isn't that what you want from any game you decide to sit down and play?!?!

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
Early Access Review
								Some people may be thrown off by the idea of buying a game in its alpha stage, but I have so much fun playing this. No matter how glitchy or buggy it may be (I have only encountered two bugs, while some people have encountered a bunch), it is all about the setting and the experience that this game creates. I started to play this game, and 4 hours later realized I had memorized patterns, and adapted my strategy, adapting to chaos and catastrophe. There is a sense of accomplishment when you get all of your crew members to an emotional state above just "Happy" and reading their logs to see what is going on in their lives. This space simulator is addicting and engaging, and I am very impressed by the amount of detail and development behind such a broken masterpiece.

Early Access Review
								It's an alpha, so you aren't really getting much right now. However, the developers are quite up front (and accurate) about what is currently in the game and have posted their near-future plans as well as those that are a bit further out. In particular, keeping morale up is very important (and not something you are really going to notice at this stage unless you check the forums) and isn't the easiest to do. I'm also not a huge fan of the fact that objects only have 2 orientation choices right now (as opposed to 4). However, all in all it has kept me amused for a good amount of time and offers a lot of promise for the future.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												While I do agree with the negative reviews in that the execution of the ideas that could have resulted (and still can result) in a gem of a game is mediocre at best, I still cautiously recommend it.Below, I list the bad and the good aspects of the game based on my very short experience playing it (one hour is normally enough for me to make my decision, but I leave it up to you to decide whether it is enough to trust my review).The bad:- The AI of your colonists is not the best, but is getting better.- The game becomes repetitive really soon (for me, it has after the first hour playing it)--there is just no hierarchy, almost no gradual development (save the research), and frankly not much to do as of now.- There is no balance. I am pretty sure the developers got their inspiration in the Dwarf Fortress (where "dying in fun" TM), but I am able to play a game of Dwarf Fortress for days, but here my colonists die horribly within 15-20 minutes (raiders, fire or what not).The good:- The graphics are pretty good. I liked them a lot.- The atmosphere of the game is its best selling point, IMO. Save the frustration of loosing each game I play pretty quickly, I like how the game feels. The colonists have their own characters, interact with each other and the environment, make friends and enemies--and all of this creates a feeling of a growing community in space, which is unfortunately quickly sent to oblivion, heh (see the balance).- Enabling the support of mods is the best of the developers' decisions, which I think has the potential to save this game. There are mods already that address the balancing issues, and I am sure there will be mods fixing the AI, adding more things to do, and generally, adding depth to the game.Despite all the drawbacks of the game, I still recommend it for one particular reason: it (still) has an enormous potential to grow into a fantastic game.I understand the reasons for the negative reviews, but I also know that these reviews can eventually bring the development of the game to a halt. And this would be the most unfortunate turn of events, as the game, as I said, has the potential to become a fantastic game that offers its players countless hours of fun (and not frustration as it is now =) playing experience.As for now, the price of the game is somewhat high for what it offers, so I suggest you buy this game on sale, and try it (with mods). I also hope more mods will be made for the game to enhance/improve it.

number of helpful: 5 of 18 people (28%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												Going against most of the people here, it seems, I think DF-9 should get a generally positive review.So you know where my view comes from: I bought this game early in alpha because I had a DF coupon, but I rarely play early EA games.  Aside from a quick try in alpha, I have only played the current 1.06.  I also rarely look in the forums, so perhaps I'm less angry than some.  :)Bottom line: if you enjoy city/base/island-building sandbox games, you will enjoy this.I found exploring the game after a minimal tutorial enjoyable.  I had several false-starts and refined my base layout as I went.  Lost one decent early base when I learned the difference between tear down and vaporize: when removing a section of wall, vaporize removes everything including the floor.  Everybody was blown out before it could be repaired.The graphics and animation quality are quite nice as are most of the sound effects.  The user interface is also easy to use in most cases.  It has a few issues when it comes to placing objects, especially ones that go on walls.  Even though they might be hard to see sometimes, the game does not allow you to use the south-east and -west walls interior (hidden) side for object placement.  Turrets are one of the few items that can face in any direction and it can be difficult to place the turrent as it will jump from wall to wall.  There needs to be a manual method to move the selection tile-by-tile.  It matters where the turret's cone of fire reaches.The AI is perhaps not superb, but so far I haven't had any serious issues with it.  At least, not yet.  Pathfinding seems okay, as long as your base isn't riddled with paths because of doors everywhere.  Picking/keeping a good crew goes along way towards avoiding frustration.  You should also invest some time in keeping them happy.  It can be difficult sometimes, but all of the information you need it given in their tabs.Sometimes, though, the AI will do something really stupid or annoying.  Like avoiding the conveniently placed fire extinguisher in the hallway and trying to stamp out the fire.  It seems as though the extinguisher must be within the room on fire.Of course, sometimes it helps to discover or know the AI's priorities.  With builders, for example, it's rather easy to observe their work, or lack of it, and to figure out what they prioritize.  They tend to prefer building floors before walls, and walls before any indoor work, and so on.  So, if you have a room built and while waiting for it to be filled you plan on a new hallway, the builders will drop their indoor work and go add that new section of hull first.The game's biggest flaw, by far, then is the lack of depth.  Except for the residence and pub areas, every room has only a very small number of objects that you can place in it.  Researching does not alleviate this problem as you really just get upgraded versions of an object or an upgraded replacement model.  That's not bad, but it would be nice to have a number of topics to research (maybe based on your contact with alien visitors) that would give you new objects to use in rooms or maybe even a new room type.This lack of depth and seeming lack of forward progression after a point seem to be the primary reasons other posters give for giving the game a thumbs down.  These really impact the length of play and replayability more than they do playability, however.If the poor description of the game that I've given sounds like a genre that you enjoy, you'll definitely have some fun playing.  For how long I think largerly depends on how much you like exploring the mechanics of the game while you learn to play.  Experimenting with various base layouts for efficiency reasons or asthetics also adds some time and depth.Whatever the reason for DF ceasing development, it seems pretty clear that what has been delivered is a *platform* for a game.  But, of course, they were supposed to deliver a game.  Fortunately, the platform seems to be robust and moddable and even as-is provides a good amount of fun.Judging by DF's last announcement, I doubt we'll be seeing anything more from them.  I choose to be optimistic about the game's future, though.  The quality of what they've open sourced appears good enough that I think the mod community will add a lot to the game in time.  I wish DF hadn't dropped it, but they did and there are far worse states they could have left it in.The game does provide some long term objectives conveniently located under the "Goals" tab of the main HUD.  They are more like milestones, however, such as getting X number of crew, surviving the Mega Fleet, or killing X number of raiders.Finally, price:  It's definitely not worth full price given the lack of depth.  I would pay anywhere between $5 and $10 for it and feel that I got my money's worth.If you're looking for similar games, I would certainly recommend either Startopia or Evil Genius.  Startopia doesn't let you build the base, but you fill it and manage the station.  It came out some years back so it runs great on most any machine and it's a lot of fun.  Evil Genius has you building a base in your island mountain hideout.  You get to design the whole layout, rooms and hallways, similar to base building in DF-9.  Evil Genius has a lot of depth as you take on nefarious missions or as you build booby traps into your base to catch unwitting good guys.I hope this provides a sufficiently objective view of the game.  Keep in mind that I'm still playing and making ever larger bases, so it's possible that there are some issues I've yet to encounter because my population hasn't been large enough.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								Spacebase DF-9 is a space colony building game by Double Fine. One moment you will go from peace across your colony with 20 citizens and then a meteor strike hits and kills 19 of your people leaving a lone survivor who is left to wallow in sadness. In this comedy with a twist starring Adam Sandler you play as Adam Sandler. The lone surviving drunkard who must rebuild his space colony 350,000 years in the future he is then attacked by giant space slugs as he uses his classic comedic timing in mutiple jokes about them. This game brings you back to the golden days of Adam Sandler when he only played a single character in the movie, rather then 2, this twist makes you remember the time where Adam Sandler had made a good movie in 10 years. Everything goes alright until Adam Sandler finally is asphyxiated by his lack of oxygen in his space suit thus ending his comedic golden age. This game is likely the movie of the century. 5 stars.

content:

Early Access Review
								Despite what the nay-sayers say...Yes, the game is Alpha. Yes, it's full of bugs, some of them fairly major. What it also has is a good bit of fun. It's not an action adventure, it's not a shoot-em-up... it's a Sim. If you play other sims, you'll probably like what this game is turning into. It has a good ways to go, no question, but with the regular updates the author has been doing (every month and a half or so) plus his response in fixing the major bugs themselves, the game is obviously being supported and actively developed.In short - if you can sit and watch an ant-farm (yes, I can... dunno why, but I can) like any other sim game, you'll be OK with this. Heck, my pre-teen kids sit and watch me play this... even ASK me to play it. Give it some time to get where the author intends it to go, and you'll see some magic, I think.

Early Access Review
								In it's current Alpha state, the foundation of the game are there and they work very well. It shows how you can assing characters to specific jobs and accumulate ressources, manage characters mood, set up different rooms that serve different functions and so on.  There is only so much you can do for now and once you've set up a good base, you can pretty much wait it out forever so there's no real interest.But the alpha game does an excellent job at demonstrating how rock solid the core elements are. Everything is intuitive, characters do what they're told, unexpected roguelike events come to break the monotony and the game already has a certain charm to it. Given how the basic elements are so well done and so stable, it's easy to see the potential of the game, they can add layers upon layers of features in futur updates and their roadmap is in fact already impressive. I can see that game becomming very complex in the future and each base you build could be very different from one another. Here's an interesting idea, at some point, why not give each base you build some kind of purpose or mission to accomplish and give members of the crew some kind of personnality system od background stories and random events. That way players could make their own little stories with character having romance or hatred or jealousy or mutiny or aliance and friendship and brotherhood and so on.

number of helpful: 2 of 12 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								Spacebase DF-9 is a "Space Station Simulator" from the people at Double Fine. The game starts out on a map screen letting you pick the best spot for your Seed Pod and every pixel has a different variable ranging from, Stellar Density, Warpgate Proximity, Threat Factor and Magnetic Interferance and all change how you game will play out. Once you have your Seed placed you will go into the space base part where you will have 3 crew and 2000 matter (Currency) to start out with, but be warned as your crew only have a limited ammount of time until there oxygen runs out so you have to be quick building a simple foundation and a good amount of oxygen genorators. Now getting more crew is as simple as waiting for a ship to come by but be warned as it could be pirates who will latch onto your ship and try to kill your crew one by one unless you have a good defence, but it could be just people wanting to be crew of your station. Mining is also a main thing that you have to be checking as if you don't mine you will slowly runout of matter and have no more.Your crew has needs such as; sleep, food and morale if any of these get low it can cause them to do their job slower, sleep longer of worse die so you do have to farm and have food replicaotrs to counter act this. Apart from the pirates being a thret  meteors can also hit the station and kill your crew so you have to be on the ball if you have a large station and have emergancy alert systems in place to get your crew out of danger.Now This game does look good but on slower machines can be slow so always check for the latest drivers and be sure that you can run this before buying, as for anything.I am going to give this game a 6.5/10 as in this is still in alpha and is nowhere finished yet, but has a good amount of features.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												This game gets an 8/10 from me. It's a really relaxing game when taken for what it is. I am reviewing it as version 1.06 Mac OSX no mods installed. I had a free version for months before finding it on steam for 99¢ and just had to buy it to encourage the developers just a little bit with my tiny contribution. I would easily pay $5 bucks for it.You're basically thrown into space, given 3 guys and very little resources to start building your space base. In the beginning you need to start as small as possible, building just the bare necessities. Once you have a small (3x3) airlock room, another room just large enough to hold 3 oxygen recyclers, and a room just large enough for a matter refinery, the rest is a piece of cake.The game is 90% relaxing, mining and building, welcoming new (weird & silly) inhabitants, and pretty much trying to keep everyone fed, breathing, and happy - or as happy as one can be in a fragile domicile in space. You need to begin early considering how to protect your base from bad guys that pop in periodically, and asteroid impact damages.Aside from the few (easy) dangers, it's just a relaxing sandbox style building game where you can be creative in making a space base to be proud of. The interface is pretty much well organized, which is an aspect that many games like this get wrong. I enjoy the weird types of characters/aliens and their thoughts and interactions.Many people complain about the AI being ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, but you have to pay attention to what each character is good or bad at and by what degree they would suck at a job. You have to assign them to duties they are good at and actually enjoy doing. Some are good at a job, but hate doing it, so yeah, they'll stand around playing games on their pads instead of doing any work, unless you assign them to a duty they enjoy. I find this aspect completely adorable, as it really adds to the immersion and how you feel or care for each individual. I also love the names - imagining how an alien would pronounce his name written as "Uneekly (nicely)" - that sorta thing.It's currently (for the past several months) been my favorite game for when I just want to relax and make a creative little space base. The few, easy dangers add just enough of that random aspect to keep you on your toes and influence the shape and direction your base takes. Have lots of good tech guys and your base will run smoothly - put lotsa gun turrets all around the outside walls and you'll be safe enough to survive a large attack that eventually happens. And just have fun building and watching how your inhabitants get along.My only complaint is - once you get a VERY LARGE base, things go bad fast. Machines start failing, catching on fire, destroying themselves everywhere, no matter how many techs you have to fix them. But I guess this is just a sign that I've gone way too far with this base and should just start a new one, haha.Lotsa people be hatin' on it, but it's been one of my favorite, relaxing games that I keep going back to.

number of helpful: 2 of 12 people (17%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								EDITED: My previous negative review stated it would remain negative until Tim Schafer released a statement of apology. He did so, and although it didn't addrerss every issue I had with the way things were handled, it did address a lot of them and was an apology I felt was sincere. The harshness of my previous review was due to anger seeing an early access game come to a sudden halt (Tim Schafer does address the lack of communication and the lessons learned from this experience. He specifically apologizes for the communication issue which was my main problem. Had there been communication about the state of things before hand, I would not have been upset. I would have been sad, but not angry. So I appreciate the fact that Double Fine realized their mistakes and apologized for them.) -- it was not, and I feel bad for not making this clear in my past review, but anger clouded my communication skills... -- it was not a negative review targeting the quality of the game.In fact, I really enjoy Spacebase, which is why I became angry. It's a game that from the beginning of early access, was getting things right. Yeah, there was rough patches, but the core of the game and vision was there and I was excited. And whether or not the finished game met all the "features we want in the game" dev list or not was not an issue for me. And my anger was not really aimed at the devs of Spacebase, really. I was angry at Tim Schafer. I'm stating this due to the amount of anger that has been directed at the developers. I think they've done a great job developing the game. Communication was not there. But that was an issue with Double Fine as a whole, not just this one development team. So, going from a thumbs down to a thumbs up becaue of an apology might seem odd to some people. And that's my fault for not being clear as to why it was getting at thumbs down. It's a good game. As it stands. And I'm sure it will be better when they release the last update. Am I sad that they weren't able to achieve what they wanted to? Yeah. But is the game bad because they weren't able to work on the game actively for a few more years? No. It's a good game.I'll be curious to see what happens when the community has the ability to create mods and etc and curious to see how if Double Fine keeps an eye on things and maybe works out a way to be there in the form of a helpful guide to the community down the road.Developers of Spacebase, you made a great game and I'm sorry you were unable to work on it as long as you wanted to. As long as I wanted you to, as well. And thank you, Tim Schafer, for you apology. It wasn't "perfect", but it was an apology I felt was sincere and that's what I needed. And yes, I know that addressing the devs and Tim Schafer in my review is silly (I don't expect them to read this.) It's what I want to include in my review. *shrugs*.

content:
Posted: June 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								Less 'Dwarf Fortress in space' and more 'The Sims meets Dungeon Keeper in space'. Not that that's a bad thing... just don't get your hopes up about interactive complexity or emergent gameplay... they're not to be found here. In fact, the only point of the game at present seems to be to keep your base operating---this might be seen as somewhat lacking in comparison with any of the above precedents--SBDF9 dosn't have the world building of DF, the customizability of The Sims, or the naughtiness and design of DK. However, it does look to aspire to all three, eventually.As of v5, it's still buggy as hell, so I would wait a while before purchasing. Get your fix from Timber and Stone or Prison Architect for the being (or check out RimWorld, which I haven't done yet).

content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												Disclaimer: This review is from someone who played the game STARTING at the most recent version, NOT in the incomplete Early Access version.As its title suggests, Spacebase DF-9 is essentially a cross between Dwarf Fortress and Star Trek Deep Space 9. Compared to other games of the colony planning genre, the complexity of game content is fairly low, but the visuals are far more detailed and approachable; What I mean is, where in other games you may be struggling to remember what that static @ on the map represents, or which one of your little colored peg people was a particular character, in Spacebases you can tell at a glance what job an individual crew member is assigned to, what they're doing, and even how they're feeling, with an exaggerated moping walk when they're upset or a bounce in their step and head held high when they're happy.The space setting gives way to elements you won't find in most other colony planning games, such as oxygen management, exploring potentially dangerous derelict vessels, asteroid storms and chest-bursting parasite monsters, but common themes remain such as the importance of high morale and dealing with tantrum-throwing or fighting crew if that morale drops,  dealing with disease outbreaks and fighting off (or capturing and reforming) invading forces.Despite the amount or complexity of content not being that deep, I've still found fourty-plus hours so far of thorough enjoyment through catastrophic failures and the desire to "build it better the next time", and much like in a Roguelike, I manage to do better, and make a spacebase survive longer, than each previous attempt.Decide for yourself what price you're willing to pay for a simplistic colony planner, but if you're a fan of them and love anything space-related, I think you'll enjoy this game.

								Before I've bought this game I've read the reviews and they were horrible, but still decided to give it a chance because its idea seemed really cool. I'm really glad I didn't give in to the negative hype. Game has it's bugs as any EA but at the moment (Alpha 6c) none of them make it unplayable. Building and running your own space station is tons of fun the way theese guys did it. Lots of ways to let your creative side run free and strategizing for those who like some action. It's always exciting to send a security detail to scout out a derelict ship, or prepare for boarding by pirates. Really like the idea of inhabitants personalities where they make friends and enemies amongs each other and situations it creates. I definately reccomend this tittle, don't believe all the bad things you hear, sometimes it's good to try stuff out on your own.

								Cooley Station was unfortunately designed to have a disastrously small selection of toilet facilities. The station’s industrial architect, Adolf Riker (a given name only recently returning to a brief but immense popularity after an extremely long hiatus) had studied under the Europan architectural school famous for its brief merger with the Plutonic school of Folk-Industrial psychology. At the time, a study of the Plutonic school had shown that workplace efficiency increased seven-fold where employees were unable to utilise the bathroom facilities and had to spend long periods yearning to pass fluids. Unfortunately it was only later discovered that the study had taken its entire sample from a pool of specially bred accountants genetically engineered to only excrete small unscented pellets every five to six years. The disposition of toilets on Cooley Station was one of the more famous and catastrophic results of the merger of the two schools, the other major notable example being the Plutonic embassy in Basra, which was constructed entirely out of fresh spring water and shaped into an immense♥♥♥♥♥♥

number of helpful: 1 of 10 people (10%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Though a number of reviewers quite zealously insist that this game is more like Dwarf Fortress than Prison Architect, I have never played Dwarf Fortress and would say that it is quite similar to Prison Architect from what I know.  The game is in early Alpha right now, so there is a limited depth of play, but it shows enormous potential.  For those that enjoy it there are a number of advantages to owning a game in Alpha, a large part of which is getting to see it grow and develop, along with being able to give feedback before everything is finalized. In essence the game is a space station sim.  You make a station, try to keep your people alive an happy, screen potential immigrants, explore derelicts, and get attacked by raiders.  Of course that’s a gross oversimplification, and trust me it’s much funnier and ridiculous as you play.  If you’re interested at all, you’ll probably like it.  At this stage it’ll likely leave you hungering for more once you stop accidentally suffocating your crew members or getting them killed by raiders.  But if you can be patient it’s very much worth your time.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								Not much to do yet. After a while you got little to do. Less to explore than Gnomoria or Towns. It would be fun if you could move the base around to a different part of the sector or dock to a moon or a planet. The little guys have a lot of data attached to them, but seems redudant and its hard to make them happy. Hard to monitor food, and what you need to produce more. There is a counter for minerals and oxygen but food is not as clear. Right now all engagements are options. You have to choices, if you want to fight or not, and you can select either. Characters are not memorable and also many wait too long to go back to the airlock and die. I wish I could send them back to the base earlier. They shouldn't die in routine jobs because they went to the airlock too late too often.

								Developers at Double Fine are consistently updating the game because it IS an Early Access/Beta. I am glad I got SpaceBase DF-9 on sale for about ten bucks, but it is definitely not worth twenty. I suggest waiting for it to go on sale if you want to try it out.In SpaceBase DF-9, there's no micro-managing. The A.I. take on a life of their own once you give them a task so it can get rather frustrating. And most of them are very, very moody, which affect their work ethic severely (ugh). They're fairly stupid at their current stage of development, so you can expect to lose a base very quickly - regardless of whether you're playing the game correctly or not. And if your base doesn't fall apart right away, it will eventually. It takes quite a while to understand how each A.I. functions (due to their personalities) and how to work around them. Even with all that said, it's a very fun game. I have fun, anyway. It helps that I enjoy simulator games. It's space sims! Sorta.

content:

Early Access Review
								Great game with much potential.. Sure I struggled a bit at first, lost many crews, but all in all they've done a nice job.. I do have a couple of gripes that I'll post here, but I'm sure it's already on their to-do list of stuff to fix:My biggest complaint is the fact that it looks like I’m commander of some of the stupidest aliens in the entire galaxy.  I had a derelict ship enter my sector, so I sent some guards to check it out. Well as soon as they did, they decided to take brief naps afterwards.  It wasn’t so bad trying to get them to leave, but when the oxygen generators failed, they started running around like chickens with their heads cut off.  My genius repair technicians decided to head over there and fix the problem, but their first step was take off their life giving suits and join the orgy of morons by running around with them.  Why they didn’t just keep their suit on, fix the unit and then take off those stinky suits is beyond me.  My only option was to destroy the ship with all the morons on board.All in all the game is addicting, even with all its flaws.. Here’s hoping they fix this craziness with some better AI or at least more logical ones.

Early Access Review
								Not much to do yet. After a while you got little to do. Less to explore than Gnomoria or Towns. It would be fun if you could move the base around to a different part of the sector or dock to a moon or a planet. The little guys have a lot of data attached to them, but seems redudant and its hard to make them happy. Hard to monitor food, and what you need to produce more. There is a counter for minerals and oxygen but food is not as clear. Right now all engagements are options. You have to choices, if you want to fight or not, and you can select either. Characters are not memorable and also many wait too long to go back to the airlock and die. I wish I could send them back to the base earlier. They shouldn't die in routine jobs because they went to the airlock too late too often.

Early Access Review
								Developers at Double Fine are consistently updating the game because it IS an Early Access/Beta. I am glad I got SpaceBase DF-9 on sale for about ten bucks, but it is definitely not worth twenty. I suggest waiting for it to go on sale if you want to try it out.In SpaceBase DF-9, there's no micro-managing. The A.I. take on a life of their own once you give them a task so it can get rather frustrating. And most of them are very, very moody, which affect their work ethic severely (ugh). They're fairly stupid at their current stage of development, so you can expect to lose a base very quickly - regardless of whether you're playing the game correctly or not. And if your base doesn't fall apart right away, it will eventually. It takes quite a while to understand how each A.I. functions (due to their personalities) and how to work around them. Even with all that said, it's a very fun game. I have fun, anyway. It helps that I enjoy simulator games. It's space sims! Sorta.

number of helpful: 1 of 10 people (10%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								[EDIT] I wrote this review when I assumed (hoped!) funding would continue and the game would reach its promising potential. With version 1.0 on the way and a general air of abandonment from DF, I'm less keen to recommend this. I still load it up now and again and lament the missed opportunity...================I'm offering up a cautious recommendation here. This game is very promising, while still being far from a complete experience in its current state (Alpha 5d). I bought it on the strength of it being made by Double Fine, who I think have a habit of putting out some really fun games. The recommendation is partially based on their reputation.As other reviewers have mentioned, the UI is great and the overall aesthetic brings to mind 70s/ 80s SF such as Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy or Dark Star. Having said that, the devs should really set about implementing some goal-based gameplay soon enough. It seems an odd move to put it out in its current state since there's not the level of freedom for it to act simply as a light space survival sim. There isn't really enough depth at the moment for the player to come up with their own objectives beyond not dying for long enough to build a space-pub. In its current state it looks like you can try out all the space- decor and experience the space- mining and space- pirates in a fairly short stretch of time. Basically, I love the content so far and I'd like there to be more. I really hope there is continued support and funding on this project. There have been a few negative reviews on Steam but most people acknowledge the potential here. I look forward to seeing the updates and in the meantime, I can set about building my Silent Running style interstellar greenhouse.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
Early Access Review
								Update:This is definitely a promising alpha, and many of the issues I'd mentioned in the previous version of my review have been fixed or improved.- The technician AI is very much improved.- I haven't run into issues with bartenders holding up people at the bar, except when I didn't have enough bartenders assigned, which seems reasonable- Intruder defense seems more manageable now, though the actual mechanics don't seem to have changed.- Haven't seen any more accidental depressurizations in a whileThe only part that is still somewhat frustrating is the builder sequencing. While building walls and floors still seems to be prioritized above everything else, tear down or vaporizing unused areas is still prioritized above building other objects. I'd love to see a queue that I can prioritize, but failing that, at least making tear down/vaporizing last in the priority list would be an improvement. Even better than that would be only deprioritizing those tasks if they're part of unclaimed structures.Some other issues I've noticed:- Occasionally people will get stuck in airlocks and eventually suffocate- There are sometimes odd placement issues with room objects randomly getting removed from the building queue, or sometimes not being able to place an object in a place that you should. I've had this happen with research consoles, beds, and rugs--------------------------------------Original Review--------------------------------------This looks promising, but in its current state, is not very fun to play. Most of the issues center around not-very-effective AI:- In order to keep your base functioning, you need technicians to keep all the systems in repair. However, the technician AI is TERRIBLE, and there's no way to force a technician to repair a specific machine. The only way I've been able to play is to keep my base relatively small. Once a hostile docks with my station and as a result, adds more machines, it's an unrecoverable downhill slide to all machines eventually breaking down, no matter how many technicians I add. I've also seen my technicians attempting to repair broken machinery in areas I'm deconstructing, which is a huge waste of time.- Your citizens need to eat. They also need to sleep. If they go to the bar to eat or drink, and the bartender isn't on duty, they'll wait until he is. Even if the bartender is, himself, waiting to eat or drink. The bartenders will not serve themselves, nor is there any sort of timer that allows them to give up and move on to do something else. There's also no way to force a bartender to go on duty. When your citizens get stuck waiting on food, it makes it very easy to start a downward spiral (especially for technicians) since they obviously aren't doing their jobs if they're waiting for food.- Defending against intruders is incredibly unreliable. From what I can tell, you're supposed to assign citizens to security duty, and use a beacon to make them congregate in a specific area, either to explore or defend against intruders. In practice, they seem to take an "I'll get to it when I'll get to it" attitude, even when their comrades are getting gunned down around them.- Sequencing building instructions is irritating - things seem to happen only in the order you enter them in - once you put in a request, there's no way to prioritize it against other requests, except to erase it and do it again, effectively putting it at the end of the queue. The exception seems to be building walls - those seem to get built before anything else.- Citizens coming in and out of airlocks will occasionally kill their comrades by an ill-timed depressurizationGiven this is an alpha, I'm guessing/hoping these issues will be smoothed out, but as it stands, it is more frustrating to play than enjoyable.

If you aren't a fan of linear games and like management games then I think you should buy it.This is my opinion you probably won't agree with it, but still If your interested in a game watch gameplay of it and you will know if you want it.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												Though this game had its development cut short, which was admittedly disappointing, its is still a solid game and one of the better city sims I have played in a while. So please, before judging solely on the fact that development was cut short, hear me out. If you wanna skip the points i will have a final verdict at the endPros1. No preset rooms, you build how you want2. Dialogue is rather humorous and reading people's thoughts normally gives me a good laugh.3. The resource management is just right, not too complex, but not too easy either.4. Since there are no templates you can really make your base yours. If you want the center of your base to be a nice dorm room thats totally doable. If you want to make it a huge club, all up to you!5. The game keeps you on your toes and often provides great stories such as when one of my engineers went crazy and caught an oxygen recycler on fire and had to be taken down by security!6. People interact and all have different opinions of each other. They may become best friends or end up knocking each other out!7. Passing ships will signal you, you may recruit a bunch of aliens waking from their cryo chambers or tell raiders you're gonna kick their butts!Cons1. Raiders get a bit overpowered in later stages of the game2. Morale is hard to regain after it drops and often leads to the end of your base3. dialogue, while funny is quite limited. You will definitely see the same phrases more than once.4. This game had insane potential, unfortunately many concept ideas that would have been great will now never be includedFinal verdict: While it isnt a perfect game, spacebase possesses a lot of charm and an amazing amount of freedom. If you are a fan of sim games and think this may interest you, at least grab it on sale. Its a great sim game that has many disappointed fans who look at it for what it could have been rather than what it is

content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								Do you like resource management type games? Do you like simulation type games? Do you like science fiction? If you answered yes to two of the previous questions you should check out Spacebase DF-9. Even though this is an Early Access Game there is still enough playability and fun in it to occupy hours of your life. Basically you build a space station or as the name suggests a Spacebase. You do this by laying out rooms and zoning them for specific tasks. At first you'll need an airlock and a life support system so that your virtual Spacebase residents can breath. As you play, you'll discover that you need to expand, and that takes resources. You'll need to build more rooms and different types of zones to make your Spacebase function. Things like refineries, sleeping quarters and pubs. Yes, they have pubs in space.To add to the gameplay each of your Spacebase residents has his or her special skill set. You need to assign them tasks based on their individual skills or train them in new ones, if you wish. As they get better at their tasks the station starts to hum along nicely. As you progress, you'll discover that the natives get restless and you'll need to attend to their complaints and unhappiness by building new rooms or maybe mixing up their work routine. All that is enough to keep you busy, but there is more. Every now and again a spaceship will pass by. They can be friendly folk and join your Spacebase or they can be your worst day in space. Sometimes you can weasel your way out of sticky situations but eventually something is going to rain on your Spacebase. You'll need to prepare for that eventuality and defend your Spacebase if you want to hold onto it. This is an Early Access Game and it’s in Alpha 4b as of this writing. Even so, there is plenty of fun to be had with this game. Double Fine Productions, the developer, is actively releasing updates. They are shooting for updates on a monthly basis and that’s good. Now I don’t want to mislead you. I’m having a ton of fun with this game, but it is and Early Access Game and it’s still in Alpha. That means it’s not for everyone. The game isn’t finished. It’s not even close to finished. It’s Alpha. Don’t buy this game expecting a polished game. Even if you have Beta tested before, keep in mind that this is pre-beta. That said, this game promises to be something extremely fun to play. If you want to be in on the ground floor and watch, as well as give feedback, as the game develops then you should definitely pick up a copy of Spacebase DF-9. It’s okay, the waters warm, jump in. You will have fun.

content:
Posted: October 22, 2013
Early Access Review
								Explore the perils of space. My first crew died because I didn't install the airlock correctly and they ran out of oxygen. My second crew died after a ship flew in and dropped off a parasite-infested crew member, who later died and spawned a parasite that rampaged through my base. My third crew died when I got boarded by a hostile ship. My fourth crew died when they got stuck in a wall and ran out of oxygen (but hey, it's early access).This game is like the FTL of space base building. It'd hard. But it's got amusing touches like the crew's personal logs, and the delicate balance of "should I explore and risk an alien attack?" Still early and a bit shallow, but has potential.

number of helpful: 13 of 36 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
Early Access Review
								This is an excellent start to what the developers hope to eventually achieve with the game. At the moment you can build your base (including multiple rooms), take on new residents (meaning you'll soon need to expand your base to cope with the extra people), fight off hostile enemies, claim "derelict" bases nearby as an expansion of your main base, and assign each resident to a job, which they progressively get better at.Eventually, you'll have a well-run base that is looked after by a team of highly trained staff, but to get to that point, you might have to survive a couple of scares near the beginning of the game (a meteor strike which leaves your base on fire when your technicians aren't well-trained to deal with it, or raiders when your security forces aren't trained up, etc).In the future, the devs want to add depth to the game with a research system, job zoning, and so on. Once those are implemented, the game will really be something. I think there's enough for more than a few hours of enjoyment here already. Definitely recommended.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												This game is the Chaos Theory evolved. Whatever can go wrong does go wrong. But it's not that expected mishap that you can see coming. No it's that 'This is kinda dumb' series of events. So the threat factor set to low causes my base of 6 people to get raided 5 times. Okay then... And debris hits only the life support, 4 times, during these raid attacks. Oooohkay. My citizens keep complaining about 'stuff' when there are well over ten shelves placed in living quarters which for some reason they decide to not stay in regardless if I put them SPECIFICALLY to a room. This game needs re-tooling. Stopped playing when I got 20 citizens then one just randomly started punching people, while a raider that was left incapacitated in my base got up and joined in on the fun.In short, 10/10 only for the execute button as I placed 5 people on security and started dropping people before opening the airlock to suck those 5 out into space. Only to have a ship pass by and tell me my base was cool as it was in ruin....Also I didn't laugh once at this game. Was I supposed to laugh at all the wacky♥♥♥♥♥♥because I didn't.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								An addicting space station creation-simulation reminscent of Dwarf Fortress, Spacebase throws you alone into the cold, deep darkness of space with nothing but 8 minutes of oxygen and a recommendation to quickly build a life support zone. The rest is up to you, as you are left to quickly build a functioning space station and hopefully turn your tiny crew of three space colonists into a fully functioning space outpost.If you're a fan of Gnomoria, Banished, or Towns, then definitely pick this one up. I'm very excited to see what future updates offer, and I hope they come soon!

content:
Posted: August 2, 2015

content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								Absolutely fantastic fun to play. The only frustrations come not from gameplay, but the little glitches etc. that are to be expected at an alpha stage of development. Two concerns right now are that your citizens can be doomed to eternally eating at the pub, never to leave until you quit and reload the game. I have had excess food and yet had many crew members die of starvation. It's frustrating to see someone starving and scream "THE FRIDGE IS RIGHT THERE, JAMES." and then have James say "no, there are people eating in the bar right now, I'll wait my turn". Meanwhile, in the timelocked existence that is the bar, 9 citizens stand at tables, frozen, looking ahead as if they've seen something I haven't. The food is long gone, but they're still eating. Forever eating. Basically, the timer freezes and stops going down.Also, when mining matter, crew members have an unexplicable urge to return from whence they came. When you have to venture away from your base in order to continue mining operations elsewhere, you think to yourself 'I'll just place another airlock and refinery here. That'll be convenient.' Nope. Instead, miners will ignore that airlock, deciding instead to head for the MOST DISTANT AIRLOCK IN THE QUADRENT. I have a silent dialogue in my head with them."Bill. I built you this airlock and refinery. I even built a long path down from the original base so you don't waste oxygen getting out here, see?""Ahh thank you sir, I appreciate that""Bill....you're going out of the far away airlock.""I know.""...why?""♥♥♥♥ it, it was closer"".........""dum dee dum dee dum""Bill?""yes sir?""why did you go PAST the airlock that's right next to the mining field""I'm heading home?""I know that Bill. I know. But you could have gone through there and just...WALKED up.""Nah I'm good.""BILL.""WHAT.""YOUR OXYGEN IS ON 30 SECONDS GO TO THE GODDAM CLOSE AIRLOCK""Nah man, YOLO"*Bill has died from asphyxiation*"...♥♥♥♥ you, Bill."I don't know if you're starting to notice some slight frustration I feel towards my dear citizens, but they will be patched soon and hell, I'm still playing aren't I? In all, though, such a good game, and it'll only get better.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is strangely and frustratingly addicting.It's by no means finished; at time of writing, Alpha 4b is the current release. Some major and glaring pieces of the game are missing. There are no doctors or infirmies to heal people from injuries, and bugs abound. AI pathing is a work in progress. The difficulty curve needs to be balanced more, and base immigration is hit or miss. Right now, the game is crying out for some sort of debug mode or option. It'd be nice to force events or otherwise peak under the hood right now to see what's going on. Adding some hints to improve morale would be welcome, too.Overall, the game is more than promising. It shows a proper spark of fun and creativity, with tons of good ideas and some solid concepts to build off of.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
												Update: All the negative reviews I read for this game were before the November 14 1.06 update, which fixed a lot of the bugs that these reviewers were discussing. I played the game for the first time after this update had already occurred.Raiders, space debris, nosy passenger ships, quiet derelict vessels, deadly diseases, and parasites that jump out of an empty husk which used to be one of your citizens. That's what you face when you become the Administrator of Spacebase DF-9. You will truly feel like the manager of a tiny oasis, alone in the vastness of a harsh galaxy.To get a summary of what it's like to play this game, combine the play styles of a small-scope RTS like Age of Mythology with The Sims. Not only do you have to build, maintain, and defend a space station, but you must also make sure you're tending to the needs of your citizens.Frustrations abound. Just when you have finally constructed a small, functional base, complete with power and air, your citizens will have the gall to ask for a place to sleep. Then, they'll want something to eat. Then they'll need a doctor. Then they'll want someplace to hang out with friends. Then your base needs a maintenance technician, but no one wants the job. Now they want a gym, but you're still trying to build the infirmary because two citizens died in the last Raider attack. But now there aren't enough power reactors! So you've zoned the construction to build a bigger power room, but then some Raider blew holes in your airlock in a firefight and now the whole thing is useless. But hey, at least he suffocated. Pompous jerk. Anyway, you've got to refit another room as an emergency airlock, to fix the airlock, so you can build the next reactor, to build the infirmary, and then ultimately build a gym, but darn it all, your Builder's feeling overworked so they went to bed! And NO, I do NOT want to answer your request to come aboard, random passenger ship!In many ways, I find this game to be a very realistic depiction of what it would probably be like to lead your own vessel out in space. You have to fight constantly against the threatening, invasive, hostile environment, while not letting your crew's own loneliness overcome them. Think about it. Suppose you were one of your citizens: one of a group of ten people stranded out in, truly, the middle of nowhere, with no chance of ever seeing Earth again. No wonder my overworked builder is having trouble staying motivated, and no wonder most of my crew spends their free time in the pub. We all might want to think that living in space would be cool, but Spacebase DF-9 reminds us of the human element.Yes, there are still minor graphical bugs, and sometimes your Miner will asphyxiate because they were too stupid to get back inside before their eight minutes of oxygen was up. However, no technical glitch any worse than this has happened to me in the time I've been playing; most of the frustrations are caused by realistic depiction of the situation. But like in Kerbal Space Program or any other pleasantly challenging game, when you overcome the trials of the moment, you will feel an immense sense of reward watching your citizens live the lives you have given them among the stars.
