content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
												Oh my.This could have been an awesome game, but they gave up on it, left it half finished, and had to call it done. DF-9 isn't a bad game, the part of it that is finished is pretty awesome and fun to play, until you run into balencing issues that hault the game. I don't know how common of a problem that is, but it seems that all the games I play end up with a negative feed back loop where if enough of the citizens become unhappy, everything on the station starts to not go well, resulting in more unhappyness. what's worse, is no explanation of why. The Wiki for the game is incomplete at best, so there is very little insight into how the game is supposed to be played.I recommend this game because I owned a copy of space colony, and it was awesome. As it stands, Space Colony is currently better and less frustrating although more than a few generations of gaming old. Spacebase DF-9 is still being worked on, and will hopefully keep improving. All the issues I currently have with the game could be fixed in future patching, and BETTER be fixed or this game will be a hightly polished turd that could have been made of gold.TLDR: Game needs balencing to be worth buying. Try Space Colony if you want this kind of game.

number of helpful: 5 of 19 people (26%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												This game feels like it's going to be extremely good.  But right now it's more like a horror game.  The whole time you're playing, you have this horrific, sinking feeling that something is going to happen that makes absolutely no sense, and you'll have to restart (or, more likely, quit).I've played several times on earlier versions, and I just played 3 games on the latest alpha (6b).  First game, I ran out of minerals before I built my refinery.  Whoops.  Second game my guys finished the building, but then wouldn't enter it, despite everything being apparently in order.  They all died of asphyxiation.  Third game, I got the base up and running, things were looking great, but then meteors came and smashed into my base.  While no walls or floor were visibly damaged, the oxygen dropped to 0% and everyone died.I can't say the game is just flat out broken, but it sure feels like it.That being said, the potential is there... they just need to get this out of alpha.  I really wish they hadn't made it early access so darn early.  This latest update does not fix the game enough to warrant being released as early access yet.I think I'll love this game eventually, but it pains me to say that I think they released this so early in order to fund other projects. The developers may love this game, deep down.  "But it's not who you are underneath, it's what you do that defines you."Edit: Is it any surprise that people disliked this negative review, and yet, I feel I hit the nail on the head now that the game has been "released".

number of helpful: 5 of 19 people (26%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've been playing the alpha 5b (Doctors with Boarders) build, and the game definitely has promise.Not everything works yet (e.g. power reactors don't seem to serve a purpose), and some things work when they probably shouldn't (e.g. the wall mounted turrets inside the base seem to be able to shoot raider ships that are outside).  The game also currently lacks any tutorial content, so you'll need to learn by playing or look for outside information.  There is enough there to enjoy, although after a few hours you'll probably reach the end of what's available and need to restart keep it from getting boring.There is minimal micro-management options available in the game (you can assign jobs to people and tell them to go to the infirmary), so you need to be careful how much work you queue up since there is no way to prioritise it.  There are other mechanics that don't work so well, such as sending security personel to derelict bases to investigate: the bases always seemed to be hostile and I would end up with some of my people dying.  I found it easier to deal with these bases by getting a builder to knock holes in a few walls to vent the atmosphere first.You can already see some of the humour that Double Fine is known for.  Each person has a SpaceFace feed where they make notes about their day.  There is humour in some of the game mechanics, such as doctors getting rid of the dead bodies in the same matter refineries used by the miners.It'll be interesting to see how the game develops.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								My first experience with this game involved scrambling to build an airlock and life support structure so my poor crew could breathe that sweet sweet air before asphyxiation ended their greatest adventure.  Sadly I was too late and my workers did not understand the importance of building that suit locker which would allow the air lock to operate properly.  So I watched as my worker scrambled to build the suit locker that would save his life only to be a few seconds too late.  He and the rest of my crew succumbed to the cruelest of fates; I can only hope it was painless.  Armed with new experience and a greater understanding of the fragility of life in space I took another bold step forward and my second base was born.  Things went much better for much longer.  The basics were established with ease and in a very timely fashion.  Mining operations were going smoothly and I was about to establish a pub for recreation and relaxation.  My builder was ordered to remove some interior walls in order to expand a room and it was hoped that he would finish the exterior walls first (you know the ones keeping the cold empty death void that is space outside of my lovely base.)  Alas this was not to be and as the second crew member was pulled into the blackness of both death and the cosmos I knew I had learned another valuable lesson in the fragility of life in space.  With just these few experiences I must say that Spacebase DF-9 has a lot to offer even as an early release.  It is a little rough around the edges and your workers will tend to aggravate you with poor decision making, but stick with it and you will be proud of your accomplishments in time.  Failure and loss is a part of this game so don’t be too frustrated when you need to start over from scratch.  If you enjoy building and management games you should at least give this a shot.

												Meh meh meh, meh meh meh. That's what almost every negative review here sounds like. All they talk about is how double fine abandoned spacebase DF-9 (which is true, but that doesn't really qualify as a reason for bad reviews.). Honestly, the gameplay here is a bit glitchy (a doctor carries away a dead body but still shows corpse, etc.), but I myself enjoyed this game (until I moved on to other games), mostly because It looked somewhat like prison architect, but less just spamming the HIRE A GUARD! button (not that I own that game, but I have played once or twice, and thats where a lot of my time went) and more problems to take care of. Now, onto the gameplay besides the prison architect style building stuff. 1: more controlled problems. In pris. arch., all you really need to worry about is food. Here you have emotions, job liking, oxygen, sleep, and nothing more that I can remember. 2: uncontrollable problems: in prison arch., you have riots. Here, you have brawls, meteor strikes, fires, betrayals, parasites and raiders. nuf' said. I like this game, so I hope you read this actually sensible review, and buy spacebase DF-9.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												        This game was made by an interesting company called Double Fine. The game it self has left early alpha and has became a full game already, now i will emit this game could of been worked on alot more then it currently is. The game many 'preset' areas that you can pick from, but each area is actually randomized as to how it's looked. i played in the same area two times before and the asteriods was layed out different, i had different encounters and much more.        Now alot of people are non-recommending this game simply because they don't see it being complete. now i do slightly agree there, but there is alot in this game you have to spend time playing to actually find. one example would be there is more research than the ones you can get at the begining once you build a research lab. Random data cores can spawn with derelict ships which have random chances to apear. so you could get a late game research earily on or just get a low grade research.        When double fine released this into full game, they had said it wasn't to the level they wanted, they wanted to do so much more with this game but they wasn't able to do it. So instead of just scrapping the game entire like some people believe they've done. They have actually given it to us... to the people of the modding community to create things for it that they would like to have seen in it. Many games have been made alot better thanks to the modding community, games that have had more things than this one even. Yet Double Fine has still been doing updates to the game to balance the game and less bugs to the game.        As for actually gameplay, the game runs fairly smooth and there use to be many annoying things that happened in the game. But the game does have random generation, so you wont have the same game twice. one game you could have an entirely peacefull game, never running into Raiders, or Aliens let alone other things. while one game you could get hit near the begining and get slaughtered, Which this is slightly factored by your chosen start location, for some has more likely hood of one thing than another would. Example: One section has tons of asteriods and rare encounters, while another has medium asteriods and very common encounters.         all in all, i actually believe it's a good Space Station Building simulation game, that many people wouldn't of thought to make, the only real bad thing of this game is the Ai i will emit mainy on the builders, if you want to remove spot in a room or anything be prepared for massive pausing and quick selection, for they will try to kill them selves at times, though i have never had to unbuild anything, because i never seen a reason to do so unless i was doubling a room, which was easy to save my builders. If You think when placing security markers that something is wrong and your security isn't going to the location, it's because either 1. their asleep. (you can't wake them up you gotta let them sleep for as long as they wish). 2. you actually don't have any (pay attention to the jobs you assign) or 3. There is no phyiscal way for them to reach the location.    I will emit this is the first time i've done a review for any game, but i believed i needed to after seeing so many negative reviews that was for reasons that in my opinion didn't fit as a good full on review of the game. This game is still a nice game to play on the side, and in my opinion once the modding community actually starts making mods and more if they haven't already, this game could become even more interesting just like Double Fine is trusting us to do.i personally would rate the game, but i'm not good at picking right numbers to what i feel it should be, it's not a game you'll want to just spend hours apon hours playing, though sometimes when you start you'll get a bit addicted.. untill your space station is killed and you rage. but you can't live forever.

number of helpful: 0 of 9 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												Before you rage at me, yes there are loads of bugs, and yes the development is "finished". I know this, so either take note of my review or shut up.For those who actually want to read my review, I say in short this game is good if you like base management, but buy it on a ridiculous sale.The last game I played that could be compared to this is Prison Architect, so I'll compare to that. This game has its ups and downs, but I found that Prison Architect became a bit stale after a while; build fast at the start, expand for new prisoners, work on efficiency. Rinse and Repeat. Not that it wasn't good, but that's the gist of it.Spacebase Df-9 on the other hand, was a somewhat evolving base management, and a bit of tower defence thrown in when raiders visit too. Once you get the hang of it, you need to constantly adapt your base to make room for new people, keep up with the component decay and so on. One of the hardest bits (albeit interesting) I found was defending against multiple raiders. If you can manage to defeat the raiders, you're then left with a depressed crew (that don't want to work) that needs to repair the remains of the station and hold out until more people show up... or more raiders.I honestly haven't seen any game breaking bugs yet (touch wood!). Bodies stick around for ages, but with enough doctors they get moved over time. Components decay rapidly, but with the right balance you can keep them in check until you research better things. And yes, research takes ages too, but it's helpful if you're around long enough to finish it.All in all, it can be problematic, and there are plenty of issues people have talked about, but with patience and taking the time to learn the game, it can be pretty fun. Maybe a 7/10 from me, buy it on a very good sale.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
Early Access Review



YouTube™ Video: Spacebase DF-9 - My Best Base Yet! 

			Views: 105		

			This is my most successful base yet! I think I made it about 3.5 hours before the SHTF. I was able to keep the base going even after that happened, building back up to about 27 citizens.		

This is a great start on the game so far. It can be a lot of fun, or really frustrating, but overall a satisfying experience if you are into roguelike games... and can handle some bugs that absolutely will kill you when they happen. Development of the game is a bit slow, but it's steady. I'm definitely a supporter of the game, and I definitely recommend it... so long as you're patient enough to deal with such an unforgiving game.I don't think it will ever be an *easy* game, but due to some current bugs it can be overbearingly hard. The above video is the longest living base I've built so far. I played about an hour longer after the end of this video, and probably could have kept playing indefinitely... but due to some kind of bug my technicians just refused to do any serious work to repairing the base, and I got fed up with it. I've played a few more games since then, but most games don't last longer than an hour. When you do get that one game like this though, it can really make it feel like it's all worth it.

number of helpful: 24 of 65 people (37%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												Now that the Early Access and broken promises are over, it's time to review this game as what it is. Forget about the development plans for now, and just focus on what was delivered.Spacebase DF-9 is definitely playable and can keep your attention for a few hours, as you struggle with a not too clever AI to survive the problems the game throws at you.You start out with next to nothing and your first priority is to build and airlock, a room around the seed pod for power, and a life support room for oxygen generation. From then on you will be constantly trying to expand as new crewmembers arrive all the time, and you will face problems like boarders, raiders, alien parasites, base breaches, and crewmen going crazy and causing damage.There is no real goal to this game other than survive. Eventually you will figure out how to create a base capable of sustaining 50 people, and the game will have reached the end: there will be nothing left to do except wait for people to die and be replaced.The game has an unfinished feel about it and that is the main reason I cannot possibly recommend this at full price, but if you can get it at a good discount and do not look at the scrapped plans for the full version, you will probably have at least some fun with it.

number of helpful: 2 of 17 people (12%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												I actually bought this game after reading all the negative reviews because I wanted to see how bad it was. I thought it might be so bad that I'd get a chance to write a funny review and laugh about it with my friends.I was shocked to discover that I actually liked it. DF-9 has much better graphics than any other dwarf-fortress-lite game I've played, and it's quite challenging while fun. I get the feeling that a lot of the hate directed at this game is due to the fact that the developers promised a lot more than they delivered on, but what's here is still pretty and enjoyable.The are some weird gameplay decisions - like the fact that when ships dock at your base, they bypass your defenses automatically and essentially becomes a new randomly generated chunk of your base. However, this can be countered by building floor in strips outside your base to keep ships from from interfering with it... so it's a weird mechanic, but it has a counter and doesn't ruin the fun.A lot of the encounters feel like they were just intended as placeholders - they feel a bit rushed.I played the game for over 32 hours, enjoyed it, and found it hard to put down... so I'd have to say overall I think I got my money's worth.

Franky, the game looks a good bit better than it used to, and the features in the trailer are in the game, so if it looks fun, it probably will be regardless of the reviews. And it's $20, even less now that it's on sale, plus they released the source code, so there's a lot of potential for mods. I know some people have said that 20 bucks is too much, but I don't think it is. Standards for game prices have gone waaaay down. Plus you can get Hack'n'Slash cheap, which is a really unique and interesting game. My only suggestion for potential buyers is to look up some videos of the game in action and make your decision that way, and not put much stock in the reviews, because many of them are colored by their expectations of early access, rather than focused on the finished product.

number of helpful: 5 of 27 people (19%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												Now I let me prefrice this by saying that I did not buy this game, I got it for free at launch with me having bought Hack n' Slash so I don't have as much attachment nor need to justify this purchise. Now with that out of the way I do want to mention that I do enjoy this game, it hits all the same centers as Dwarf fortress did. I will and do recomend this game to anyone who likes Dwarf fortress and Gnomeariea.Now for anyone who wants some more info on this title and not just a breif blurb. Starbase DF-9 is a take on your Dwarf fortress style game I personaly like it more but this is my byis towards space over fantasy. For those of you who do not know what this game or style of game is let's run this down real quick. In these style of game you take a small group of settlers and build a base having to harvest rescorces, defend your land make everyone happy. This is much harder then you would think, and these games suscribe to the idea that loseing is fun, you either ram your head into it and start to learn how to play it through sevrial fresh runs. Double Fine did a great job as usuial with it's sense of humor in a game although for them this is a weaker showing, which is stil better then most "ha ha we're funny" games bring us. The graphics are styleized and rich the artists did a nice job in the 2d art you see in dialoge but I do feel that the models coud use some work, although this still could grow on me and is made to make it easier to tell at a glace who is doing what in your base.This game has a lot of potential but it did not and is not paying for its devlopement which is a sad thing so that game finalised early and is only a shadow of what they wanted to bring us. I hope that as this game sits on steam and sells they can make more patches to bring us the content they want us to have and make a okay game a stong game for those in this neich of gaming.

number of helpful: 2 of 21 people (10%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												Spacebase DF-9 is a space station-building tycoon game with a storied development. Initially conceived during developer Double Fine's Amnesia Fortnight event, Spacebase went on to enter early access with hopes of a long, successful development period which would allow the game to keep expanding for years to come. Despite promising early sales numbers the development couldn't sustain itself and was cut much shorter than everyone expected. Version 1.0 does still offer a full experience, albeit one with quite a few bugs and rough edges. For more, check out the  VIDEO REVIEW

number of helpful: 8 of 50 people (16%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												Well I have to start with saying that I am really surprised by all the negative comments on this game......but then again I bought this game in alpha, played about an hour, forgot about it after getting into other games and then when I got back to it there were tons of new features. At this point I had a blast playing it (even in its alpha state I could easily get 10+ hours of gameplay) and was sure that small balances and tweaks would add a lot to the games value. I guess would sum it all up to I was not really expecting much. So as It is now I really enjoy the game, with no bias of previously reading dev posts of false promises and what could have been. What it is right now is a modern version of a god game where your in space.... think dwarf fortress meets the sims with a dash of spacestation sim. It does have its bugs and it is a shame that they still exist in the full 1.0 release but I am confident they will patch the problems over time.As for everyone being hurt by how the devs represented themselves, the game, and double fine, (after reading the many reviews on this game) It really does suck. But Hey - At least it's not Infestation. Or any other of those super scamy games.... you got to admit that this game comes out as something pretty decent, even though it might still be a prototype.

Which for those who don't know, basically backers were promised a lot of features that they later cut in order to push the game to launch due to lack of money.Politics aside, Spacebase DF-9 is a good game. It has a lot of character, makes you smile at corny jokes, looks pretty good, and in general is a good colony management game. I don't think I can flat out reccommend it at $20, but if you pick it up during a sale I'm sure you'll find it well worth the money.
